| wish it were possible for me. personally to extend a warm handshake of greeting to every visitor. Since
it isn't, allow me to express my cordial welcome in the printed word. As mayor of the city, | voice

Baltimore's welcome with the heartiness typical of Southern hospitality.

There are many sides to Baltimore. If you are artistically inclined and are fond of paintings and bronzes,
you'll get a real thrill when you visit our Art Museum. The building itself, is an architectural gem and the

art objects in it have been very carefully selected.

If you fancy picturesque scenery, you'll go into raptures when you see Druid Hill Park. It is one of the
great parks in the land, embracing over seven hundred acres of gloriously inspiring landscape. Be sure



UHE

Plan to see Baltimore in all its charming facets. The scene around the War Memorial, the City Hall Plaza
and the City Hall will remind you of picturesque Berlin.

The old world dignity of Mt. Vernon Place will bring up memories of the Place Vendome in Paris

And Lexington Street in our shopping district may bring up visions of Piccadilly Circus in London.
Try to catch the spirit of Baltimore. A stroll through Guilford, Homeland and Roland Park, our most

impressive suburban section, will show you that Baltimoreans appreciate the finer things . . . and know

how to live.

to see lovely Druid Lake. If you have any children, take them to the zoo, by all means. Queen Rambai-

Barni of Siam described Druid Hill Park as one of the most beautiful she ever visited.

Now when it comes to the historic, Baltimore is rich in landmarks and in shrines of history. Baltimore
opens many breathtaking pages of past glories. Of course, you're planning to see Fort McHenry. This
famous fort was the scene of the memorable repulse of the British fleet in 1814.

stirring battle that Francis Scott Key wrote the “Star Spangled Banner.”

The Shot Tower is another well-known landmark. It was erected in 1828 and is the only one of its kind

in America.

Then, we have superbly sculptured monuments by the score. Baltimore is known as the ““Monumental
City” and has certainly earned the honor. First,” among our important monuments is the impressive

It was during this’

You'll find that our hotels enjoy offering superb service to the visitor within our midst.

The delicacies in sea food and Southern food are to be had in Baltimore at their best.- Modestly, | say

W ashington Monument in quaint Mt. Vernon Place. It was the first public monument erected by any
city or state in memory of George Woashington. A tour of the monuments, shrines, tablets and other
historical places should give you several pleasant afternoons.

Municipa| Tour One

One-hour Motor Trip from the City Hall
to the Mansion House in Druid Hill Park

Start at the City Hall Plaza, corner of Holliday and Lexington
Streets. Facing the City Hall on the east is the imposing War
Memorial Building. In the block next to the City Hall is the
new Municipal Office Building. On the opposite side of
Holliday Street is the Municipal Museum.



South on Holliday Street to Fayette. West on Fayette to
Calvert. In the plaza is the Battle Monument, erected more
than 100 years ago in commemoration of the victories at the
Battle of Baltimore (North Point) and in the attack on Fort
McHenry in 1814. On the right is the new Postoffice. On
the left is the city's $3,000,000 Courthouse, containing
picturesque mural paintings depicting the early history of the
city and state.

South on Calvert to Redwood. West on Redwood to Light.
On the northeast corner there is a tablet on the site of the
Fountain Inn, where George Washington was entertained on
many occasions in Colonial days. .

North on Light Street to Baltimore—On the southwest corner
is the Baltimore Trust Building, 34 stories, total height 500
feet, the city's tallest structure. On the northeast corner is the
city's oldest bank, its charter dating from 1795.

North on Light Street (St. Paul St.) to Fayette. West on
Fayette Street to Green—On the southeast corner stands old
W estminster Presbyterian Church and graveyard, which con-
tains the remains of Edgar Allan Poe, poet and writer, and

author of “'The Raven''.

South on Green Street to Baltimore, thence east to Howard
Street, thence north to Saratoga. This section just passed through
is the heart of Baltimore's retail shopping district, containing
nearly all of the large department stores and specialty shops.
The district extends a short distance westward.

East on Saratoga Street to Charles—On the southeast corner
is St. Paul’s P. E. Church, the oldest congregation in Baltimore.
The present edifice stands on the site of the original lot bought
in 1830 for $10.

North on Charles Street to Mulberry—On the northeast
corner is the Roman Catholic Archepiscopal residence, for
many years the home of James Cardinal Gibbons, the first
American to be given the Red Hat by the Vatican.

West on Mulberry Street to Cathedral, thence north on
Cathedral—On the right is the Roman Catholic Cathedral,
erected in 1808, and on the left Calvert Hall College. Note

Rochambeau tablet on College wall. It was here that Count
Rochambeau camped with his army on the return from York-
town.

North on Cathedral to Monument, thence east to Charles—In
the center of the square is the first monument erected to
General Washington by any commonwealth. The corner-
stone was laid on July 4, 1815, with Masonic ceremony. The
land was given by Col. John Eager Howard, Revolutionary
War hero and friend of Washington, whose statue is in the
square. The stone was given by the owner of a Maryland
quarry and the funds for construction were raised by lottery.
The massive figure of Washington was placed atop the shaft
in 1824. The total height is 210 feet. A few yards south of
the monument stands an equestrian statue of Lafayette,
erected by the city of Baltimore and dedicated by President
Coolidge. On the northeast corer is Mount Vernon Place
M. E. Church, erected on the site of the home in which
Francis Scott Key, author of ‘“‘The Star Spangled Banner,"
died. Note tablet on wall.

On the southeast corner is the Peabody Conservatory of
Music, of national importance, founded by George Peabody
whose statue is in the square. Looking south from this point,
a distance of one block, is the Walters Art Gallery (Centre
and Charles) which was bequeathed to the city of Baltimore
by Henry Walters. It contains one of the finest private col-
lections in the world.

Circle Washington Monument and go west on Monument
Street to Cathedral, thence to Mt. Royal Avenue, passing the
handsome Maryland Institute of Art and Design on the left,
thence around south side of reservoir to the Mansion House
in Druid Hill Park. This is Baltimore's oldest public park. It is
replete with natural scenery and contains nearly 700 acres. In
the park are to be seen deer and sheep and the city zoo is also
located here.

Municipal Tour Two

One-hour Motor Trip from the Mansion
House in Druid Hill Park to
Fort McHenry

Leaving the Mansion House, proceed to the north side of
reservoir, cross Cedar Avenue Bridge to the U. S. Marine
Hospital, thence north in W yman Park to University Parkway
at Stony Run Bridge, thence circling in front of the Maryland
Casualty Company group of buildings at 40th Street and
Keswick Road, coming out at 40th to University Parkway,
thence to 39th Street, thence ¢ast to Charles, thence north on
Charles to Greenway, then making sharp right turn coming
south on Greenway to Charles and University Parkway. In
this section, which includes a part of Guilford, may be seen
some of Baltimore's fine residences and modern apartment
houses.

At Charles Street enter Homewood, the group of buildings of

the Johns Hopkins University. The Colonial mansion opposite

Greenway was the home of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, one

of the Maryland signers of the Declaration of Independence,

and is one of the finest examples of Colonial architecture yet

sstanding. Circle the Hopkins grounds, coming out at 33rd
treet.

South on Charles Street to 29th passing on the right the new
Municipal Art Museum.

East on 29th Street to Greenmount Avenue, thence north to
33rd Street, thence east to the Hillen Road. On the right, a
short distance east of Greenmount Avenue, on an eminence
stands the new City College, which is declared to be the finest
building of its kind from an architectural standpoint in the
United States. A little nearer on the left side is seen the
Baltimore Stadium, the scene of many big contests. The seat-
ing capacity of the Stadium is 78,000.

At Hillen Road circle the city's big water filtration plant, the
capacity of which now is being doubled.

Enter Clifton Park at 33rd Street and pass around or near the
mansion of the late Johns Hopkins, who made possible the
University, Medical School and Hospital bearing his name. At
the time of Hopkins' endowment it was the largest single be-
quest made to any educational institution in the country.
Leave Clifton Park by way of the Washington Street entrance
to North Avenue and thence west to Broadway.

South on Broadway to Monument Street. On the left is the
group of buildings of the world-renowned Johns Hopkins
Hospital and Medical School, the buildings extending
several blocks to the south and east. Ccntinue south on
Broadway to Fayette Street, near the corner being seen a
monument to Thomas Wildey, founder of Odd Fellowship
in the United States more than 100 years ago. Continue south
on Broadway to its foot, which is Fell's Point, the third oldest
section of Baltimore, several houses over a century old still
standing there. It was here that the famous clipper ships were
built several generations ago. Go around the market house,
which also is very old, and proceed north to Fayette Street.

West on Fayette Street to Aisquith. On the Northwest
corner, in the rear, is an old Quaker Meeting House and
graveyard dating back nearly 200 years. Continue west on
Fayette Street to the Civic Center, which begins at the Falls-
way. In a straight line running westward are to be seen the old
Shot Tower, erected in 1828, Police Building, War Memorial,
City Hall, Postoffice and Courthouse. At Gay Street, looking
north across the plaza, are to be seen the Fire Department and

Municipal Office Buildings.

South on Gay Street to Pratt, thence east to Albermarle. On
the northwest corner is the ''Flag House," where Mrs. Mary
Pickersgill made the flag which floated triumphantly over
Fort McHenry throughout its bombardment in 1814, This
flag is preserved in the Smithsonian Institute at Washington.

North on Albemarle Street to Lombard, thence to Front
Street to the house where Charles Carroll of Carrollton died.
The city has been using the building as a vocational school.
This section today is not very inviting, but it is a part of old
Baltimore Town and once contained the residences of its best
citizens.

Here's hoping your stay in Baltimore will be a happy one.
home about some of your pleasant experiences in our city.

it, Baltimore cuisine is outstanding .

West on Lombard Street to Light, thence south to Key High-
way, thence to Fort Avenue and Fort McHenry. The old fort

. dates from 1777, but was not used in the Revolutionary War.

It was constructed originally by the citizens of Baltimore at
their own expense. Later it was presented to the Federal
Government and the Star Fort built in its center. The Govern-
ment appropriated only $20,000 for this, the people of
Baltimore paying the balance. The fort defeated the British
fleet on September 13-14, 1814, said defeat causing the
British Government to make peace soon afterward. The fort,
which contains statues of Col. George Armistead, its defender;
Francis Scott Key, who wrote the National Anthem while
detained on a British ship during the bombardment, and a
shaft to the privateersmen, was dedicated on Septem‘)er 12,
1928, as a National Shrine. The old fort has been restored to
its appearance in 1814, The Star Fort, magazine, dungeons,
cannon ball storage mounds, batteries, officers’ quarters and
other buildings are of exceptional interest.

Municipal Tour Three

Tour of Baltimore's Public Park System

Starting from Memorial Plaza east of the City Hall. East on
Fayette Street to Fallsway, south to Baltimore, east to Eden
Street. South on Eden gtreet to Gough the course will pass
City Springs Square in the most thickly populated section of
the city. East on Gough to Patterson Park, the city's first
Public Park of consequence with its many historical associa-
tions.

Westerly on Baltimore Street from Patterson Park to Broad-
way and thence north apast the Johns Hopkins Hospital to
North Avenue and eastwardly to Washington Street and into
Clifton Park, one time the home of the celebrated Johns
Hopkins.

Leaving Clifton Park by way of the Alameda to 33rd Street
and westerly to Venable Park and the Baltimore Stadium.
Continuing westerly to University Parkway and thence north-
west to the entrance into W yman Park in the vicinity of 39th
Street and south through W yman Park to the Marine Hospital
and westerly into Druid Hill Park, world famous for its natural
beauties.

Leaving Druid Hill Park by way of Mondawmin Avenue out
the Gwynn's Falls Parkway to the Windsor Mill Road to the
Franklintown Road and thence south through Gwynn's Falls
Park to the Ellicott Driveway and thence continuing by way
of Brunswick Street, Wilkens Avenue and Monroe Street into
Carnroll Park to the historical museum maintained by the
Daughters of the American Revolution and where the most
modern playground facilities may be seen.

Leaving Carroll Park by way of Bayard Street to Hamburg
and following easterly on Hamburg to Battery Avenue will
bring the party to the celebrated Federal Hill Park overlook-
ing the Baltimore Harbor.

South from Federal Hill Park on Battery Avenue to Riverside
Park with its modern swimming pool facilities and thence

This folder is a miniature “guide book.” It will tell you where to go and how to go. See Baltimore and
you will see portrayed the history of our country, through important shrines and beautiful memorials.
You will see, too, a city where people enjoy 312 days of sunshine a year. Not a land of enchantment
with make-believe joys and bizarre thrills. Baltimore is real . . . it's human . . . it's genuine. It has
character, friendliness and an appreciation of living.



west on Randall Street to Hanover and south on Hanover
across the bridge to Broening Park where refreshments may

be had at the Maryland Yacht Club.
Municipal Tour Four

Green Spring Valley--Loch Raven Tour

See the picturesque country-side surrounding Baltimore.
Enjoy the scenic beauties of this charming rolling country in
a memorable two-hour tour.

Start at Belvedere Avenue and Park Heights Avenue. Con-
tinue along Park Heights Avenue past the Maryland Country
Club. Turn left on Slade Avenue past Suburban Club. Turn
right on Reisterstown Road, past Woodholme Country Club.
Turn right at Tobin Station on Valley Road, past Green Spring
Valley Hunt Club. Turn left at Stevenson. Continue on Valley
Road past Maryland Polo Club and Brooklandwood Farm,
scene of the nationally famous point-to-point race. Turn left
on Falls Road. Turn right on Seminary Avenue, through
Lutherville past Maryland College for Women. Turn left at
York Road past Timonium, scene of Maryland State tair. Turn
right at Warren Road. Tu-n right at Sunnybrook on Jarrets-
ville Road. Sharp left U turn to Dulaney Valley to Loch
Raven Road, to Loch Raven Bridge past impressive Loch
Raven Dam. Continue to Cromwell Bridge to Joppa Road.
Turn left at Charles Street Avenue, past Elkridge Kennels. On
the left, see Homeland, impressive residential section of
Baltimore. Continue on Charles Street to Mt. Vernon Place,
one of the most beautiful public squares in the country.

PORT OF BALTIMORE
As viewed from historic Federal Hill Park

From this picturesque hilltop can be seen the city’s growing
skyline, while spread out below is Baltimore's international
port, which handles shipping from the Seven Seas and con-
ducts business with all important harbors of the United States
and foreign countries. This port handles a yearly business
of 15,000,000 tons of cargo, valued at $750,000,000.

Fifty-four steamship services operate direct from Baltimore.

Southeast across the harbor is Fort McHenry, birthplace of
the “‘Star-Spangled Banner'. In the distance is historic Fort
Carroll.

The harbor view includes the four great marine terminals of
the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the Pennsylvania Railroad,
the Western Maryland Railway and the Canton Company,
with 38 deepwater ocean piers. In the Middle Branch section
is the new $8,500,000 marine terminal constructed by the
city of Baltimore and operated by the Western Maryland
Railway. Modern shipbuilding and repair yards are scattered
along the shore line. Great waterfront industrial plants in the
business of steel, sugar, petroleum, copper, tin, spices, chemi-
cals, fertilizers, canning, airplane manufacturing, and many
other lines give testimony to the importance of Baltimore as a

seaboard manufacturing center, and the seventh industrial city

of the United States.

Jacksz;

Main ship channels and all channels leading to the ocean

_ piers of the marine terminals have a controlling depth of 35

feet at mean low water.

The Baltimore Association of Commerce will supply the visi-
tor with complete data on the Port of Baltimore, the second
foreign trade tonnage port on the Atlantic Coast.

Make Baltimore

Your Tour-quarters

The territory surrounding Baltimore is rich in historic interest
and nature's beauties. Make Baltimore your headquarters and
arrange daily trips that will live in your memory through the
years.

See quaint Annapolis, one of the most charming Colonial
towns in the United States.

See Gettysburg Battlefield, one of the world's most important
battlefields.

See Mount Vernon, home and burial place of George Wash-
ington and his wife.

See Washington, the nation's capital.
See Frederick, the home of Barbara Fritchie.

See Southern Maryland where the first Maryland Colonists

settled.

See the Eastern Shore of Maryland, a beautiful territory with

large estates and stately Colonial mansions.

See Ocean City, Maryland's famous seashore. And bathe in

the Atlantic Ocean.



And see, too, many other places you have read about on the

pages of history.

And Lexington Street in our shopping district may bring up visions of Piccadilly Circus in London.

impressive suburban section, will show you that Baltimoreans appreciate the finer things . . . and know

how to live.

to see lovely Druid Lake. If you have any children, take them to the zoo, by all means. Queen Rambai-

Barni of Siam described Druid Hill Park as one of the most beautiful she ever visited.

Now when it comes to the historic, Baltimore is rich in landmarks and in shrines of history. Baltimore
opens many breathtaking pages of past glories. Of course, you're planning to see Fort McHenry. This
famous fort was the scene of the memorable repulse of the British fleet in 1814.

stirring battle that Francis Scott Key wrote the “Star Spangled Banner.”

The Shot Tower is another well-known landmark. It was erected in 1828 and is the only one of its kind

in America.

Then, we have superbly sculptured monuments by the score. Baltimore is known as the ““Monumental
City” and has certainly earned the honor. First,” among our important monuments is the impressive

It was during this’

You'll find that our hotels enjoy offering superb service to the visitor within our midst.

The delicacies in sea food and Southern food are to be had in Baltimore at their best.- Modestly, | say

W ashington Monument in quaint Mt. Vernon Place. It was the first public monument erected by any
city or state in memory of George Woashington. A tour of the monuments, shrines, tablets and other
historical places should give you several pleasant afternoons.

Municipa| Tour One

One-hour Motor Trip from the City Hall
to the Mansion House in Druid Hill Park

Start at the City Hall Plaza, corner of Holliday and Lexington
Streets. Facing the City Hall on the east is the imposing War
Memorial Building. In the block next to the City Hall is the
new Municipal Office Building. On the opposite side of
Holliday Street is the Municipal Museum.



South on Holliday Street to Fayette. West on Fayette to
Calvert. In the plaza is the Battle Monument, erected more
than 100 years ago in commemoration of the victories at the
Battle of Baltimore (North Point) and in the attack on Fort
McHenry in 1814. On the right is the new Postoffice. On
the left is the city's $3,000,000 Courthouse, containing
picturesque mural paintings depicting the early history of the
city and state.

South on Calvert to Redwood. West on Redwood to Light.
On the northeast corner there is a tablet on the site of the
Fountain Inn, where George Washington was entertained on
many occasions in Colonial days. .

North on Light Street to Baltimore—On the southwest corner
is the Baltimore Trust Building, 34 stories, total height 500
feet, the city's tallest structure. On the northeast corner is the
city's oldest bank, its charter dating from 1795.

North on Light Street (St. Paul St.) to Fayette. West on
Fayette Street to Green—On the southeast corner stands old
W estminster Presbyterian Church and graveyard, which con-
tains the remains of Edgar Allan Poe, poet and writer, and

author of “'The Raven''.

South on Green Street to Baltimore, thence east to Howard
Street, thence north to Saratoga. This section just passed through
is the heart of Baltimore's retail shopping district, containing
nearly all of the large department stores and specialty shops.
The district extends a short distance westward.

East on Saratoga Street to Charles—On the southeast corner
is St. Paul’s P. E. Church, the oldest congregation in Baltimore.
The present edifice stands on the site of the original lot bought
in 1830 for $10.

North on Charles Street to Mulberry—On the northeast
corner is the Roman Catholic Archepiscopal residence, for
many years the home of James Cardinal Gibbons, the first
American to be given the Red Hat by the Vatican.

West on Mulberry Street to Cathedral, thence north on
Cathedral—On the right is the Roman Catholic Cathedral,
erected in 1808, and on the left Calvert Hall College. Note

Rochambeau tablet on College wall. It was here that Count
Rochambeau camped with his army on the return from York-
town.

North on Cathedral to Monument, thence east to Charles—In
the center of the square is the first monument erected to
General Washington by any commonwealth. The corner-
stone was laid on July 4, 1815, with Masonic ceremony. The
land was given by Col. John Eager Howard, Revolutionary
War hero and friend of Washington, whose statue is in the
square. The stone was given by the owner of a Maryland
quarry and the funds for construction were raised by lottery.
The massive figure of Washington was placed atop the shaft
in 1824. The total height is 210 feet. A few yards south of
the monument stands an equestrian statue of Lafayette,
erected by the city of Baltimore and dedicated by President
Coolidge. On the northeast corer is Mount Vernon Place
M. E. Church, erected on the site of the home in which
Francis Scott Key, author of ‘“‘The Star Spangled Banner,"
died. Note tablet on wall.

On the southeast corner is the Peabody Conservatory of
Music, of national importance, founded by George Peabody
whose statue is in the square. Looking south from this point,
a distance of one block, is the Walters Art Gallery (Centre
and Charles) which was bequeathed to the city of Baltimore
by Henry Walters. It contains one of the finest private col-
lections in the world.

Circle Washington Monument and go west on Monument
Street to Cathedral, thence to Mt. Royal Avenue, passing the
handsome Maryland Institute of Art and Design on the left,
thence around south side of reservoir to the Mansion House
in Druid Hill Park. This is Baltimore's oldest public park. It is
replete with natural scenery and contains nearly 700 acres. In
the park are to be seen deer and sheep and the city zoo is also
located here.

Municipal Tour Two

One-hour Motor Trip from the Mansion
House in Druid Hill Park to
Fort McHenry

Leaving the Mansion House, proceed to the north side of
reservoir, cross Cedar Avenue Bridge to the U. S. Marine
Hospital, thence north in W yman Park to University Parkway
at Stony Run Bridge, thence circling in front of the Maryland
Casualty Company group of buildings at 40th Street and
Keswick Road, coming out at 40th to University Parkway,
thence to 39th Street, thence ¢ast to Charles, thence north on
Charles to Greenway, then making sharp right turn coming
south on Greenway to Charles and University Parkway. In
this section, which includes a part of Guilford, may be seen
some of Baltimore's fine residences and modern apartment
houses.

At Charles Street enter Homewood, the group of buildings of

the Johns Hopkins University. The Colonial mansion opposite

Greenway was the home of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, one

of the Maryland signers of the Declaration of Independence,

and is one of the finest examples of Colonial architecture yet

sstanding. Circle the Hopkins grounds, coming out at 33rd
treet.

South on Charles Street to 29th passing on the right the new
Municipal Art Museum.

East on 29th Street to Greenmount Avenue, thence north to
33rd Street, thence east to the Hillen Road. On the right, a
short distance east of Greenmount Avenue, on an eminence
stands the new City College, which is declared to be the finest
building of its kind from an architectural standpoint in the
United States. A little nearer on the left side is seen the
Baltimore Stadium, the scene of many big contests. The seat-
ing capacity of the Stadium is 78,000.

At Hillen Road circle the city's big water filtration plant, the
capacity of which now is being doubled.

Enter Clifton Park at 33rd Street and pass around or near the
mansion of the late Johns Hopkins, who made possible the
University, Medical School and Hospital bearing his name. At
the time of Hopkins' endowment it was the largest single be-
quest made to any educational institution in the country.
Leave Clifton Park by way of the Washington Street entrance
to North Avenue and thence west to Broadway.

South on Broadway to Monument Street. On the left is the
group of buildings of the world-renowned Johns Hopkins
Hospital and Medical School, the buildings extending
several blocks to the south and east. Ccntinue south on
Broadway to Fayette Street, near the corner being seen a
monument to Thomas Wildey, founder of Odd Fellowship
in the United States more than 100 years ago. Continue south
on Broadway to its foot, which is Fell's Point, the third oldest
section of Baltimore, several houses over a century old still
standing there. It was here that the famous clipper ships were
built several generations ago. Go around the market house,
which also is very old, and proceed north to Fayette Street.

West on Fayette Street to Aisquith. On the Northwest
corner, in the rear, is an old Quaker Meeting House and
graveyard dating back nearly 200 years. Continue west on
Fayette Street to the Civic Center, which begins at the Falls-
way. In a straight line running westward are to be seen the old
Shot Tower, erected in 1828, Police Building, War Memorial,
City Hall, Postoffice and Courthouse. At Gay Street, looking
north across the plaza, are to be seen the Fire Department and

Municipal Office Buildings.

South on Gay Street to Pratt, thence east to Albermarle. On
the northwest corner is the ''Flag House," where Mrs. Mary
Pickersgill made the flag which floated triumphantly over
Fort McHenry throughout its bombardment in 1814, This
flag is preserved in the Smithsonian Institute at Washington.

North on Albemarle Street to Lombard, thence to Front
Street to the house where Charles Carroll of Carrollton died.
The city has been using the building as a vocational school.
This section today is not very inviting, but it is a part of old
Baltimore Town and once contained the residences of its best
citizens.

Here's hoping your stay in Baltimore will be a happy one.
home about some of your pleasant experiences in our city.

it, Baltimore cuisine is outstanding .

West on Lombard Street to Light, thence south to Key High-
way, thence to Fort Avenue and Fort McHenry. The old fort

. dates from 1777, but was not used in the Revolutionary War.

It was constructed originally by the citizens of Baltimore at
their own expense. Later it was presented to the Federal
Government and the Star Fort built in its center. The Govern-
ment appropriated only $20,000 for this, the people of
Baltimore paying the balance. The fort defeated the British
fleet on September 13-14, 1814, said defeat causing the
British Government to make peace soon afterward. The fort,
which contains statues of Col. George Armistead, its defender;
Francis Scott Key, who wrote the National Anthem while
detained on a British ship during the bombardment, and a
shaft to the privateersmen, was dedicated on Septem‘)er 12,
1928, as a National Shrine. The old fort has been restored to
its appearance in 1814, The Star Fort, magazine, dungeons,
cannon ball storage mounds, batteries, officers’ quarters and
other buildings are of exceptional interest.

Municipal Tour Three

Tour of Baltimore's Public Park System

Starting from Memorial Plaza east of the City Hall. East on
Fayette Street to Fallsway, south to Baltimore, east to Eden
Street. South on Eden gtreet to Gough the course will pass
City Springs Square in the most thickly populated section of
the city. East on Gough to Patterson Park, the city's first
Public Park of consequence with its many historical associa-
tions.

Westerly on Baltimore Street from Patterson Park to Broad-
way and thence north apast the Johns Hopkins Hospital to
North Avenue and eastwardly to Washington Street and into
Clifton Park, one time the home of the celebrated Johns
Hopkins.

Leaving Clifton Park by way of the Alameda to 33rd Street
and westerly to Venable Park and the Baltimore Stadium.
Continuing westerly to University Parkway and thence north-
west to the entrance into W yman Park in the vicinity of 39th
Street and south through W yman Park to the Marine Hospital
and westerly into Druid Hill Park, world famous for its natural
beauties.

Leaving Druid Hill Park by way of Mondawmin Avenue out
the Gwynn's Falls Parkway to the Windsor Mill Road to the
Franklintown Road and thence south through Gwynn's Falls
Park to the Ellicott Driveway and thence continuing by way
of Brunswick Street, Wilkens Avenue and Monroe Street into
Carnroll Park to the historical museum maintained by the
Daughters of the American Revolution and where the most
modern playground facilities may be seen.

Leaving Carroll Park by way of Bayard Street to Hamburg
and following easterly on Hamburg to Battery Avenue will
bring the party to the celebrated Federal Hill Park overlook-
ing the Baltimore Harbor.

South from Federal Hill Park on Battery Avenue to Riverside
Park with its modern swimming pool facilities and thence

This folder is a miniature “guide book.” It will tell you where to go and how to go. See Baltimore and
you will see portrayed the history of our country, through important shrines and beautiful memorials.
You will see, too, a city where people enjoy 312 days of sunshine a year. Not a land of enchantment
with make-believe joys and bizarre thrills. Baltimore is real . . . it's human . . . it's genuine. It has
character, friendliness and an appreciation of living.



west on Randall Street to Hanover and south on Hanover
across the bridge to Broening Park where refreshments may

be had at the Maryland Yacht Club.
Municipal Tour Four

Green Spring Valley--Loch Raven Tour

See the picturesque country-side surrounding Baltimore.
Enjoy the scenic beauties of this charming rolling country in
a memorable two-hour tour.

Start at Belvedere Avenue and Park Heights Avenue. Con-
tinue along Park Heights Avenue past the Maryland Country
Club. Turn left on Slade Avenue past Suburban Club. Turn
right on Reisterstown Road, past Woodholme Country Club.
Turn right at Tobin Station on Valley Road, past Green Spring
Valley Hunt Club. Turn left at Stevenson. Continue on Valley
Road past Maryland Polo Club and Brooklandwood Farm,
scene of the nationally famous point-to-point race. Turn left
on Falls Road. Turn right on Seminary Avenue, through
Lutherville past Maryland College for Women. Turn left at
York Road past Timonium, scene of Maryland State tair. Turn
right at Warren Road. Tu-n right at Sunnybrook on Jarrets-
ville Road. Sharp left U turn to Dulaney Valley to Loch
Raven Road, to Loch Raven Bridge past impressive Loch
Raven Dam. Continue to Cromwell Bridge to Joppa Road.
Turn left at Charles Street Avenue, past Elkridge Kennels. On
the left, see Homeland, impressive residential section of
Baltimore. Continue on Charles Street to Mt. Vernon Place,
one of the most beautiful public squares in the country.

PORT OF BALTIMORE
As viewed from historic Federal Hill Park

From this picturesque hilltop can be seen the city’s growing
skyline, while spread out below is Baltimore's international
port, which handles shipping from the Seven Seas and con-
ducts business with all important harbors of the United States
and foreign countries. This port handles a yearly business
of 15,000,000 tons of cargo, valued at $750,000,000.

Fifty-four steamship services operate direct from Baltimore.

Southeast across the harbor is Fort McHenry, birthplace of
the “‘Star-Spangled Banner'. In the distance is historic Fort
Carroll.

The harbor view includes the four great marine terminals of
the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the Pennsylvania Railroad,
the Western Maryland Railway and the Canton Company,
with 38 deepwater ocean piers. In the Middle Branch section
is the new $8,500,000 marine terminal constructed by the
city of Baltimore and operated by the Western Maryland
Railway. Modern shipbuilding and repair yards are scattered
along the shore line. Great waterfront industrial plants in the
business of steel, sugar, petroleum, copper, tin, spices, chemi-
cals, fertilizers, canning, airplane manufacturing, and many
other lines give testimony to the importance of Baltimore as a

seaboard manufacturing center, and the seventh industrial city

of the United States.

The Baltimore Association of Commerce will supply the visi-
tor with complete data on the Port of Baltimore, the second
foreign trade tonnage port on the Atlantic Coast.

Make Baltimore

Your Tour-quarters

The territory surrounding Baltimore is rich in historic interest
and nature's beauties. Make Baltimore your headquarters and
arrange daily trips that will live in your memory through the
years.

See quaint Annapolis, one of the most charming Colonial
towns in the United States.

See Gettysburg Battlefield, one of the world's most important
battlefields.

See Mount Vernon, home and burial place of George Wash-
ington and his wife.

See Washington, the nation's capital.
See Frederick, the home of Barbara Fritchie.

See Southern Maryland where the first Maryland Colonists

settled.

See the Eastern Shore of Maryland, a beautiful territory with

large estates and stately Colonial mansions.

See Ocean City, Maryland's famous seashore. And bathe in

the Atlantic Ocean.



And see, too, many other places you have read about on the

pages of history.

Baltimore street is the dividing line for numbers on Streets and
Avenues running North and South and Charles street for those run-

    BUS

    WHEN YOU ARE PLANNING A BUS T &
    OR AN "OUTING," PHONE PLAZA 5000,
    OR VISIT THE BALTIMORE TRANSIT COM-
    PANY'S CHARTERED BUS DEPARTMENT,
    441 EQUITABLE BUILDING. This office will
    be glad to estimate the cost of your trip, and
    help with arrangements to make it enjoyable.



    o

    NFORMATION

    The Baltimore Transit Company's Information
    Service was inaugurated to help the public
    use the street car, bus and trackless trolley
    facilities of Baltimore more easily and con-
    veniently. Questions about how to get from
    one point to another in the city by the quick-
    est route, with transfer points, street locations,
    most convenient transit lines, etc., will all be
    promptly answered if you will call "Informa-
    tion," Plaza 5000, or stop in at the convenient
    Information Desk, Lobby, Equitable Building,
    or the Information and Service Department,
    515 Equitable Building, S. W. Cor, Calvert &
    Fayette Sts.







    JAN 24 2011

    WHEN YOU ARE PLANNING A BUS T &
    OR AN "OUTING," PHONE PLAZA 5000,
    OR VISIT THE BALTIMORE TRANSIT COM-
    PANY'S CHARTERED BUS DEPARTMENT,
    441 EQUITABLE BUILDING. This office will
    be glad to estimate the cost of your trip, and
    help with arrangements to make it enjoyable.

    NFORMATION

    The Baltimore Transit Company's Information
    Service was inaugurated to help the public
    use the street car, bus and trackless trolley
    facilities of Baltimore more easily and con-
    veniently. Questions about how to get from
    one point to another in the city by the quick-
    est route, with transfer points, street locations,
    most convenient transit lines, etc., will all be
    promptly answered if you will call "Informa-
    tion," Plaza 5000, or stop in at the convenient
    Information Desk, Lobby, Equitable Building,
    or the Information and Service Department,
    515 Equitable Building, S. W. Cor, Calvert &
    Fayette Sts.

1. FEDERAL HILL—Hughes St., Battery and Warren Aves.
Commanding an excellent view of Baltimore’s upper harbor
and skyline, this site was fortified by Union forces during the
Civil War.

2. FORT McHENRY—This National Park is a vivid reminder
of our defense against the British fleet in September, 1814,
which inspired Francis Scott Key to compose our national
anthem.

3. UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND & UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL—
Greene and Lombard Sts. Founded in 1807, the University
includes the oldest dental college in the world.

4. POE’S GRAVE & WESTMINISTER CHURCH—Fayette &
Greene Sts. The grave of Edgar Allan Poe, who died in
Baltimore in 1849, is in the northwest corner of this old

Mary Pickersgill made the American Flag that waved over
Fort McHenry during the bombardment by the British in 1814.

Mt. Vernon Place, with
its Old World charm, is
one of the beauty spots
of Baltimore. It provides
an Eden-like setting for
many of the city’s best-
loved monuments. Here,
towering to a height of
approximately 200 feet,
is the first monument
erected to the memory of George Washington.
It was begun in 1815 and completed in 1829

with money raised by lottery.

The equestrian statue of Lafayette stands gal-
lantly in a natural setting among the trees and

shrubs of the Square.

Other personages whose statues may be seen at
vantage points around the Place are Roger
Brooks Taney, a Chief Justice of the United
States; George Peabody, whose gifts founded
the Peabody Institute, and John Eager Howard,

one of early Baltimore’s foremost citizens.



1y {0 wmasnp aL0wnng

altimore- the onumental City

In recognition of Baltimore’s participation in
the Civil War—her geographical location drew
recruits for the armies of both the North and
the South — several beautiful monuments have
been erected. Among these are the Confederate
Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Mt. Royal
Avenue near Mosher Street, the Confederate
Women’s Monument on University Parkway,
the Union Soldiers and Sailors Monument in
Druid Hill Park, and the double equestrian
statue of Generals “Stonewall” Jackson and
Robert E. Lee in Wyman Park mnear Charles
Street. In addition, there is the Armistead Monu-
ment in Federal Hill Park—a memorial to Col.
George Armistead who directed the successful
defense of Fort McHenry against the British
Fleet in 1814.

A monument of Cecilius Calvert, second Lord
Baltimore, stands on the steps of the Court
House, on St. Paul Street. Lord Proprietary of
Maryland from 1632 to 1675, Calvert was one
of the first champions of freedom of religious
worship, separation of Church and State, and

the participation of every freeman in the mak-









PrIOWD Y] 4D H

Dicturesque “Tours

of Three Valleys

The countryside to the north of Baltimore pre-
sents scenes of year-round beauty, amid rolling
hills and three fertile valleys. Two tours are
suggested — or if desired, they could be com-
bined in one trip of approximately four hours.
It’s a restful drive, free from traffic congestion,
with pastoral estates in striking contrast to the
skyscrapers and busy tempo of a large city.

Tour A—(See map, reverse side) Proceed
north on North Charles Street to Joppa Road,
turn right to Towson, then turn left on Dulaney
Valley Road, to Loch Raven Road to Valley
Road, making almost a complete circuit of Loch
Raven, the city’s huge water reservoir. Return
to Towson by way of Valley Road, Providence
Road and the Joppa Road.

Tour B—(See map, reverse side) Starting at
Towson, proceed north on York Road (U. S.
111) approximately 1145 miles to Seminary
Avenue and turn left to Falls Road. Turn right
on Falls Road approximately 514 miles to

eautiful Homes,
esidential Charm

To the visitor who is interested in the home

beautiful, in residential charm whether it be
in modest surroundings or vast estates, a tour
through the attractive suburbs of Baltimore is
most delightful.

Rather than specify a particular route, it is sug-
gested that visitors spend a few hours in the
northern section of the city, driving along the
winding tree-lined roads of Roland Park, Guil-
ford, Homeland and smaller developments
just north of University Parkway, both east and
west of North Charles Street.

Here you will find homes of distinction, and gar-
dens of outstanding beauty. From the wooded
section of Roland Park to the little lakes of
Homeland, you will be impressed by the sim-
plicity and charm of Baltimore’s residential
areas.

Point, in September 1814, in which the British

and Lanvale Street, represents the poet return-

Street, was erected in 1792, and was the first

NUMBER 22
Crosstown Bus Line

ROUTE: Bank and Grundy Sts.: Grundy, Eastern
Ave., Conkling, Bank, Highland Ave., Madison, Edi-
son Highway, Erdman Ave., Harford Ave., 32nd,
33rd, University Pkwy., 40th, 41st, Hooper Ave.,
Druid Park Drive, to Liberty Heights Ave. Return-
ing over same route to Bank and Grundy Sts.

NUMBER 23
Middle River - Essex - Fayette Street Bus Line

ROUTE: New Eastern Blvd. via Wilbur Rd. to
Eastern Ave., Haven St., Lombard St., Conkling St.,
Baltimore St., Ellwood Ave., Fayette St., Linwood
Ave., Pulaski Hwy., Fayette St., Holliday St., Lex-
ington St., Howard St. to Centre St. Returning east-
bound via Centre St., Calvert St., Saratoga St., Hol-
liday St., Fayette St., Ellwood Ave., Baltimore St.,
Conkling St., Lombard St., Grundy St., Eastern Ave.
to Middle River terminus.

NUMBER 25

ROUTE: Belvedere Ave. Loop via Belvedere Ave.,

Ave., Falls Rd., 36th St., Chestnut Ave., 33rd St.,

Howard St., Madison St., Cathedral St., Maryland
Ave., 25th St., then over same route to Belvedere
Loop.

NUMBER 26

rows Point. Returning over same route to Eastern
Ave., Haven to Pratt and Grundy Streets.

Population, city and suburbs, 949,247 . . . 8th in the Nation in size . . . 7th in in-
dustry . . . 3rd in foreign trade tonnage . . . has more than 2,100 manufacturing plants
making 2,000 commodities . . . 62% of Baltunore s homes are owned by their occupants

. one of the world's great medical centers.

A city of narrow, crowded downtown streets . . . red brick buildings . . .
white steps . . . unexpected squares . . . green with grass and trees . . .
flowers . . . stores and shops Fifth Ave. would boast of . . . lofty skyscrapers, just
around the corner from century-old buildings . . . here a monument . . . there a beautiful
old church . . . white-coiffed Sisters of Charity . . . brisk, modern manners with a touch
of the courtesy of the Old South . . . a city that buys as cheerfully as it sells . . . if you
have something of merit it needs . . . a kindly city of beautiful, wide avenues . . . parks

. homes . . . places of historic interest . . . if you can find them . . . and so few
visitorsdo . . . the Gateway tothe wonderful Chesapeake Bay Country . developms
into a glorious summer play-ground . . . a city with 127 miles of deep harbor . . .
nearer the South and the vast Missiscippi region . . . nearer the center of population
and center of wheat and corn production . . . with nearly half the Nation’s manufactured
products made in states directly connected by shorter rail routes and lower freight rates

. greatest manufacturing city nearest Central America and the west coast of North and
South America . . . Baltimore makes the world’s best of Oyster Cocktails and Aircraft

. is first and best in so many things and so seldom mentions it . . . where other cities
parade their advantages, Baltimore lets you “discover’” hers and perhaps this absence of
“selling” effort is part of Baltimore's charm.

immaculate

Baltimore was founded in 1729 after a century of colonizing venturers inaugurated by the
Lords Baltimore . . . the original settlers were earnest, practical and intensely liberty-
loving folks . . . their plantations of tobacco spread along the waterside and up the tidal
streams . . . each sufficient to itself with its own handicrafts . . . each with its own
schooner waiting at its wharf to bear its cured tobacco to the King's ships at anchor in
the bay . . . the scattered settlzrs found they needed cities . . . so in a single law they
decreed that 31 cities shouid arise . . . and they arose . . . farms by the waterside
appeared laid out with streets . . . each “City” as cocky as a western “‘Metropolis” of
later days . . . each confident It would become the great seaport . . . some did grow
into important shipping points . . . with merchants living in such princely style as to
amaze European visitors. In the coves of the Patapsco estuary which opens towards the
mountains on the west shores of the Chesapeake, colonists took up grants m the neaghbor-
hood of what is now Baltimore . . . here, too, arose a demand for a “‘town” . . . so
“Baltimore Town"" was laid out in the swampy ground between the “‘Basin,” the ° Falls
and the Great Eastern Stage Road . . . the thoroughfare from New England, New York
and the Delaware Settlements to Virginia and the Carolinas . . . over this road traveled
the culture, wealth and commerce of north and south . . . Baltimore, located mid-course
of the road, was deeply effected in its culture, patnotlsm, energy and cosmopolitan spirit
. the courage and enterprise shown in filling up its marshes and developing its harbor
won for “‘Baitimore Town'” a reputation that brought settlers and new business enterprises
: soon it outran Boston and raced neck and neck with New York, both older by more
than a hundred years . . . records of this period read like later-day descriptions of the
growth of Chicago or Miami.
Early Baltimore needed ships—she built them . . . they were beauties and they got there
first . . . she needed roads and soon from her business center there radiated “‘turn pikes™™
thronged with great wagons and droves of cattle . . . she saw the possibilities of the
R. R. and she built the first in America.

In the Revolutionary War it was a Baltimore regiment of business men, meeting with the

bayonet in their first battle the veterans of Europe . . . hopelessly outnumbered, but
forcing the enemy back three times . . . that gave the Colonies hope of final victory . . .
in the War of 1812 with Washington captured . . . Baltimoreans fresh from store and
desk . . . went out to meet the veterans of Napoleonic wars . . . they saved Baltimore
from capture and again inspired the Nation with new hope . . . on the seas the Baltimore
Clipper ships won world renown . . . The Chasser, a Baltimore-built privateer, com-
manded by a Batlimore citizen, Capt. Boyle . .

and made it stick . . . capturing 80 British ships . . . 32 of equal force and 18 of greater.

_old Lexington Market . .

of Scouring’ briskly at work on marble steps and brass knobs . . . the grave of Edgar
Allen Poe . . . first buried as a pauper . . . recognized at last and honored with a ~

Baltimore allows herself to be known but slowly . . . but anyone can feel the spirit of
Baltimore . . . Baltimore being self-respecting compels respect . . . being vital and
peaceful, she inspires peace in those who enjoy her hospitality . . . hers is the quiet of
an old, established order . . . acity able to adjust and accept the good in the new without
losing the good in the old . . . a self-contained city steadily progressing and steadily
refusing to blow trumpets about it . . . You will like Baltimore.

Population, city and suburbs, 949,247 . . . 8th in the Nation in size . . . 7th in in-
dustry . . . 3rd in foreign trade tonnage . . . has more than 2,100 manufacturing plants
making 2,000 commodities . . . 62% of Baltunore s homes are owned by their occupants

. one of the world's great medical centers.

A city of narrow, crowded downtown streets . . . red brick buildings . . .
white steps . . . unexpected squares . . . green with grass and trees . . .
flowers . . . stores and shops Fifth Ave. would boast of . . . lofty skyscrapers, just
around the corner from century-old buildings . . . here a monument . . . there a beautiful
old church . . . white-coiffed Sisters of Charity . . . brisk, modern manners with a touch
of the courtesy of the Old South . . . a city that buys as cheerfully as it sells . . . if you
have something of merit it needs . . . a kindly city of beautiful, wide avenues . . . parks

. homes . . . places of historic interest . . . if you can find them . . . and so few
visitorsdo . . . the Gateway tothe wonderful Chesapeake Bay Country . developms
into a glorious summer play-ground . . . a city with 127 miles of deep harbor . . .
nearer the South and the vast Missiscippi region . . . nearer the center of population
and center of wheat and corn production . . . with nearly half the Nation’s manufactured
products made in states directly connected by shorter rail routes and lower freight rates

. greatest manufacturing city nearest Central America and the west coast of North and
South America . . . Baltimore makes the world’s best of Oyster Cocktails and Aircraft

. is first and best in so many things and so seldom mentions it . . . where other cities
parade their advantages, Baltimore lets you “discover’” hers and perhaps this absence of
“selling” effort is part of Baltimore's charm.

immaculate

Baltimore was founded in 1729 after a century of colonizing venturers inaugurated by the
Lords Baltimore . . . the original settlers were earnest, practical and intensely liberty-
loving folks . . . their plantations of tobacco spread along the waterside and up the tidal
streams . . . each sufficient to itself with its own handicrafts . . . each with its own
schooner waiting at its wharf to bear its cured tobacco to the King's ships at anchor in
the bay . . . the scattered settlzrs found they needed cities . . . so in a single law they
decreed that 31 cities shouid arise . . . and they arose . . . farms by the waterside
appeared laid out with streets . . . each “City” as cocky as a western “‘Metropolis” of
later days . . . each confident It would become the great seaport . . . some did grow
into important shipping points . . . with merchants living in such princely style as to
amaze European visitors. In the coves of the Patapsco estuary which opens towards the
mountains on the west shores of the Chesapeake, colonists took up grants m the neaghbor-
hood of what is now Baltimore . . . here, too, arose a demand for a “‘town” . . . so
“Baltimore Town"" was laid out in the swampy ground between the “‘Basin,” the ° Falls
and the Great Eastern Stage Road . . . the thoroughfare from New England, New York
and the Delaware Settlements to Virginia and the Carolinas . . . over this road traveled
the culture, wealth and commerce of north and south . . . Baltimore, located mid-course
of the road, was deeply effected in its culture, patnotlsm, energy and cosmopolitan spirit
. the courage and enterprise shown in filling up its marshes and developing its harbor
won for “‘Baitimore Town'” a reputation that brought settlers and new business enterprises
: soon it outran Boston and raced neck and neck with New York, both older by more
than a hundred years . . . records of this period read like later-day descriptions of the
growth of Chicago or Miami.
Early Baltimore needed ships—she built them . . . they were beauties and they got there
first . . . she needed roads and soon from her business center there radiated “‘turn pikes™™
thronged with great wagons and droves of cattle . . . she saw the possibilities of the
R. R. and she built the first in America.

In the Revolutionary War it was a Baltimore regiment of business men, meeting with the

bayonet in their first battle the veterans of Europe . . . hopelessly outnumbered, but
forcing the enemy back three times . . . that gave the Colonies hope of final victory . . .
in the War of 1812 with Washington captured . . . Baltimoreans fresh from store and
desk . . . went out to meet the veterans of Napoleonic wars . . . they saved Baltimore
from capture and again inspired the Nation with new hope . . . on the seas the Baltimore
Clipper ships won world renown . . . The Chasser, a Baltimore-built privateer, com-
manded by a Batlimore citizen, Capt. Boyle . .

and made it stick . . . capturing 80 British ships . . . 32 of equal force and 18 of greater.

of Scouring’ briskly at work on marble steps and brass knobs . . . the grave of Edgar

Baltimore allows herself to be known but slowly . . . but anyone can feel the spirit of
Baltimore . . . Baltimore being self-respecting compels respect . . . being vital and
peaceful, she inspires peace in those who enjoy her hospitality . . . hers is the quiet of
an old, established order . . . acity able to adjust and accept the good in the new without
losing the good in the old . . . a self-contained city steadily progressing and steadily
refusing to blow trumpets about it . . . You will like Baltimore.

e STATE ROADS COMMISSION i < DELAWARE 4
. BALTIMORE, MD. : 4
. : 477

BAY

ON THIS MAP OF MARYLAND IS STRIKINGLY DISPLAYED THE SYSTEM OF HIGHWAYS
BUILT BY THE STATE

iy



Every county seat in the 23 counties is connected with the city of
Baltimore, and every section of the State is opened to easy and
convenient access.

Across the central part of the State runs a continuous route from
the eastern border through Elkton in Cecil county, crossing the
beautiful Susquehanna river at Perryville, and through Belair in
Harford county to the city of Baltimore, and then over the Balti-
more-Washington Boulevard to the city of Washington. This route
across Maryland is an important part of a continuous route through
ten States—Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New
York, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire
and Maine—by which an automobile may travel from Augusta, Me.,
to the National Capital over an unbroken succession of State high-
ways, passing through the principal cities of the Eastern Seaboard,
a distance of about 679.5 miles.

The roads of Maryland are naturally divided into four main
arterial systems, with the city of Baltimore as the centre.

With Baltimore as a base, these four unique tours can be made by
automobile with ease and comfort in about a week’s time.

These tours naturally begin with that of the Eastern Shore, the
main artery of which begins at Elkton and passes south through
this fertile and thriving section of the State, where many houses
dating from the Colonial period still remain. The route divides at
Church Hill, and affords the choice of two roads, by one of which,
passing through Centreville and Easton, the beauty of the shores of
the Chesapeake Bay may be enjoyed, and by the other passing inland
through the highly cultivated farming section through Denton and
Federalsburg to Hurlock, where the roads unite and pass to
Salisbury.

From Salisbury a concrete boulevard 35 miles in length runs to
Ocean City. On this boulevard at Berlin a spur will connect with
the Du Pont Boulevard in Delaware, by which travel from the East
may reach the Maryland highways, journeying up over these roads
to Baltimore via Elkton. This system beyond Salisbury terminates
at Crisfield, the southern extremity of this section of the State.

This trip from Baltimore represents a running distance to Salis-
bury of about 176.3 miles, and going and returning requires about
two days, the many large towns affording excellent hotel accommo-
dations for tourists.

The second tour from Baltimore is through Belair in Harford
county, and thence via Aberdeen across the Susquehanna river at
Havre de Grace to Elkton ; returning through the rolling country of
the northern part of Cecil county through Fair Hill and Rising Sun,
crossing the Susquehanna river at Conowingo and reaching Balti-
more via Belair. This route, with its two crossings of the Susque-
hanna river and running through the hilly country of the north-
eastern part of the State, is one of great variety and interest.

From Baltimore a fine boulevard runs to Annapolis, the capital
of the State, with its interesting Colonial houses and the beautiful
Naval Academy. As a continuation of this route, the State highway



passes from Annapolis south through Prince Frederick in Calvert
county to Solomon’s Island, a distance from Baltimore of about
84.4 miles—the round trip easily accomplished in a day.

Washington is reached from Baltimore by the fine Washington
Boulevard, a distance of about 40 miles, and the tour of another
section of the Western Shore of Maryland begins at the District of
Columbia line and runs through Prince George’s county to Waldorf
in Charles county, where the route divides, in one case passing
through La Plata to Rock Point on the Potomac river, the second
route from Waldorf passing through Charlotte Hall and Leonard-
town—both places historically interesting of the Lords of Calvert
and Colonial days—te Point Lookout, the southern extremity of
St. Mary’s county and of this section of the State.

The fourth tour from Baltimore is by the main western artery to
Oakland in Garrett county, at the extreme western part of the State,
through the beautiful rolling country of Howard and Frederick
counties, into the lower ranges of the Blue Ridge Mountains in
Washington county, and beyond in Allegany and Garrett counties
for 83.5 miles into the Allegheny Mountains, through Cumberland
and the rich mineral district of the State to Oakland, a distance of
192.3 miles. From Frederick one spur runs to the Virginia line and

Harpers Ferry, and by another through Thurmont and Emmitsburg

the Pennsylvania line is crossed to reach Gettysburg. The latter
point may also be reached by leaving this main artery at West
Friendship, and going via Westminster and Taneytown, or by the
more direct route through Reisterstown. From a point near Mount
Airy on this main route a State road runs through Montgomery
county to Washington, by which this western tour may be varied,
reaching Baltimore again over the Washington Boulevard.

The scenery of Maryland is very varied and of rare beauty. The
continuous route over the western extremity of the State in the
heart of the Allegheny Mountains over the main western artery to
Baltimore, and from thence crossing the Susquehanna river at
Havre de Grace to Elkton and down over the State roads of the
Eastern Shore to Ocean City, Md., is unsurpassed in the variety
and beauty of the scenery, and is a distance of about 403.4 miles
from the mountains to the sea, all within the State.

In the new State highways of Maryland a greater degree of con-
centrated interest and variety is afforded the tourist by automobile
than in any other State. There is not a mile of monotony; the
beauty, great historic interest and advantages of the State have been
made open and of free access to all, and a week spent on the Mary-
land roads will abundantly repay those who come within our bor-
ders, and it will be found that the State has prepared a warm
welcome in the roads that have been built and which have so fully
opened all for which the State is justly celebrated.

The distance of every town and point of interest from Baltimore
as they lie on the State highways is plainly marked on this map,
and the map should go far to awaken general interest in this new
field that has been opened to tourists by automobile, for the free
distribution among whom it has been prepared.

(D) Grave of Edgar Allan Poe

In the old Westminster Churchyard,



the marble monument marking the
grave of Edgar Allan Poe, that melan-
choly genius whose short life was so
poignant with beauty and tears. Poe
was born on Front Street, Baltimore,
and although much of his life was
spent elsewhere, he lived and died here,

were written in this city ; notably, ‘“The
Raven,” and “The Bells.”

Buffeted in life by trouble and mis-
understandings, Poe finally came to his
end in the charity ward of a public
hospital on October 7, 1849, One car-
riage hauled all the mourners who followed him to a pauper’s
grave in the rear of Westminster churchyard. In this forgotten
spot he lay neglected and alone, his grave decked with weeds,
its only visitors the wind and the rain.

On November 17, 1875, a second funeral was held for Poe
and his body moved to a more suitable spot on the Fayette Street
side of the churchyard. A fine white marble monument, pur-
chased with money contributed by school children, was erected
over the grave. At the unveiling of this monument many not-
ables were present, among them Walt Whitman; and letters
were read from Longfellow, Tennyson, Lowell, Whittier and
Swinburne.

On June 25, 1921, the French Literary Society presented a
bronze wreath in memory of Poe. This wreath was attached to
the right hand side of the shaft. The front of the monument
bears the name, Edgar Allan Poe, and beneath it is a bronze
bust of the poet, taken from an old daguerreotype. On the
bottom of the monument is simply inscribed the words,

Born, January 19, 1809
Died, October 7, 1849

Number 1, 7, 8 and 18 line cars pass Westminster Churchyni'd
where one may visit the grave of Poe. The Baltimore Press
Club looks after this shrine and bestows much care upon it.

(E) The Lexington Market

On Lexington Street, stretching be-
tween Eutaw and Pearl Streets, is the
famous old Lexington Market. The
land on which the market stands was
donated to the City by John Eager
Howard, and in 1803 it was formally
opened. At that time it occupied but
one block, between Eutaw and Paca
Streets, but with the passing of years
its commercial value expanded and new
additions were constantly added wuntil
it reached its present proportions.

There is an appealing ‘old-world”
charm about the market. Here you will
find color and beauty. Little flower
stalls mingle with Italian fruit stands.
The hustle and bustle of shopping
crowds ; the busy hawkers crying their
wares; heaps of produce from the
countryside ; quarters of beef, fat pork-
ers and tender lamb, home-made cookie >
stalls, pickle stands; fish, crabs and oysters in season, fresh
from the Chesapeake. Winter brings an added touch of color
when the mantle of snow descends upon the market. Here and
there, great charcoal braziers throw their red glow about a group
of rosy cheeked marketeers, stamping thickly shod feet and
swinging burly arms against the bite of the frosty air.

The Lexington Market is one of the few remaining, still
thriving, traditions of early life in Baltimore.

Other old markets are Belair, Broadway, Hollins and Cross
Street markets, and the newest is North Avenue Market, a
model of sanitation and cleanliness.

Street cars passing directly through the Lexington market
area are lines Number 5, 16, 18, 31 and 83. It is easily acces-
sible by street car from any part of the City. :

(F) The Battle Monument




At Calvert and Fayette Streets stands
the Battle Monument, erected in honor of -
the defenders of the city at the Battle of
North Point more properly called ‘“The
Battle of Baltimore.”

On September 11, 1814, a fleet of fifty -
British warships anchored off North Point
and prepared to attack the city. Manned
by sailors fresh from Nelson’s service, and
by veteran soldiers, they presented a for-
midable array to the handful of citizens
who determined to sell their lives dearly
in defense of Baltimore.

General Smith, in command of the mili-
tary force of the city, sent a party to “feel
out” the enemy. ree thousand strong,
and led by General Stricker, this brigade
was composed of patriots, some in uniform,
some wearing plain homespun.

On the morning of the 14th, the British,
commanded by General Ross, disembarked
and prepared to sack the “Pirate’s Den” of Baltimore, as the
enemy called it. They were met by the advance guard of
Americans under Stricker, and the Battle of North Point ensued.
In the first skirm'ish. General Ross was killed; a musket ball
passing through his chest. The British failed in their efforts to
take the city by a landing force, and retired to their ships.

The cornerstone of the monument was laid September 12,
1815, on the first anniversary of the battle. The shaft was made
of white marble, and the bas reliefs depict the battle itself,

the death of General Ross, and the bombardment of Fort
McHenry.

Eight car lines pass the Battle Monument. Numbers 11, 17
and 29 on Calvert Street; Numbers 1, 7, 8, 23 and 26 on
Fayette Street.

(O) The Peabody Institute

On the southeast corner of Mount Vernon Place is the Pea-
body Institute, the center of the musical life of Baltimore. Many
famous names have been associated with this institution. Sidney
Lanier, the southern poet, was at one time a member of its
orch_estra. The Peabody Library, next to the Conservatory of
Music, boasts a splendid collection of the world’s greatest
literary works. ‘

George Peabody was born in Danvers, Massachusetts, in
1795. Because of the redueed straits of his family, he was
compelled to leave school at the age of eleven. When but a
youth, he and his brother opened a small store in Newburyport,
but a fire put an end to their business career, and Peabody
determined to go south.

He set out for Georgetown, in 1815, but the British were on
their way to destroy Washington, and young Peabody enlisted
with the defenders. He was sent to Fort Warburton, Maryland,
and there he met Francis Scott Key and Elisha Riggs. Later
he met another Baltimoreans, John P. Kennedy, with whom he
established a firm friendship.

., After the war, Peabody and Riggs set up in business in Bal-
timore, and prospered. In 1837, Peabody journeyed to England
to_transact business, and finding it greatly to his liking, de-
cided to live there. He still kept alive his interest in Baltimore
and knowing Kennedy’s love for the city, Peabody consulted him
as to the best possible foundation that could be established.

In 1868, the Peabody Institute was established, and has re-
mained a cultural influence on the life of the community.

The Charles Street and Mount Royal Avenue buses pass
directly by the Peabody Institute, and it is accessible by street
car from any point in the city.

Roger Brooke Taney Statue

In Mount Vernon Place stands the bronze statue of Taney,
Maryland’s illustrious Chief Justice of the United States Supreme
Court. He served under Andrew Jackson as Attorney General
and Secretary of the Treasury. He was born in 1777 and died
in 1864. The Charles Street buses pass the statue, and it is
accessible by street car from all city points.

John Eager Howard Statue

Among the foremost men of Maryland in ‘our national his-
tory, is John Eager Howard. The fine bronze equestrian statue
of Howard stands at the extreme northern edge of Mount Ver-
non Place, overlooking Charles Street. 3

John Eager Howard was born June 4th, 1752, in Baltimore
County. He reached manhood just before war was declared
between England and the Colonies. Immediately enlisting in
the cause of his country, he raised a company of militia, of
which he was chosen captain. After the battle of Hobkirk’s
Hill, he succeeded to the command of the 2nd regiment of regu-
lars on the death of Colonel Ford.

He participated in the battles of White Plains and German-
town, distinguishing himself by his bravery and skill. In 1780,
the Maryland troops were sent to the south; their first engage-
ment was at Camden, S. C., where Colonel Howard displayed
great skill under disaster. At Cowpens, he played so important
and brilliant a part, that Congress conferred a medal upon
him. At this battle he had at one time in his hands the swords
of seven officers who had surrendered personally to him.

In all the succeeding battles of the campaign he bore himself
bravely, and was severely wounded in the battle of Eutaw.

After the war, in 1788, Colonel Howard was elected Governor
of the State, and in the fall of 1796, he was sent to the United
States Senate, which he graced with his presence until March,
1803.

It is fitting and proper that the monument to Howard should
stand in Mount Vernon Place, the grounds of which he himself
donated for the monument to his brother-at-arms, General
‘Washington.

The Charles Street bus passes the Howard statue, and the 11,
17, and 29 line cars pass within one block of it.

Otterbein Church -

Quaint old Otterbein Church, at Sharp and Conway Streets, =.
built in 1785 by Philip William Otterbein, bishop and founder <
of the United Brethren in Christ, cradled the first American- =
born religious denomination. The bells for the tower were cast”™ ==
in Bremen in 1789, but the church is a perfect example of early...
American architecture. Routes 19, 82 and 2 reach the church.



(G) The Shot Tower -

At the corner of Fayette and Front Streets, stands another ES
landmark of the halcyon days of old Baltimore; the Shot Tower. -7
Constructed of very fine brick, without the use of scaffolding,.. ..
the tower risés to a height of 250 feet. The cornerstone was <
laid in 1828, by Charles Carroll of Carrollton, and a million =
bricks were used in the construction. It is one of the last of _‘L:“:
the old shot manufactories. C:_'S

The old tower has been the scene of....‘..j
many exciting episodes; for example on -
the morning of September 22, 1878, a citi- €12
zen awakened the members of Number 1 €773
Hook and Ladder Company, and inform
them that fire was coming out of the to
of the tower. On the arrival of the Fire
Department, the sight was a magnificent
one. There stood the tower, its base all
darkness, while out of the top poured fire
and smoke, illuminating the city for blocks
around. As the firemen prepared to carry
their hose into the tower, Mr. Simon V.
Cullen, superintendent at the works, rushed
up and shouted that there were fifteen tons
of lead at the top. The men in the tower
were ordered to drop everything and run
for their lives. Scarcely had the last man
reached the pavement, when down came
the immense weight of liquid lead. If Mr.
Cullen had been ten minutes late, that force
of intrepid fire fighters would have met
instant death at the post of duty.

However, the Shot Tower was: saved for
4 future generations of Baltimoreans, and it
can be seen by taking the Fayette Street
bus, which runs directly by it, or it is as-
cessible by street car from any point in
“ the city.

(H) The University
of Maryland

At the corner of Lombard
and Greene Streets stands
the famous University of
Maryland Medical College, a
building modeled after the
mPantheon. at Rome. The
University began in a Col-
ege of Medicine established
n 1807, and five years later

its charter was enlarged and
the present building erected in 1811.

From this famous old school have come some of the most
learned physicians the world has known. Chief among them,
Doctor Nathan Ryno Smith, elected to the chair of surgery in
1827. The reputation earned by Professor Smith as one of the
most skillful surgeons in the country attracted students from all
parts of the South and West, and frequently from the North.
Doctor Smith was universally accorded the title, ‘‘Chief of
American Surgeons.”

In 1823, the Baltimore Infirmary, or University Hospital was
erected, and a training school for nurses added. Here students
acquired a practical knowledge of the science of medicine as
they proceeded with their theoretical studies. In 1841, the De-
partment of Chemistry was added to the University, and the
Dental Department organized in 1882.

.The study of Law began with the establishing of the Univer-
sity in 1807, and some of the first statesmen and lawyers of
the country were graduated here.

The Number 3 line passes directly by the University of Mary-
land and the University Hospital. Number 2, 15, 18 and 33
line cars pass within a block of these buildings. They are easily
reached by street car from any point in the city.












On the northeast corner of Front and Lombard Streets stands
the old home of Charles Carroll of Carrollton. This distinguished
son of Maryland, known as her ‘“First Citizen,” was born in
Annapolis, in 1737.

‘When Carroll was ten years old, he was sent over to the
eastern shore to be educated in a school conducted by the Jesuits,
Intolerant laws were then in vogue in Maryland and young Car-
rell was taken from the school and sent to France, where he
received his education at the famous school of St. Omer’s, and
later at the College of St. Louis le Grand, at Paris.

In 1757, Carroll crossed the channel to London, where he
studied law until 1764, when he returned to Maryland.

On August 2, 1776, when the Declaration of Independence was
presented to the Maryland members, John Hancock asked Car-
roll if he would sign it. ‘“Most willingly,” said Carroll, and
signed his name as was his wont—Charles Carroll. A by-
stander remarked, ‘“There go millions.” ‘No,’”’ said another,
‘“there are several Carrolls, they will not be able to identify
him.” TUpon hearing this Carroll took up his pen and added to
his signature “Of Carrollton,” remarking as he did so, ‘“There,
they will not mistake me now.”

Number 5, 18, and 33 line cars pass by the old Carroll resi-
dence.

(K) The Revolutionary Monument

At Mount Royal Avenue and Cathedral Street, opposite Mount
Royal Station, stands the shaft commemorating the men of
Maryland who fought with such valor during the struggle for
independence.

The granite shaft, surmounted by a bronze statue of Liberty,
by Van der Bergen, rises to a height of sixty feet. It was un-
veiled in October, 1901, and carries the inscription; ‘‘To the
Maryland Line, Who Were to Generals Washington and Greene
what the ‘Old Guard’ was to Napoleon; to the ‘Bayonets of the
Revolution’ we Dedicate This Shaft.”

The Maryland regiment won the right to be called the “Bay-
onets of the Revolution” by distinguished bravery in action at
the battle of Long Island. Washington chose them to meet
the crack British troops bayonet to bayonet and thrust for
thrust. Hopelessly outnumbered and surrounded, they forced
back the enemy three times, and when finally driven from the
field, they brought their prisoners with them.

Throughout the entire war, the Maryland militia continued to
distinguish itself by conspicuous bravery, and at the _close of
the struggle, with victory won, Washington expressed his heart-
felt dgratitude for the assistance the Maryland Line had ren-
dered.

The Mount ‘Royal Bus passes the Revolutionary Monument.

St. Mary’s Seminary

Originally St. Mary’s College, this historic Sulpician seminal_‘y
was built at Paca and St. Mary’s Streets and Pennsylvaqla
Avenue late in the 18th Century. The spot was then the site
of the One Mile Tavern, far from the distractions of -the city.
Two portraits by Rubens hang in a classroom. Many dis-
tinguished Marylanders graduated from St, Mary’s before it
began exclusively preparing men for the Catholic priesthood.
Routes 5, 1§ and 33 pass the Seminary.

(J) The Flag House

At the corner of Pratt and Albemarle Streets, sandwiched in
between larger buildings devoted to commerce, stands the little
old-fashioned house where the flag was made that flew over Fort
McHenry and inspired Key to write his immortal song.

Here, in 1814, lived Mary Pickersgill, and to her home came
General McDonald, who lived around the corner, and Commodore
Barney. Their quest was to ask if she would make a flag that
should fly over the City as a signal of “no surrender.” Flag
making ran in the Pickersgill family; her mother had_ made
them during the Revolution under the guidance of Washington.

Together, Mrs. Pickersgill and her little daughter Caroline,
worked night and day on the flag which was to fly over Balti-

more. It was a large and cumbersome piece of work, too large -

indeed for the little house in which they lived, and so permission
was had from a nearby malt house, where the wox:k could be
finished more rapidly.

At last the flag was fin-
= ished and wunfurled to the
breeze, and valiantly went
S g forth the Baltimore militia to
Py defend the town against the
crack British regiments com-
manded by the brilliant Gen-
eral Ross. What transpired
is written to their glory in
the annals of history. Ross
was killed, the British with-
drew, and the “‘Star Spangled
Banner’’ was given to the
world.

The “Old Flag House’” has
been taken over by the city:
and placed under the care of
a patriotic group of men and
women who have made it a
worthy shrine to the patriots
that defended Baltimore.

The Number 10 line car
passes by the Flag House,
and it can be reached by
electric car from virtually
any point in the City.
