(D) Grave of Edgar Allan Poe

In the old Westminster Churchyard,



the marble monument marking the
grave of Edgar Allan Poe, that melan-
choly genius whose short life was so
poignant with beauty and tears. Poe
was born on Front Street, Baltimore,
and although much of his life was
spent elsewhere, he lived and died here,

were written in this city ; notably, ‘“The
Raven,” and “The Bells.”

Buffeted in life by trouble and mis-
understandings, Poe finally came to his
end in the charity ward of a public
hospital on October 7, 1849, One car-
riage hauled all the mourners who followed him to a pauper’s
grave in the rear of Westminster churchyard. In this forgotten
spot he lay neglected and alone, his grave decked with weeds,
its only visitors the wind and the rain.

On November 17, 1875, a second funeral was held for Poe
and his body moved to a more suitable spot on the Fayette Street
side of the churchyard. A fine white marble monument, pur-
chased with money contributed by school children, was erected
over the grave. At the unveiling of this monument many not-
ables were present, among them Walt Whitman; and letters
were read from Longfellow, Tennyson, Lowell, Whittier and
Swinburne.

On June 25, 1921, the French Literary Society presented a
bronze wreath in memory of Poe. This wreath was attached to
the right hand side of the shaft. The front of the monument
bears the name, Edgar Allan Poe, and beneath it is a bronze
bust of the poet, taken from an old daguerreotype. On the
bottom of the monument is simply inscribed the words,

Born, January 19, 1809
Died, October 7, 1849

Number 1, 7, 8 and 18 line cars pass Westminster Churchyni'd
where one may visit the grave of Poe. The Baltimore Press
Club looks after this shrine and bestows much care upon it.

(E) The Lexington Market

On Lexington Street, stretching be-
tween Eutaw and Pearl Streets, is the
famous old Lexington Market. The
land on which the market stands was
donated to the City by John Eager
Howard, and in 1803 it was formally
opened. At that time it occupied but
one block, between Eutaw and Paca
Streets, but with the passing of years
its commercial value expanded and new
additions were constantly added wuntil
it reached its present proportions.

There is an appealing ‘old-world”
charm about the market. Here you will
find color and beauty. Little flower
stalls mingle with Italian fruit stands.
The hustle and bustle of shopping
crowds ; the busy hawkers crying their
wares; heaps of produce from the
countryside ; quarters of beef, fat pork-
ers and tender lamb, home-made cookie >
stalls, pickle stands; fish, crabs and oysters in season, fresh
from the Chesapeake. Winter brings an added touch of color
when the mantle of snow descends upon the market. Here and
there, great charcoal braziers throw their red glow about a group
of rosy cheeked marketeers, stamping thickly shod feet and
swinging burly arms against the bite of the frosty air.

The Lexington Market is one of the few remaining, still
thriving, traditions of early life in Baltimore.

Other old markets are Belair, Broadway, Hollins and Cross
Street markets, and the newest is North Avenue Market, a
model of sanitation and cleanliness.

Street cars passing directly through the Lexington market
area are lines Number 5, 16, 18, 31 and 83. It is easily acces-
sible by street car from any part of the City. :

(F) The Battle Monument




At Calvert and Fayette Streets stands
the Battle Monument, erected in honor of -
the defenders of the city at the Battle of
North Point more properly called ‘“The
Battle of Baltimore.”

On September 11, 1814, a fleet of fifty -
British warships anchored off North Point
and prepared to attack the city. Manned
by sailors fresh from Nelson’s service, and
by veteran soldiers, they presented a for-
midable array to the handful of citizens
who determined to sell their lives dearly
in defense of Baltimore.

General Smith, in command of the mili-
tary force of the city, sent a party to “feel
out” the enemy. ree thousand strong,
and led by General Stricker, this brigade
was composed of patriots, some in uniform,
some wearing plain homespun.

On the morning of the 14th, the British,
commanded by General Ross, disembarked
and prepared to sack the “Pirate’s Den” of Baltimore, as the
enemy called it. They were met by the advance guard of
Americans under Stricker, and the Battle of North Point ensued.
In the first skirm'ish. General Ross was killed; a musket ball
passing through his chest. The British failed in their efforts to
take the city by a landing force, and retired to their ships.

The cornerstone of the monument was laid September 12,
1815, on the first anniversary of the battle. The shaft was made
of white marble, and the bas reliefs depict the battle itself,

the death of General Ross, and the bombardment of Fort
McHenry.

Eight car lines pass the Battle Monument. Numbers 11, 17
and 29 on Calvert Street; Numbers 1, 7, 8, 23 and 26 on
Fayette Street.

(O) The Peabody Institute

On the southeast corner of Mount Vernon Place is the Pea-
body Institute, the center of the musical life of Baltimore. Many
famous names have been associated with this institution. Sidney
Lanier, the southern poet, was at one time a member of its
orch_estra. The Peabody Library, next to the Conservatory of
Music, boasts a splendid collection of the world’s greatest
literary works. ‘

George Peabody was born in Danvers, Massachusetts, in
1795. Because of the redueed straits of his family, he was
compelled to leave school at the age of eleven. When but a
youth, he and his brother opened a small store in Newburyport,
but a fire put an end to their business career, and Peabody
determined to go south.

He set out for Georgetown, in 1815, but the British were on
their way to destroy Washington, and young Peabody enlisted
with the defenders. He was sent to Fort Warburton, Maryland,
and there he met Francis Scott Key and Elisha Riggs. Later
he met another Baltimoreans, John P. Kennedy, with whom he
established a firm friendship.

., After the war, Peabody and Riggs set up in business in Bal-
timore, and prospered. In 1837, Peabody journeyed to England
to_transact business, and finding it greatly to his liking, de-
cided to live there. He still kept alive his interest in Baltimore
and knowing Kennedy’s love for the city, Peabody consulted him
as to the best possible foundation that could be established.

In 1868, the Peabody Institute was established, and has re-
mained a cultural influence on the life of the community.

The Charles Street and Mount Royal Avenue buses pass
directly by the Peabody Institute, and it is accessible by street
car from any point in the city.

Roger Brooke Taney Statue

In Mount Vernon Place stands the bronze statue of Taney,
Maryland’s illustrious Chief Justice of the United States Supreme
Court. He served under Andrew Jackson as Attorney General
and Secretary of the Treasury. He was born in 1777 and died
in 1864. The Charles Street buses pass the statue, and it is
accessible by street car from all city points.

John Eager Howard Statue

Among the foremost men of Maryland in ‘our national his-
tory, is John Eager Howard. The fine bronze equestrian statue
of Howard stands at the extreme northern edge of Mount Ver-
non Place, overlooking Charles Street. 3

John Eager Howard was born June 4th, 1752, in Baltimore
County. He reached manhood just before war was declared
between England and the Colonies. Immediately enlisting in
the cause of his country, he raised a company of militia, of
which he was chosen captain. After the battle of Hobkirk’s
Hill, he succeeded to the command of the 2nd regiment of regu-
lars on the death of Colonel Ford.

He participated in the battles of White Plains and German-
town, distinguishing himself by his bravery and skill. In 1780,
the Maryland troops were sent to the south; their first engage-
ment was at Camden, S. C., where Colonel Howard displayed
great skill under disaster. At Cowpens, he played so important
and brilliant a part, that Congress conferred a medal upon
him. At this battle he had at one time in his hands the swords
of seven officers who had surrendered personally to him.

In all the succeeding battles of the campaign he bore himself
bravely, and was severely wounded in the battle of Eutaw.

After the war, in 1788, Colonel Howard was elected Governor
of the State, and in the fall of 1796, he was sent to the United
States Senate, which he graced with his presence until March,
1803.

It is fitting and proper that the monument to Howard should
stand in Mount Vernon Place, the grounds of which he himself
donated for the monument to his brother-at-arms, General
‘Washington.

The Charles Street bus passes the Howard statue, and the 11,
17, and 29 line cars pass within one block of it.

Otterbein Church -

Quaint old Otterbein Church, at Sharp and Conway Streets, =.
built in 1785 by Philip William Otterbein, bishop and founder <
of the United Brethren in Christ, cradled the first American- =
born religious denomination. The bells for the tower were cast”™ ==
in Bremen in 1789, but the church is a perfect example of early...
American architecture. Routes 19, 82 and 2 reach the church.



(G) The Shot Tower -

At the corner of Fayette and Front Streets, stands another ES
landmark of the halcyon days of old Baltimore; the Shot Tower. -7
Constructed of very fine brick, without the use of scaffolding,.. ..
the tower risés to a height of 250 feet. The cornerstone was <
laid in 1828, by Charles Carroll of Carrollton, and a million =
bricks were used in the construction. It is one of the last of _‘L:“:
the old shot manufactories. C:_'S

The old tower has been the scene of....‘..j
many exciting episodes; for example on -
the morning of September 22, 1878, a citi- €12
zen awakened the members of Number 1 €773
Hook and Ladder Company, and inform
them that fire was coming out of the to
of the tower. On the arrival of the Fire
Department, the sight was a magnificent
one. There stood the tower, its base all
darkness, while out of the top poured fire
and smoke, illuminating the city for blocks
around. As the firemen prepared to carry
their hose into the tower, Mr. Simon V.
Cullen, superintendent at the works, rushed
up and shouted that there were fifteen tons
of lead at the top. The men in the tower
were ordered to drop everything and run
for their lives. Scarcely had the last man
reached the pavement, when down came
the immense weight of liquid lead. If Mr.
Cullen had been ten minutes late, that force
of intrepid fire fighters would have met
instant death at the post of duty.

However, the Shot Tower was: saved for
4 future generations of Baltimoreans, and it
can be seen by taking the Fayette Street
bus, which runs directly by it, or it is as-
cessible by street car from any point in
“ the city.

(H) The University
of Maryland

At the corner of Lombard
and Greene Streets stands
the famous University of
Maryland Medical College, a
building modeled after the
mPantheon. at Rome. The
University began in a Col-
ege of Medicine established
n 1807, and five years later

its charter was enlarged and
the present building erected in 1811.

From this famous old school have come some of the most
learned physicians the world has known. Chief among them,
Doctor Nathan Ryno Smith, elected to the chair of surgery in
1827. The reputation earned by Professor Smith as one of the
most skillful surgeons in the country attracted students from all
parts of the South and West, and frequently from the North.
Doctor Smith was universally accorded the title, ‘‘Chief of
American Surgeons.”

In 1823, the Baltimore Infirmary, or University Hospital was
erected, and a training school for nurses added. Here students
acquired a practical knowledge of the science of medicine as
they proceeded with their theoretical studies. In 1841, the De-
partment of Chemistry was added to the University, and the
Dental Department organized in 1882.

.The study of Law began with the establishing of the Univer-
sity in 1807, and some of the first statesmen and lawyers of
the country were graduated here.

The Number 3 line passes directly by the University of Mary-
land and the University Hospital. Number 2, 15, 18 and 33
line cars pass within a block of these buildings. They are easily
reached by street car from any point in the city.












On the northeast corner of Front and Lombard Streets stands
the old home of Charles Carroll of Carrollton. This distinguished
son of Maryland, known as her ‘“First Citizen,” was born in
Annapolis, in 1737.

‘When Carroll was ten years old, he was sent over to the
eastern shore to be educated in a school conducted by the Jesuits,
Intolerant laws were then in vogue in Maryland and young Car-
rell was taken from the school and sent to France, where he
received his education at the famous school of St. Omer’s, and
later at the College of St. Louis le Grand, at Paris.

In 1757, Carroll crossed the channel to London, where he
studied law until 1764, when he returned to Maryland.

On August 2, 1776, when the Declaration of Independence was
presented to the Maryland members, John Hancock asked Car-
roll if he would sign it. ‘“Most willingly,” said Carroll, and
signed his name as was his wont—Charles Carroll. A by-
stander remarked, ‘“There go millions.” ‘No,’”’ said another,
‘“there are several Carrolls, they will not be able to identify
him.” TUpon hearing this Carroll took up his pen and added to
his signature “Of Carrollton,” remarking as he did so, ‘“There,
they will not mistake me now.”

Number 5, 18, and 33 line cars pass by the old Carroll resi-
dence.

(K) The Revolutionary Monument

At Mount Royal Avenue and Cathedral Street, opposite Mount
Royal Station, stands the shaft commemorating the men of
Maryland who fought with such valor during the struggle for
independence.

The granite shaft, surmounted by a bronze statue of Liberty,
by Van der Bergen, rises to a height of sixty feet. It was un-
veiled in October, 1901, and carries the inscription; ‘‘To the
Maryland Line, Who Were to Generals Washington and Greene
what the ‘Old Guard’ was to Napoleon; to the ‘Bayonets of the
Revolution’ we Dedicate This Shaft.”

The Maryland regiment won the right to be called the “Bay-
onets of the Revolution” by distinguished bravery in action at
the battle of Long Island. Washington chose them to meet
the crack British troops bayonet to bayonet and thrust for
thrust. Hopelessly outnumbered and surrounded, they forced
back the enemy three times, and when finally driven from the
field, they brought their prisoners with them.

Throughout the entire war, the Maryland militia continued to
distinguish itself by conspicuous bravery, and at the _close of
the struggle, with victory won, Washington expressed his heart-
felt dgratitude for the assistance the Maryland Line had ren-
dered.

The Mount ‘Royal Bus passes the Revolutionary Monument.

St. Mary’s Seminary

Originally St. Mary’s College, this historic Sulpician seminal_‘y
was built at Paca and St. Mary’s Streets and Pennsylvaqla
Avenue late in the 18th Century. The spot was then the site
of the One Mile Tavern, far from the distractions of -the city.
Two portraits by Rubens hang in a classroom. Many dis-
tinguished Marylanders graduated from St, Mary’s before it
began exclusively preparing men for the Catholic priesthood.
Routes 5, 1§ and 33 pass the Seminary.

(J) The Flag House

At the corner of Pratt and Albemarle Streets, sandwiched in
between larger buildings devoted to commerce, stands the little
old-fashioned house where the flag was made that flew over Fort
McHenry and inspired Key to write his immortal song.

Here, in 1814, lived Mary Pickersgill, and to her home came
General McDonald, who lived around the corner, and Commodore
Barney. Their quest was to ask if she would make a flag that
should fly over the City as a signal of “no surrender.” Flag
making ran in the Pickersgill family; her mother had_ made
them during the Revolution under the guidance of Washington.

Together, Mrs. Pickersgill and her little daughter Caroline,
worked night and day on the flag which was to fly over Balti-

more. It was a large and cumbersome piece of work, too large -

indeed for the little house in which they lived, and so permission
was had from a nearby malt house, where the wox:k could be
finished more rapidly.

At last the flag was fin-
= ished and wunfurled to the
breeze, and valiantly went
S g forth the Baltimore militia to
Py defend the town against the
crack British regiments com-
manded by the brilliant Gen-
eral Ross. What transpired
is written to their glory in
the annals of history. Ross
was killed, the British with-
drew, and the “‘Star Spangled
Banner’’ was given to the
world.

The “Old Flag House’” has
been taken over by the city:
and placed under the care of
a patriotic group of men and
women who have made it a
worthy shrine to the patriots
that defended Baltimore.

The Number 10 line car
passes by the Flag House,
and it can be reached by
electric car from virtually
any point in the City.

f P

SPECIAL MAPS AND SHEETS.

[Measurements are approximate.]

Electric generating stations and transmission lines used in the public service in Maryland
and Delaware in 1919. The hydroelectric generating stations, the fuel-consuming generating
stations, the stations combining these two sources of power, the substations, the switching stations,
and the primary transmission lines are shown by distinctive symbols, printed in red. A numbered list
of the operating companies is printed on the margin of the map, and the proper number is placed at
each station symbol on the map. Size, 25 by 39 inches. Secale, 1:500,000, or about 8 miles to 1 inch.
Price, 50 cents; if included in wholesale ord=rs, 30 cents. :

Maryland and Delaware (States). This map is in black and white. It shows county boundaries,
location and names of all towns and most of the smaller settlements, railroads, rivers, and many of
the smaller streams and water features. It does not show contours. Size, 20 by 34 inches. Scale,
1:500.000, or about 8 wiles to 1 inch. Price, 25 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 15 cents. Also
published on a scale of 1:1,000,000, or about 16 miles to 1 inch; size, 12 by 19 inches; price, b cents; if
included in wholesale orders, 3 cents.

Philadelphia and vicinity, Pa.-N. J.-Del. This map is composed of the Philadelphia, Germantown,
Norristown, and Chester maps, combined and printed as a single map. Limiting parallels, 39° 45’ and
40° 15. Limiting meridians, 75° and 75° 30. Size, 32 by 40 inches. Scale, 1:62,500 or about 1 mile to
1inch. Contour interval, 20 feet. Price, 40 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 24 cents.

Washington and vicinity. This map embraces an area of 464 square miles and shows the entire District
of Columbia and adjoining parts of the States of Maryland and Virginia. Limiting parallels, 38° 45" and
39 5. Liwmiting meridians, 76° 52 30 and 77 15. Size, 44 by 52 inches. Scale, 1:31,680, or half a mile
to 1 ineh. Contour interval, 10 feet. Published in two editions. one showing automobile roads in red.
Price of either edition. 25 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 15 cents.

Washington and vicinity (road map). Shaded relief map of part of Maryland and Virginia, with the
Disirict of Columbia near the center of the area. Limiting parallels, 33° 30" and 39° 30". Limiting
meridians, 76 30 and i7° 30. Size, 17 by 20 inches. Seale, 1:250,000 or about 4 wiles to 1 inch. Balti-
lore is near the northeast corner of the area Annapolis on the eastern margin, and Frederick in the
northwest corner. On the south the area extends just beyond Quantico, Va., and La Plata, Md. The
main through roads »nd other improved roads are shown by red overprint, and the quality of the roads
is indicated. On the back of the sheet 1s an interesting deseription of the country around Washington,
in which the chief features of geographie, geologie, and historic interest are briefly considered. Price,
10 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 6 cents.

Coal fields and producing districts. A set of nine maps, on a scale of 1:1,000,000, or about 16 miles to
1 inch. showing the principal coal-producing distriets and the areas underlain by coal-bearing rocks in
the following States: West Virginia and part of Maryland, Kentucky, Tennessee. Pennsylvania, Virginia,
Alabama and part of Georgia, Ohio. Indiana, and 1llinois. Price of each map, 10 cents, or of the set,
50 cents, which should not be included in wholesale orders.

North America. This map does not show contours. Size, 29 by 38 inches. Scale, 1:10,000,000, or about
158 miles to 1 ineh. Price, 40 cents: if included in wholesale orders, 24 cents.

Sheet of conventional signs. Shows symbols and abbreviations adopted by the U. S. Geographic
Board and recommended for use on Government maps. Size, 20 by 33 inches. Price, 20 cents; if
inceluded in wholesale orders, 12 cents.

Sheet of lettering and conventional signs. Shows lettering and symbols used on the topographic
maps of the U. 8. Geological Survey. Size, 16§ by 20 inches. Price, 10 cents; if included in wholesale
orders, 6 cents.



LOCAL AGENTS FOR TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS.

Purchasers may save delay incident to ordering through the mails by buying of the following
agents, who carry in stock maps of areas in their vicinity and sell them at prices slightly in
advance of rates mentioned in this circular:

MARYLAND.

BALTIMORE: CUMBERLAND:
Prof. A. B. Bibbins, Maryland Academy of Science, John A. Fulton & Co., Books and Stationery.
1056 West Franklin Street.
Lucas Bros., 221 East Baltimore Street.
Sutton & Co., 839 St. Paul Place.
Young & Selden, Calvert and Saratoga streets.

PENNSYLVANIA.
PHILADELPHIA: ;
C. 8. Wertsner & Son, 50 North Thirteenth Street.
DELAWARE.
WILMINGTON:

E. S. R. Butler & Son, 421 Market Street.
David A. Hay & Co., 121 Market Street.

DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR

UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY

TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF

MARYLAND AND DELAWARE

MADE AND FOR SALE BY THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

The United States Geological Survey is making a standard topographic atlas of the United
States. The unit of survey is a quadrangle bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of
longitude, but different quadrangles are mapped on different scales, and consequently the standard
maps,'though of nearly uniform size (about 164 by 20 inches), represent areas of different sizes.
The standard scales are 1:31,680 (1 inch —one-half mile), 1:62,500 (1 inch=nearly 1 mile), and
1:125,000 (1 inch =nearly 2 miles). Some maps are published on special scales for special pur-
poses. Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature
within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which
maps have been published. The maps are engraved on copper and printed from stone, in three
colors. The cultural features, such as roads, railroads, cities, and towns, as well as the lettering,
are in black ; the water features are in blue; and the features of relief—hills, mountains, etc.—are
shown by brown contour lines. The contour interval differs according to the scale of the map and
the relief of the country. On some maps the contour lines are supplemented by shading, which
gives a more pictorial representation of the relief, and on some maps woodland areas are shown in
green and special features in other colors.

Maryland and Delaware are now completely mapped, as shown on the index map within.
The surveys in Maryland from 1896 to 1912 were made in cooperation with the State. Each of the
rectangles outlined in red on the index map shows the location and area of a quadrangle of which
a topographic survey has been made. The name of the resulting topographic map, if published,
is also shown, and its scale is indicated by the size of the rectangle; thus the larger rectangles indi-
cate the smaller-scale maps and the smaller rectangles the larger-scale maps. For areas represented
by small rectangles within larger ones maps on different scales have been published. Each of
the maps represented by the smaller rectangles shows a quadrangle measuring 15’ each way (one-
sixteenth of a “square degree’’), or from 229 to 236 square miles, the area differing according
to the latitude. The scale is 1:62,500, or about 1 mile to 1 inch, and the contour interval is
either 10 or 20 feet, but as the entire area shown on two of the maps in Maryland is less than
5 feet above sea level these maps have no contour lines. Each of the maps represented by the
larger rectangles shows a quadrangle measuring 30’ each way (one-fourth of a ‘‘square degree’’),
or from 919 to 938 square miles. The scale is 1:125,000, or about 2 miles to 1 inch, and the con-
tour interval ranges from 10 to 100 feet. The whole number of published topographic maps cover-
ing quadrangles in Maryland is 81, in Delaware 21. If maps covering areas in both States are
counted only once the total is 93. A list of special maps and sheets is given on page 6.

The price of the standard maps of either large or small quadrangles is 10 cents each, but a
discount of 40 per cent is allowed on an order amounting to %5 at the retail price—that is, the
wholesale rate for standard topographic maps is $3 for 50. The discount is allowed on an
order for maps alone, either of one kind or in any assortment, or for maps together with geologic
folios. (See p. 4.) Prices for maps other than the standard are given on page 6 of this circular.
No discount will be allowed on an order amounting to less than $3. Prepayment is required and
may be made by money order, payable to the Director of the United States Geological Survey
(not postage stamps), or in cash—the exact amount—at sender’s risk.

If maps ordered are not in stock the right is reserved to substitute others rather than
return very small sums of money by mail, unless directions to the contrary are given in the order.
Name of county should be included in post-office address.

The Survey can not supply mounted maps.

All correspondence should be addressed to—

THE DIRECTOR,
UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY,
W ASHINGTON, D. C.

January 1, 1924.

5—10,000.

39 5. Liwmiting meridians, 76° 52 30 and 77 15. Size, 44 by 52 inches. Scale, 1:31,680, or half a mile
to 1 ineh. Contour interval, 10 feet. Published in two editions. one showing automobile roads in red.
Price of either edition. 25 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 15 cents.

Washington and vicinity (road map). Shaded relief map of part of Maryland and Virginia, with the
Disirict of Columbia near the center of the area. Limiting parallels, 33° 30" and 39° 30". Limiting
meridians, 76 30 and i7° 30. Size, 17 by 20 inches. Seale, 1:250,000 or about 4 wiles to 1 inch. Balti-
lore is near the northeast corner of the area Annapolis on the eastern margin, and Frederick in the
northwest corner. On the south the area extends just beyond Quantico, Va., and La Plata, Md. The
main through roads »nd other improved roads are shown by red overprint, and the quality of the roads
is indicated. On the back of the sheet 1s an interesting deseription of the country around Washington,
in which the chief features of geographie, geologie, and historic interest are briefly considered. Price,
10 cents; if included in wholesale orders, 6 cents.

Coal fields and producing districts. A set of nine maps, on a scale of 1:1,000,000, or about 16 miles to
1 inch. showing the principal coal-producing distriets and the areas underlain by coal-bearing rocks in
the following States: West Virginia and part of Maryland, Kentucky, Tennessee. Pennsylvania, Virginia,
Alabama and part of Georgia, Ohio. Indiana, and 1llinois. Price of each map, 10 cents, or of the set,
50 cents, which should not be included in wholesale orders.

North America. This map does not show contours. Size, 29 by 38 inches. Scale, 1:10,000,000, or about
158 miles to 1 ineh. Price, 40 cents: if included in wholesale orders, 24 cents.

Sheet of conventional signs. Shows symbols and abbreviations adopted by the U. S. Geographic
Board and recommended for use on Government maps. Size, 20 by 33 inches. Price, 20 cents; if
inceluded in wholesale orders, 12 cents.

Sheet of lettering and conventional signs. Shows lettering and symbols used on the topographic
maps of the U. 8. Geological Survey. Size, 16§ by 20 inches. Price, 10 cents; if included in wholesale
orders, 6 cents.



LOCAL AGENTS FOR TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS.

Purchasers may save delay incident to ordering through the mails by buying of the following
agents, who carry in stock maps of areas in their vicinity and sell them at prices slightly in
advance of rates mentioned in this circular:

MARYLAND.

BALTIMORE: CUMBERLAND:
Prof. A. B. Bibbins, Maryland Academy of Science, John A. Fulton & Co., Books and Stationery.
1056 West Franklin Street.
Lucas Bros., 221 East Baltimore Street.
Sutton & Co., 839 St. Paul Place.
Young & Selden, Calvert and Saratoga streets.

PENNSYLVANIA.
PHILADELPHIA: ;
C. 8. Wertsner & Son, 50 North Thirteenth Street.
DELAWARE.
WILMINGTON:

E. S. R. Butler & Son, 421 Market Street.
David A. Hay & Co., 121 Market Street.

DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR

UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY

TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF

MARYLAND AND DELAWARE

MADE AND FOR SALE BY THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

The United States Geological Survey is making a standard topographic atlas of the United
States. The unit of survey is a quadrangle bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of
longitude, but different quadrangles are mapped on different scales, and consequently the standard
maps,'though of nearly uniform size (about 164 by 20 inches), represent areas of different sizes.
The standard scales are 1:31,680 (1 inch —one-half mile), 1:62,500 (1 inch=nearly 1 mile), and
1:125,000 (1 inch =nearly 2 miles). Some maps are published on special scales for special pur-
poses. Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature
within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which
maps have been published. The maps are engraved on copper and printed from stone, in three
colors. The cultural features, such as roads, railroads, cities, and towns, as well as the lettering,
are in black ; the water features are in blue; and the features of relief—hills, mountains, etc.—are
shown by brown contour lines. The contour interval differs according to the scale of the map and
the relief of the country. On some maps the contour lines are supplemented by shading, which
gives a more pictorial representation of the relief, and on some maps woodland areas are shown in
green and special features in other colors.

Maryland and Delaware are now completely mapped, as shown on the index map within.
The surveys in Maryland from 1896 to 1912 were made in cooperation with the State. Each of the
rectangles outlined in red on the index map shows the location and area of a quadrangle of which
a topographic survey has been made. The name of the resulting topographic map, if published,
is also shown, and its scale is indicated by the size of the rectangle; thus the larger rectangles indi-
cate the smaller-scale maps and the smaller rectangles the larger-scale maps. For areas represented
by small rectangles within larger ones maps on different scales have been published. Each of
the maps represented by the smaller rectangles shows a quadrangle measuring 15’ each way (one-
sixteenth of a “square degree’’), or from 229 to 236 square miles, the area differing according
to the latitude. The scale is 1:62,500, or about 1 mile to 1 inch, and the contour interval is
either 10 or 20 feet, but as the entire area shown on two of the maps in Maryland is less than
5 feet above sea level these maps have no contour lines. Each of the maps represented by the
larger rectangles shows a quadrangle measuring 30’ each way (one-fourth of a ‘‘square degree’’),
or from 919 to 938 square miles. The scale is 1:125,000, or about 2 miles to 1 inch, and the con-
tour interval ranges from 10 to 100 feet. The whole number of published topographic maps cover-
ing quadrangles in Maryland is 81, in Delaware 21. If maps covering areas in both States are
counted only once the total is 93. A list of special maps and sheets is given on page 6.

The price of the standard maps of either large or small quadrangles is 10 cents each, but a
discount of 40 per cent is allowed on an order amounting to %5 at the retail price—that is, the
wholesale rate for standard topographic maps is $3 for 50. The discount is allowed on an
order for maps alone, either of one kind or in any assortment, or for maps together with geologic
folios. (See p. 4.) Prices for maps other than the standard are given on page 6 of this circular.
No discount will be allowed on an order amounting to less than $3. Prepayment is required and
may be made by money order, payable to the Director of the United States Geological Survey
(not postage stamps), or in cash—the exact amount—at sender’s risk.

If maps ordered are not in stock the right is reserved to substitute others rather than
return very small sums of money by mail, unless directions to the contrary are given in the order.
Name of county should be included in post-office address.

The Survey can not supply mounted maps.

All correspondence should be addressed to—

THE DIRECTOR,
UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY,
W ASHINGTON, D. C.

January 1, 1924.

5—10,000.

This set of pictures was taken by the United States Navy, Bureau of Aeronautics, Rear Admiral W. A.
Moffett, Commanding; commencing on the west side of Chesapeake Bay north of the mouth of the Severn River,
and continuing up the west side of the bay; Patapsco River, and Baltimore Harbor, passing around the Upper Basin
and down the East Side of the Harbor and River to North Point.

In obtaining permission from the United States Navy to use these pictures, it was expressly agreed that
they would not be used in any form except as presented herewith, and that they would not be put to any pri-
vate or commercial use whatsoever. Reproduction in any form is positively prohibited.

J. E. GREINER » H. H. A

J. E. GREINER COMPANY

CONSULTING ENGINEERS
1201 ST. PAUL STREET
BALTIMORE, MD.

October 15, 1938.

State Roads Commission of Maryland,
Federal Reserve Bank Building,
Baltimore, Maryland.

Gentlemen:

Complying with the terms of our contract dated June 3, 1938,
we respectfully submit herewith our report on the following crossings,
comprising Maryland's Primary Bridge Program:—

A A bridge across the Susquehanna River from Havre de Grace
to Perryville;

2 A bridge across the Patapsco River from Fairfield to Canton
in Baltimore City, and as an alternate thereto, a tunnel
under the Patapsco River between said two points;

3 A bridge across the Potomac River from Ludlow's Ferry,
Maryland, to Dahlgren, Virginia; and

4 A bridge across the Chesapeake Bay to be located either from
Millers Island to Tolchester, or from Sandy Point to Kent
Island.

We present herewith the principal data for each of the crossings.
Estimates of gross revenue and maintenance and operation expenses are

based on the reports of Coverdale and Colpitts.

Susquehanna River Bridge





Length

Bay Bridge, Sandy Point site alone, $96,000 per annum.

Interest During Construction and Bond Discount.......... $14,110,000



The maintenance and operation expenses listed hereinbefore under
each of the crossings cover operation, maintenance and insurance with about-
five per .cent contingencies, but does not include general and administrative
expense which will vary in amount, depending upon the number of bridges to
be included in the program and the proportionate part of these items of ex-
pense which may be borne by the Commission and paid for from funds other than
toll revenues.

We have previously reported to you that the War Department
Engineers have signified to us the basis upon which they will approve plans
for a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay at Sandy Point. Our report is based

field_edited_text_processed:
State Roads Commission. -7- ~ October 15, 1938,

upon plans which the War Department Engineers have reviewed and have
indicated will be approved for this crossing. We have been further
advised by the War Department Engineers that no action will be taken
at this time toward the approval of plans for the Millers' Island site.
You were advised, at the time of the War Department Hearing, of the
opposition on the part of the Commanding Officer at Aberdeen Proving
Grounds to a bridge of any kind at the Millers' Island site.

Because of the uncertainty of approval by the War Department
of a Bay Bridge at the Millers' Island site and because the traffic re-
ports indicate that the Sandy Point Bridge will carry more traffic and
serve more people, we concur with the view of the Commission that the
Sandy Point — Kent Island site is preferable and should be selected.

We recommend the construction of a bridge across the Patapsco
River as preferable to the construction of a tunnel, since the bridge will
cost less than the tunnel, will accommodate traffic in the future until
the traffic volume has reached the present volume of traffic over the
Hanover Street Bridge, whereas a tunnel will reach its maximum capacity
when traffic reaches a maximum of six and one half million vehicles per
year, and a bridge may be maintained and operated for $87,000. per year
less than the annual sum required to maintain and operate a tunnel.

Objections to a bridge, as voiced by the aviation interests in
Baltimore, are based upon alleged interference with the Baltimore Municipal
Airport and operation of sea planes in the Patapsco River. The bridge is
more than two miles from the center of the airport, whereas legal control
over airport surroundings has never been extended beyond one and one half
miles. The bridge towers will be only about half as high as the Maryland
Statute permits, even if the control were extended to include the area of
the bridge.

The objections on account of alleged interference with landing
and taking off of sea planes fail to recognize the already existing
obstacles to the use of the main Fort McHenry navigation channel for such
landings and take offs, because of the activity of shipping in Baltimore
Harbor which, according to a recent report of the Baltimore Association of
Commerce, is second only to New York.

The estimates of cost of the several crossings and their respective
approaches have been very carefully prepared, and we believe them to rep-
resent the true cost of the several crossings under existing construction
conditions. Fluctuations in labor and material costs will affect the final
costs, but unless such fluctuations are considerable, -the estimates herein -
presented will be sufficient to complete each of the crossings.

It is assumed that the cost bf the projects will be financed by T‘
grants of 45¢ from the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works and
by the sale of Revenue Bonds sufficient to pay the remaining 55% of the cost.

field_edited_text_processed:
State Roads Commission. -8- October 15, 1938.

We have fully considered the sources of labor and material
supplies in preparing the estimates, in order to insure the completion
of the work within the time limits established by the P.W.A.

Neither the Sandy Point Bridge nor the Millers' Island Bridge
could be completed by June 30, 1940. Progress Chart, Plate 83,
for the Sandy Point Bridge indicates that two and one half years would
be required for the completion of this bridge. No similar Progress Chart
has been prepared for the Millers' Island Bridge because of previous in-
dications that this bridge would not be built, but such a chart, if pre-
pared, would indicate that about two and one half years would be required
for its completion. Each of the three bridges across the Susquehanna, the
Patapsco, and the Potomac Rivers, respectively, can be completed by June 30,
1940, provided the schedules shown on Progress Charts, Plates 15, 47, and
64, are followed with respect to authorizations to proceed.

The principal parts of all structures have been actually designed
to insure accuracy in estimating quantities of construction materials.

All construction plans are based on the use of standard construc-
tion methods. The deep pier foundations have been specially designed by
us and may, in the future, be patented by us. In the event these designs
should be patented by us, the Commission will of course be entitled to their
use in connection with the bridges covered by this report, without charge
other than the fees named in our engineering contract of June 3, 1938.

We have previously informed the Commission that substantial savings
in the cost of construction of these bridges can be effected by the use of
certain patented designs. The actual amount of the saving on any particular
bridge will depend upon the royalty or license fee required to be paid for
the use of the patented design. We understand that the owners of the patents
in question have submitted to the Commission an offer to permit the use
of their patented design in connection with certain of these bridges upon
certain conditions and that such offer is being considered by the Commission
at this time. In the event an agreement is reached between the Commission
and the patent owners we will be in a position to make revised cost estimates.

We recommend that copies of our report, submitted herewith, be
forwarded to the Regional Director of the P.W.A. in New York as the basis
for amendments of your applications for P.W.A. grants, Maryland Docket
Nos. 1138 and 1139.

The estimates which accompanied your applications to the P.W.A.
were prepared in July, 1938, from plans submitted to the War Department,
before the War Department Engineers had indicated to us what changes would
be required in the plans, and before borings had been completed at Havre de
Grace and at Sandy Point.

The estimates presented in our report submitted herewith, are less
than those accompanying the P.W.A. applications of August 1, 1938, in the
case of the Patapsco River Bridge and are greater in the case of all other
crossings.

field_edited_text_processed:
State Roads Commission. -9- October 15, 1938.

The main channel span lengths have been increased in the case of
all other crossings, to meet navigation requirements as determined by the
War Department Engineers.

The channel spans in the Susquehanna River Bridge have been
increased from 350 feet to 456 feet, and borings disclosed that
rock is deeper than had been estimated by comparison with the adjacent
railroad bridge foundations.

No changes have been required in the main channel clearance of the
Patapsco River Bridge. The 1000 feet lateral clearance proposed has
been accepted by the War Department.

The length of the main channel span in the Potomac River Bridge
has been increased from 650 feet to 800 feet, to provide a lateral clearance
of 700 feet instead of 570 feet, to meet War Department requirements.

The main span has also been shifted eastward into deeper water, as required
by the War Department.

The east channel span in the Millers' Island - Tolchester Bridge
has been increased to provide 1000 feet lateral clearance, instead of 636
feet, and the west channel span has been decreased in vertical clearance
from 140 feet to 50 feet. The increased cost of the east channel span
will not be offset by the decreased cost of the west channel span.

The location of the Sandy Point - Kent Island Bridge has been
shifted south about one mile, making the crossing considerably longer than
originally proposed. The main channel span has been increased to provide
1200 feet lateral clearance instead of 1000 feet. The east channel span
has been entirely omitted, although all spans across the deep water of
the bay at this site have been increased in length in order to balance
substructure and superstructure costs. Here again the increase in cost,
due to lengthening the west channel span, will not be entirely offset by
the decrease due to the omission of the east channel span.

The total estimated cost, exclusive of interest during construction
and bond discount, of the four bridges proposed to be constructed in the
program, namely; Susquehanna River Bridge, Patapsco River Bridge, Potomac
River Bridge and Chesapeake Bay Bridge (Sandy Point—Kent Island Site) is
$33,911,100.

Respectfully submitted,

J. E. GREINER COMPANY

N QA AN A
field_edited_text_value:
State Roads Commission. -9- October 15, 1938.

The main channel span lengths have been increased in the case of
all other crossings, to meet navigation requirements as determined by the
War Department Engineers.

The channel spans in the Susquehanna River Bridge have been
increased from 350 feet to 456 feet, and borings disclosed that
rock is deeper than had been estimated by comparison with the adjacent
railroad bridge foundations.

No changes have been required in the main channel clearance of the
Patapsco River Bridge. The 1000 feet lateral clearance proposed has
been accepted by the War Department.

The length of the main channel span in the Potomac River Bridge
has been increased from 650 feet to 800 feet, to provide a lateral clearance
of 700 feet instead of 570 feet, to meet War Department requirements.

The main span has also been shifted eastward into deeper water, as required
by the War Department.

The east channel span in the Millers' Island - Tolchester Bridge
has been increased to provide 1000 feet lateral clearance, instead of 636

The total estimated cost, exclusive of interest during construction

Respectfully submitted,

J. E. GREINER COMPANY

field_edited_text_processed:
Engineering Organization





THE engineering work for this program was done under the direct super-
vision of John E. Greiner, B.S., C.E., Sc.D., Dr.Eng., Hon. M. Am. Soc.
C.E. and Herschel H. Allen, B.S. in C.E., C.E., M. Am. Soc. C.E., members
of the firm of J. E. Greiner Company.

The following engineers were called in for special consultation work:—

Glennon Gilboy, S.B., S.M., Se.D., Assoc. M. Am. Soc. C.E., Assoc.
Prof. of Soil Mech., Mass. Inst. Tech. on Soil Analysis;

Ole Singstad, C.E., M. Am. Soc. C.E., Chief Engr. New York City
Tunnel Authority, for preparation of plans and estimates for
Patapsco River Tunnel,;

Thomas F. Comber, Jr., B.S. in C.E., M. Am. Soc. C.E., Assoc. Prof.
of Civ. Eng., The Johns Hopkins Univ., on special computations.

S. S. Steinberg, B.E., C.E., M. Am. Soc. C.E., Acting Dean, Coll. of
Eng., Univ. of Md., as surveys consultant and in general charge
of all surveys; and

Milton A. Pyle, B.S., in C.E., C.E., Asst. Prof. of Civ. Eng., Coll. of
Eng., Univ. of Md., as Engineer of Surveys.

The following members of J. E. Greiner Company’s staff were assigned
to head the engineering groups for each of the crossings:—

Edward Russell Allen, B.S. in C.E., Assoc. M. Am. Soc. C.E.;

Joseph K. Knoerle, B.S. in M.E., M.S., Assoc. M. Am. Soc. C.E.;
W. Calvert Roberts, A.B., C.E.

William H. Pahl, B.S. in C.E.

It was necessary to greatly expand the regular engineering force of J. E.
Greiner Company, in order to complete the engineering work on schedule.
In addition to the foregoing engineering executives, a force of eighty skilled
engineers, draftsmen, surveyors and junior assistants, working day and
night, were required to complete the engineering data embodied in this
report.

field_edited_text_processed:
Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program





THE LARGE percentage of water area in the State of Maryland,
including the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, presents a traffic problem
which has become more and more pressing as the use of the automobile for
transportation has increased. Ways and means of financing a program of
bridge construction to connect the shores of the State, separated by these
waterways, have been discussed for many years. Various planning groups,
not only in the State of Maryland and in the City of Baltimore, but also in
Washington, have studied the necessary crossings. The problem has
national significance as well as being vital to the State, with relation to
the development of an arterial highway system.

The City of Washington is quite as much interested as the State of Mary-
land in the solution to this problem, since the people of that City are almost
as dependent upon the Maryland highway system as are the people of the
State of Maryland. It has been estimated that about three quarters of the
population of the United States is so located with respect to Washington
that this large number of citizens of the country would have to pass through
the State of Maryland, in order to reach the National Capital.

Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program has therefore been developed as a
combination of the needs of the State, the needs of the Nation (insofar as
the Capital of the country is concerned), and the needs of the populous
areas along the Atlantic Seaboard, requiring bridges to connect an arterial
north-south route, by-passing the congested areas of the metropolitan
districts. The program as developed, therefore, includes the bridges in a
National North-South Highway comprising Project Number 1 of the
program. The bridges in this project, listed from north to south, include
crossings of the Susquehanna River, Patapsco River and the Potomac
River.

Upon the completion of these three crossings and the necessary connect-
ing roads, a modern north-south arterial highway through the State of
Maryland will have become a reality. Motor vehicle traffic from Phila-

1

Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program





THE LARGE percentage of water area in the State of Maryland,
including the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, presents a traffic problem
which has become more and more pressing as the use of the automobile for
transportation has increased. Ways and means of financing a program of
bridge construction to connect the shores of the State, separated by these
waterways, have been discussed for many years. Various planning groups,
not only in the State of Maryland and in the City of Baltimore, but also in
Washington, have studied the necessary crossings. The problem has
national significance as well as being vital to the State, with relation to
the development of an arterial highway system.

The City of Washington is quite as much interested as the State of Mary-
land in the solution to this problem, since the people of that City are almost
as dependent upon the Maryland highway system as are the people of the
State of Maryland. It has been estimated that about three quarters of the
population of the United States is so located with respect to Washington
that this large number of citizens of the country would have to pass through
the State of Maryland, in order to reach the National Capital.

Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program has therefore been developed as a
combination of the needs of the State, the needs of the Nation (insofar as
the Capital of the country is concerned), and the needs of the populous
areas along the Atlantic Seaboard, requiring bridges to connect an arterial
north-south route, by-passing the congested areas of the metropolitan
districts. The program as developed, therefore, includes the bridges in a
National North-South Highway comprising Project Number 1 of the
program. The bridges in this project, listed from north to south, include
crossings of the Susquehanna River, Patapsco River and the Potomac
River.

Upon the completion of these three crossings and the necessary connect-
ing roads, a modern north-south arterial highway through the State of
Maryland will have become a reality. Motor vehicle traffic from Phila-

1

field_edited_text_processed:
2 MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRIDGE PROGRAM

delphia, New York, and other northeastern points destined either for
Baltimore, Annapolis, Washington, Richmond or other southern points,
will use the Susquehanna River Bridge. Such traffic destined for Wash-
ington, Annapolis, Richmond, and other southern points will use both the
Susquehanna River Bridge and the Baltimore Harbor crossing. Such
traffic destined for Richmond and other southern points will use all three
of the bridges constituting this project and will be enabled to by-pass
both the City of Baltimore and the City of Washington. Not only will
the actual distance by motor vehicle between Philadelphia and Richmond
be shortened appreciably, but the actual travel time by motor vehicle be-
tween Philadelphia and Richmond will be shortened tremendously.

Project Number 2 of the program comprises a crossing of the Chesapeake
Bay. A highway bridge between the Eastern and Western Shores is a
necessary link to connect the highway systems of these now divided sec-
tions of the State. There are alternate locations under consideration, the
choice between the two depending upon the capital expenditure and pro-
spective revenues from tolls in each case hereinafter developed. One of the
sites for the proposed Chesapeake Bay Crossing lies between Millers Is-
land and Tolchester. A bridge at this site would form a new arterial high-
way leading into the City of Baltimore. The other site proposed for this
crossing lies between Sandy Point and Kent Island. The upper crossing
lies north of the mouth of the Patapsco River at a narrow point in the
bay and crosses navigation channels leading from Baltimore through the
C & D Canal. The lower bridge crosses the main ship channel between the
Virginia Capes and Baltimore Harbor and is located at the narrowest part
of the Bay. The upper location involves a crossing ten miles long including
the approaches across Hart and Millers Island; while the lower crossing is
about five miles long. The former would be a direct highway from Balti-
more to the Eastern Shore, while the latter would form a connection be-
tween the Eastern and Western Shores more accessible for the people in
the Washington area than a bridge at the former location would be, but
removed farther from Baltimore.

The necessity for bridges in Maryland has been officially recognized in
the past, through the appointment by the Governor of a Commission to
study the problem confronting Maryland by reason of the increasing use
of the automobile. The Chesapeake Bay separates the State for 130 miles,
with no highway connection except by means of ferries. Maryland and
Virginia are separated by the Potomac River for the entire length of the
field_edited_text_value:
2 MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRIDGE PROGRAM

delphia, New York, and other northeastern points destined either for
Baltimore, Annapolis, Washington, Richmond or other southern points,
will use the Susquehanna River Bridge. Such traffic destined for Wash-
ington, Annapolis, Richmond, and other southern points will use both the

Virginia are separated by the Potomac River for the entire length of the

field_edited_text_processed:
MARYLAND’S PrRiMARY BRIDGE PrRoGRAM 3

river below Washington without a highway connection other than an inade-
quate ferry. Seven years ago the Commission appointed by the Governor
and consisting of leading citizens from every section of the State, urged
that a plan be adopted to finance the sorely needed bridges by the revenue
bond method of financing, which is based upon the principle that the users
of the bridge will pay for it, and after once having been paid for, the bridge
will then become a free facility for the use of the traveling public. By this
method of financing, highway funds and gasoline taxes will not be used to
pay for the bridge structures, but will be available for building increased
miles of highway and for general road purposes. Thus the development of
this bridge plan is a matter of evolution over a number of years, and not an
entirely new proposal.

The progressive development of the program resulted finally in State
Legislation, and on April 15, 1937, the Governor of Maryland approved
an Act of the Maryland Legislature, effective June 1, 1937, (Chapter 356,
Acts of 1937, Regular Session), authorizing the State Roads Commission to
formulate a comprehensive plan for the construction of bridges and tunnels,
providing for the creation of the Bridge Supervisory Committee, providing
for the construction, operation and maintenance of bridges over and tunnels
under rivers and navigable waters which are wholly or partly in the State,
authorizing the issuance of Revenue Bonds of the State through the State
Roads Commission and providing for the collection of tolls for the payment
of such bonds and the interest thereon and for the cost of maintenance,
operation and repair of the bridges and tunnels.

On April 7, 1938 the President of the United States approved an Act of
Congress authorizing the State of Maryland, by and through its State
Roads Commission, to construct, maintain, and operate (1) A bridge across
the Susquehanna River from a point in Cecil County at or near Perryville
to a point approximately opposite in Harford County at or near Havre de
Grace; (2) A bridge across or a tunnel under the Patapsco River south of
the City of Baltimore from a point at or near the mouth of North West
Branch to a point approximately opposite at or near Fairfield; (3) A bridge
across the Potomac River from a point in Charles County at or near Lud-
low’s Ferry to a point approximately opposite in the State of Virginia near
Dahlgren and Colonial Beach; and (4) A bridge across the Chesapeake
Bay from a point in Baltimore County at or near Millers Island to a point
approximately opposite in Kent County at or near Tolchester; or, as an
alternate thereto, a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay or a tunnel under or
field_edited_text_value:

quate ferry. Seven years ago the Commission appointed by the Governor

Bay from a point in Baltimore County at or near Millers Island to a point

alternate thereto, a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay or a tunnel under or

field_edited_text_processed:
4 MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRIDGE PROGRAM

a combined bridge and tunnel from a point in Anne Arundel County at or
near Annapolis to a point approximately opposite on Kent Island.

The Bridge Supervisory Committee, created by the above mentioned
Maryland Act of 1937 consists of seven members and includes well known
citizens of the State, prominent in their respective businesses and profes-
sions, and vested with the responsibility for the approval or veto of any
program of bridges or tunnels adopted by the State Roads Commission
under said Act.

On September 7, 1938 the State Roads Commission adopted a program
comprising the four crossings described above, and on September 13, 1938
the Bridge Supervisory Committee approved the plan adopted by the State
Roads Commission by the passage of a resolution which in part reads as
follows:

“BE IT RESOLVED that this Committee does hereby approve the project adopted
by the State Roads Commission as set out in such resolution as feasible and practicable
and advantageous to the State of Maryland;
~ FURTHER RESOLVED that the State Roads Commission is requested to file with
this Committee such additional detailed data with respect to each of the items in the
foregoing project as may be reasonably desired by this Committee; and that no material
modification of the project hereby approved and no material details with respect to the
consummation of such project shall be adopted by the State Roads Commission without
the prior approval of this Committee.”

The Congressional Act authorizing the construction of the bridges in this
program requires that plans and specifications for same shall be submitted
to the Secretary of War and Chief of Engineers for their approval and shall
be approved by them before construction shall commence.

The Chief of Engineers of the United States Army has indicated to the
State Roads Commission the requirements at four of the sites to meet
navigation needs, and the plans for the crossings as shown on the plates
referred to herein are based upon plans which the War Department has
approved or which the War Department has indicated will be approved.

With respect to the Chesapeake Bay Bridge at Millers Island, the War
Department has indicated that a main east channel span with 1000 feet
horizontal clearance and 140 feet vertical clearance, located closer to the
Eastern Shore than was originally proposed by the State Roads Commis-
sion, would be the basis of the requirement if the War Department were to
further consider the approval of a bridge at this site. The Department has
field_edited_text_value:
4 MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRIDGE PROGRAM

a combined bridge and tunnel from a point in Anne Arundel County at or
near Annapolis to a point approximately opposite on Kent Island.

The Bridge Supervisory Committee, created by the above mentioned
Maryland Act of 1937 consists of seven members and includes well known
citizens of the State, prominent in their respective businesses and profes-
sions, and vested with the responsibility for the approval or veto of any
program of bridges or tunnels adopted by the State Roads Commission
under said Act.

comprising the four crossings described above, and on September 13, 1938
the Bridge Supervisory Committee approved the plan adopted by the State
Roads Commission by the passage of a resolution which in part reads as
follows:

by the State Roads Commission as set out in such resolution as feasible and practicable
and advantageous to the State of Maryland;
~ FURTHER RESOLVED that the State Roads Commission is requested to file with
this Committee such additional detailed data with respect to each of the items in the
foregoing project as may be reasonably desired by this Committee; and that no material
modification of the project hereby approved and no material details with respect to the
consummation of such project shall be adopted by the State Roads Commission without
the prior approval of this Committee.”

The Congressional Act authorizing the construction of the bridges in this
program requires that plans and specifications for same shall be submitted
to the Secretary of War and Chief of Engineers for their approval and shall
be approved by them before construction shall commence.

The Chief of Engineers of the United States Army has indicated to the
State Roads Commission the requirements at four of the sites to meet
navigation needs, and the plans for the crossings as shown on the plates
referred to herein are based upon plans which the War Department has
approved or which the War Department has indicated will be approved.

With respect to the Chesapeake Bay Bridge at Millers Island, the War
Department has indicated that a main east channel span with 1000 feet
horizontal clearance and 140 feet vertical clearance, located closer to the
Eastern Shore than was originally proposed by the State Roads Commis-
sion, would be the basis of the requirement if the War Department were to
further consider the approval of a bridge at this site. The Department has

field_edited_text_processed:
MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRrRIDGE ProGrRAM 5

also indicated that it would approve a modification in the plans submitted,
by reducing the vertical clearance at the west channel crossing from 140
feet to 50 feet. It was determined that 50 feet vertical clearance would be
sufficient at this crossing.

In the case of the Sandy Point-Kent Island Bridge, the State Roads Com-
mission proposed two channel crossings. The War Department has decided
that only one is needed, but has requested that this span be widened to
provide for 1200 feet lateral clearance instead of 1000 feet lateral clearance
proposed, with vertical clearance of 175 feet. Also the location of the
bridge will be shifted south, in order to provide better navigation ap-
proaches to the channel span than was possible at the location proposed
originally, which was very close to the turn in the navigation channel at
Sandy Point Lighthouse.

In the case of the Susquehanna River Bridge, the span lengths are
longer than those originally proposed. These longer spans were dictated
by economical layout requirements, after depth of foundations had been
definitely established by borings.

The War Department modifications in the plans for crossing the Patapsco
River consisted only of changes in the fender system. The proposed 1000
feet horizontal clearance and 175 feet vertical clearance over the channel
has been approved by the War Department.

The Potomac River Bridge has been changed to meet War Department
requirements by increasing the channel span 150 feet in length (from 650
feet to 800 feet) to provide for a clear opening 700 feet wide. The vertical
clearance of 135 feet has not been changed for this structure. The channel
span, however, has been shifted eastward toward the Maryland shore,
which has effected changes in the approach spans which, in addition to the
increased span length, make this bridge a more expensive structure than it
would have been under the original plans.

The State Roads Commission has made two applications to the Federal
Emergency Administration of Public Works for grants to aid in financing
the construction of the four bridges in this program. One application
covers the three bridges in the north-south highway as a single project
herein designated as Project Number 1, including the Susquehanna, Pa-
tapsco, and Potomac River Bridges. See (1), (2), and (3) on Map of
Maryland, showing Arterial Highways—Plate 1.

The other application covers a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay, herein
field_edited_text_value:
MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRrRIDGE ProGrRAM 5

also indicated that it would approve a modification in the plans submitted,
by reducing the vertical clearance at the west channel crossing from 140
feet to 50 feet. It was determined that 50 feet vertical clearance would be
sufficient at this crossing.

In the case of the Sandy Point-Kent Island Bridge, the State Roads Com-
mission proposed two channel crossings. The War Department has decided
that only one is needed, but has requested that this span be widened to
provide for 1200 feet lateral clearance instead of 1000 feet lateral clearance
proposed, with vertical clearance of 175 feet. Also the location of the
bridge will be shifted south, in order to provide better navigation ap-
proaches to the channel span than was possible at the location proposed
originally, which was very close to the turn in the navigation channel at
Sandy Point Lighthouse.

In the case of the Susquehanna River Bridge, the span lengths are
longer than those originally proposed. These longer spans were dictated
by economical layout requirements, after depth of foundations had been
definitely established by borings.

The War Department modifications in the plans for crossing the Patapsco
River consisted only of changes in the fender system. The proposed 1000
feet horizontal clearance and 175 feet vertical clearance over the channel
has been approved by the War Department.

The Potomac River Bridge has been changed to meet War Department
requirements by increasing the channel span 150 feet in length (from 650
feet to 800 feet) to provide for a clear opening 700 feet wide. The vertical
clearance of 135 feet has not been changed for this structure. The channel
span, however, has been shifted eastward toward the Maryland shore,
which has effected changes in the approach spans which, in addition to the
increased span length, make this bridge a more expensive structure than it
would have been under the original plans.

The State Roads Commission has made two applications to the Federal
Emergency Administration of Public Works for grants to aid in financing
the construction of the four bridges in this program. One application
covers the three bridges in the north-south highway as a single project
herein designated as Project Number 1, including the Susquehanna, Pa-
tapsco, and Potomac River Bridges. See (1), (2), and (3) on Map of
Maryland, showing Arterial Highways—Plate 1.

The other application covers a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay, herein

field_edited_text_processed:

designated as Project Number 2, at either one of the two alternate loca-
tions. See (4) and (4A) on Map of Maryland, showing Arterial High-
ways—Plate 1.
An engineering report covering each of the crossings is contained herein,

in the following order:

1. Susquehanna River Bridge.

2. Patapsco River Crossing.

3. Potomac River Bridge.

field_edited_text_processed:
Engineering Procedure





EARLY in May, 1938 the State Roads Commission engaged the services
of Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, to
prepare a traffic survey and traffic report to determine prospective reve-
nues from tolls which may be expected from toll facilities in the Maryland
Bridge Program. Under date of August 13, 1938 the preliminary report
on estimated traffic and revenues for crossings comprised in the State of
Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program was submitted to the State Roads
Commission by Coverdale and Colpitts. On September 3, 1938 they sub-
mitted their final report entitled ‘‘Report on Estimated Traffic Gross
Revenues and Toll Schedules for Crossings Included in the State of Mary-
land’s Primary Bridge Program.”

The Revenue Bond method of financing public works in which prospec-
tive revenues form the only security for the bonds, is made possible when
prospective revenues are sufficient without question, to pay all costs in
connection with the proposed construction project, when a completed
project can be proven to cost no more than the proceeds of the bonds
issued for that purpose, and when revenues or other funds are sufficient
to cover fully the cost of maintaining the facility for the life of the bonds,
and the cost of operating the facility efficiently to insure its earning capac-
ity during the life of the bonds, as well as the cost of interest and amortiza-
tion.

On May 20, 1938 the State Roads Commission engaged the services of
J. E. Greiner Co. to prepare an Engineering report on the crossings included
in this program and to perform engineering services in connection with the
construction of those structures which are authorized to proceed.

The object of this report is to determine the cost of each of the crossings
in the program, to set forth the amount of funds necessary to be made
available for the complete operation, maintenance and insurance of each
of the crossings during the life of the bond issue, and to set forth for ready
reference the results of the traffic survey and traffic report referred to above.

7

ENGINEERING PROCEDURE 9

expenses and fees; cost of audits; and all other items of expense
incident to the construction and equipment of each of the
facilities; cost of lands, properties, rights-of-way, franchises,
and damages incident to or consequent upon the construction
and operation of the facilities.

(9) The completion of engineering reports for each of the crossmgs in
the program, for use by the State Roads Commission in financ-
ing the project, and in dealing with Federal or other agencies
for grants or subsidies.

II. “Contract Plans and Specifications,” consists of the preparation of
contract plans, specifications, contract documents, advertising for bids,
receiving bids, investigation of bidders, award of contracts, and all else re-
quired preparatory to the beginning of actual construction work. In a
program of the magnitude of that herein described, this phase of engineering
will run concurrently with the third phase, IIT “Supervision of Construe-
tion,” for the reason that the first contracts to be awarded on each of the
crossings will consist of substructure work only, while the superstructures,
toll plazas, lighting, toll equipment, and other portions of the structures
can be started at later dates and can be designed, planned, and specified
coincident with the supervision of the construction contracts which have
been previously awarded and the construction of which is then under way.
By this means this second phase of engineering work may be extended,
thus spreading the engineering work over a longer period without producing
undue peaks of work to be completed within short periods of time.

II1I. “‘Supervision of Construction,” consists of supervision of laying out
the work by setting grades to be followed in the work of construction,
maintaining engineering control over the construction, to insure its comple-
tion within the time limit preseribed, the sampling and testing of all ma-
terials entering the construction work, the inspection of the work as it
progresses, to insure workmanship and materials of the quality specified,
the preparation of estimates of the value of the work performed, periodically
during the progress of the work, and the final approval, acceptance, and
preparation of final estimates for payment for the work completed.

The first phase of the engineering work, ‘“Preliminary Work,” has now
been completed. J. E. Greiner Company’s organization was subdivided
into four groups, each group headed by an engineer in responsible charge
of the development of all of the preliminary engineering phases of the cross-

field_edited_text_processed:
10 ENGINEERING PROCEDURE

ing assigned to him, with the group organizations directed and supervised
by the members of J. K. Greiner Co. The duties of each of the engineers
in charge of each crossing were as follows:

1. Assigning of individual tasks and duties to the members of his group.

2. Maintaining contact with the survey corps in order to insure receipt
of survey data on his particular structure in the order in which the
data was required for the proper coordination of his program.

3. Assembly of all data available pertaining to the ownership and value
of properties required for the construction of the structure.

4. The first objective on the part of the group chief was the preparation
and completion of drawings prepared in accordance with the rules
and regulations of the War Department, to accompany an applica-
tion for a War Department Permit to build the structure.

This was accomplished after the completion of preliminary studies
and estimates in sufficient detail to discuss with the War Depart-
ment the effect of wider and higher clearances on the cost of the
structure, and also to be able to make accurate comparisons between
the cost of a bridge and a tunnel, in the case of the Patapsco River
Crossing.

It was necessary to study shipping conditions in order to arrive at
reasonable lateral and vertical clearances to accommodate present
and future shipping.

Simultaneous with the preparation of War Department permit
drawings for a bridge, it was necessary to make preliminary sketches
and estimates for a tunnel at the Patapsco River Crossing looking
toward the possibility of the Government making the span and
height requirements for a bridge so expensive that it would be
cheaper to put a tunnel under ground, even when the differences
in operation costs were considered. A bridge can satisfy navigation
requirement at any site anywhere if the span is made long enough
and the clearance high enough. In the case of the Patapsco River
Crossing aviation conditions were investigated.

5. After the War Department had indicated its requirements for the con-
struction of a structure the engineering group proceeded immedi-
ately with the preparation of the engineering report for which the
following data was prepared.

A. A map showing the crossing with connecting arterial high-
ways.

The topographical surveys at the site of all the crossings were made by
survey corps furnished for the purpose by the State Roads Commission
under the general direction of S. S. Steinberg, Dean of Engineering at the
University of Maryland, acting as Survey Consultant in collaboration with
J. E. Greiner Company and M. A. Pyle, member of the engineering faculty
of the University of Maryland, acting as engineer of surveys to whom the
chiefs of survey parties reported directly. Surveys were completely co-
ordinated with the U. S. Coast and Geodetic control points and at one time
for a period of several weeks, there were six U. S. Coast and Geodetic men
and nine five-men survey parties assigned to the work in progress of making
the surveys at the sites of all of these bridges. Permanent triangulation
points, hubs and bench marks have been established at all crossing sites.
