field_edited_text_processed:
Susquehanna River Bridge





SITE OF THE BRIDGE

HE modern dual highway, The Governor Nice Highway, U. S. Number 40,
between the City of Baltimore and Havre de Grace, was completed in 1937.
The State Roads Commission plans to extend this highway by way of North-
east, by-passing Elkton, to the Maryland-Delaware line. At this point it will
connect with the present dual highway leading to Wilmington, Philadelphia
and the New Castle Ferry crossing the Delaware River. The proposed new
bridge across the Susquehanna River is an essential link in this plan of im-
provement, as the existing bridge at Havre de Grace, an old converted bridge
of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, is inadequate and unfavorably
located. Traffic on U. S. Number 40 now passes through the streets of Havre
de Grace and Perryville, but will be removed from these streets when the
new bridge forms a link in the new highway route. The site of this new
bridge is about midway between the Pennsylvania Railroad Bridge crossing
the Susquehanna River at Havre de Grace and the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-
road Bridge crossing the river just north of Havre de Grace, and is shown on
the “Vicinity Map,” Plate 2. The new route will be designated as part of
the official U. S. Route No. 40. There was no highway bridge at or near
Havre de Grace prior to the conversion of the present Pennsylvania Rail-
road Bridge in 1910.

EXISTING BRIDGE

The existing bridge is located immediately south of the present Pennsyl-
vania Railroad Bridge, and was built between the years 1870 and 1880 by
the Philadelphia-Baltimore and Washington Railroad Company. It is
comprised of twelve fixed spans and one swing span, with a total length of
3,382 feet. Some of the spans were constructed with Phoenix column sec-
tions for the main compression members, while other spans built later con-
tained structural box sections more nearly conforming to modern bridge
construction. All spans were pin connected, as was the general practice in
bridge construction at that time. The substructure consists of heavy
masonry piers and abutments.

In 1904, the Railroad was authorized to build a new bridge, under legisla-

14
field_edited_text_value:
Susquehanna River Bridge





SITE OF THE BRIDGE

HE modern dual highway, The Governor Nice Highway, U. S. Number 40,
between the City of Baltimore and Havre de Grace, was completed in 1937.
The State Roads Commission plans to extend this highway by way of North-
east, by-passing Elkton, to the Maryland-Delaware line. At this point it will
connect with the present dual highway leading to Wilmington, Philadelphia
and the New Castle Ferry crossing the Delaware River. The proposed new
bridge across the Susquehanna River is an essential link in this plan of im-
provement, as the existing bridge at Havre de Grace, an old converted bridge
of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, is inadequate and unfavorably
located. Traffic on U. S. Number 40 now passes through the streets of Havre
de Grace and Perryville, but will be removed from these streets when the
new bridge forms a link in the new highway route. The site of this new
bridge is about midway between the Pennsylvania Railroad Bridge crossing
the Susquehanna River at Havre de Grace and the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-
road Bridge crossing the river just north of Havre de Grace, and is shown on
the “Vicinity Map,” Plate 2. The new route will be designated as part of
the official U. S. Route No. 40. There was no highway bridge at or near
Havre de Grace prior to the conversion of the present Pennsylvania Rail-
road Bridge in 1910.

EXISTING BRIDGE

The existing bridge is located immediately south of the present Pennsyl-
vania Railroad Bridge, and was built between the years 1870 and 1880 by
the Philadelphia-Baltimore and Washington Railroad Company. It is
comprised of twelve fixed spans and one swing span, with a total length of
3,382 feet. Some of the spans were constructed with Phoenix column sec-
tions for the main compression members, while other spans built later con-
tained structural box sections more nearly conforming to modern bridge
construction. All spans were pin connected, as was the general practice in
bridge construction at that time. The substructure consists of heavy
masonry piers and abutments.

In 1904, the Railroad was authorized to build a new bridge, under legisla-

14

field_edited_text_processed:
DEescripTiON OF PROPOSED BRIDGE 15

tion which required that the old bridge be removed within one year from the
time the new bridge was put into operation. This time was subsequently
extended, and in 1908 the old bridge property was authorized to be trans-
ferred and conveyed to individuals for the purpose of converting the struc-
ture into a bridge for vehicular and pedestrian use. It was taken over by a
private corporation at that time and maintained and operated as a highway
toll bridge, until it was bought by the State through the State Roads Com-
mission, in 1922. From then until 1929 the bridge was maintained and oper-
ated as a publicly owned toll bridge.

In 1926, the State Roads Commission converted it into a double deck
bridge to increase its capacity and to provide for one way traffic in each
direction on each deck. The cost of the double decking and improvement
of the bridge was defrayed by continuing the tolls for a longer period.
Tolls were finally abolished in 1929, and since that date the bridge has been
maintained and operated by the State Roads Commission as a free facility
and as a part of the system of highways of the State.

With the increasing volume of traffic over this bridge, its obsolescence
and inadequacy has become more apparent. The vertical clearance be-
tween the decks is inadequate and frequently trucks stacked high with
freight become wedged between the deck and the overhead structure, making
it necessary to deflate the tires and thus reduce the height to allow the truck
to pass. On such occasions long lines of traffic are held up until the ob-
struction has been cleared. In addition, the structure is in poor condition
and eventually would have to be replaced.

The existing double deck bridge above described is illustrated in Figure 1,
‘““Photograph of Existing Double Deck Bridge at Havre de Grace” .

DESCRIPTION OF PROPOSED BRIDGE

The west approach to the proposed bridge begins at the intersection of
the Governor Nice Highway extended and the Chapel Road from Havre de
Grace to Bel Air, and the east approach to the bridge begins at the Perry-
ville-Aiken Road. The toll plaza is located between the Perryville-Aiken
Road and the east abutment.

The Susquehanna River at the site of the bridge is divided into two chan-
nels by Garrett Island. The bridge is made up of a west channel crossing
2169 feet long, Garrett Island crossing 1509 feet 9 inches long, an east chan-
nel crossing 1646 feet long, with a west approach section 1039 feet 3 inches
long, and an east approach section 1249 feet long, making a total length of
7613 feet from abutment to abutment. The highway approach to the west
field_edited_text_value:
DEescripTiON OF PROPOSED BRIDGE 15

tion which required that the old bridge be removed within one year from the
time the new bridge was put into operation. This time was subsequently
extended, and in 1908 the old bridge property was authorized to be trans-
ferred and conveyed to individuals for the purpose of converting the struc-
ture into a bridge for vehicular and pedestrian use. It was taken over by a
private corporation at that time and maintained and operated as a highway
toll bridge, until it was bought by the State through the State Roads Com-
mission, in 1922. From then until 1929 the bridge was maintained and oper-
ated as a publicly owned toll bridge.

bridge to increase its capacity and to provide for one way traffic in each

The existing double deck bridge above described is illustrated in Figure 1,

DESCRIPTION OF PROPOSED BRIDGE

The west approach to the proposed bridge begins at the intersection of
the Governor Nice Highway extended and the Chapel Road from Havre de
Grace to Bel Air, and the east approach to the bridge begins at the Perry-
ville-Aiken Road. The toll plaza is located between the Perryville-Aiken
Road and the east abutment.

The Susquehanna River at the site of the bridge is divided into two chan-
nels by Garrett Island. The bridge is made up of a west channel crossing
2169 feet long, Garrett Island crossing 1509 feet 9 inches long, an east chan-
nel crossing 1646 feet long, with a west approach section 1039 feet 3 inches
long, and an east approach section 1249 feet long, making a total length of
7613 feet from abutment to abutment. The highway approach to the west

field_edited_text_processed:
16 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

abutment is 1175 feet long, and the highway approach to the east abutment
is 1573 feet 8 inches long, making the total length of the bridge and ap-
proaches 10,361 feet 8 inches.

The main channel crossing over each of the two channels consists of a
three span continuous unit, the center span of which is a through truss and
the two side spans of which are part through trusses. All of the remain-
ing sections of the bridge are deck trusses or deck girders of the simple or
continuous types.

The bridge provides a roadway 46 feet wide between curbs to accommo-
date four lanes of traffic and in addition, two emergency footways each 2
feet 6 inches wide.

The maximum grade is 3 per cent, rising from the west approach to a
point over the west channel. The vertical curve connecting this approach
grade with the level grade over the remaining length of bridge is 670 feet
long, providing a minimum sight distance of 1000 feet. The alignment is
straight except for a section of the west approach which is on a 2 degree
curve.

The main channel spans crossing both the west and east channels clear
mean low water in the Susquehanna River by 89 feet, which is the same ver-
tical clearance provided by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Bridge about
1 mile upstream. A ‘“‘Sketch of the Main Channel Span over the East
Channel’”” appears on Plate 14. The lateral clearances were dictated by the
engineering economics of superstructure and substructure costs, which
provided ample navigation clearances. The bridge has been made a high
level structure to eliminate the necessity for a movable span to accommodate
navigation on the river and to effect grade separations. The elevation of
the west approach was fixed by the desirability of a grade separation at the
Aldino road from Havre de Grace to Bel Air. All approaches are above the
elevation of the highest recorded flood in the Susquehanna River. The
bridge is shown in plan and profile on “General Layout,” Plate 3, and on
“General Plan and Elevation,” Plates 4 to 10 inclusive.

The bridge has been designed for Standard H-20 loading, in accordance
with the Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges, adopted and pub-
lished by the American Highways Officials Association in 1935, except for
slight modifications, which are made necessary because the above men-
tioned specifications are intended to cover span lengths of 300 feet or less.
The design of long span highway bridges involves the use of special pro-
visions which have not been published as standard, but which have been ac-

field_edited_text_processed: Ficure 1. PHOTOGRAPH OF EXISTING DOoUBLE DECK BRIDGE AT HAVRE DE GRACE
field_edited_text_value: Ficure 1. PHOTOGRAPH OF EXISTING DOoUBLE DECK BRIDGE AT HAVRE DE GRACE

field_edited_text_processed:
BorinGgs 19

cepted by the engineering profession in connection with the long span
bridges recently built in this country.

The standard H-20 loading referred to above is intended to provide for
trucks of 20 tons gross maximum load, placed anywhere on the roadway,
and in such number as to produce the maximum stress which might occur
in any member of the bridge or portion of the structure.

TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS

The topographical surveys were preceded by reconnaissance surveys of all
available sites. The proposed site was selected after considering the follow-
ing conditions:

(1) By locating the bridge between the railroads, grade crossings or grade

separations over the main line tracks of the railroads were avoided;

(2) By selecting a location on high ground along the river for the east
approach, the railroad crossings were made less expensive;

(3) By selecting a site north of the more populous sections of Harve de
Grace and Perryville, right-of-way costs and property damages
were held to a minimum;

(4) By selecting the proposed site, the relatively inexpensive construction
cost across Garrett Island was included as a part of the bridge
structure; and

(5) The site selected offers a through route free from the congestion of the
streets of Havre de Grace and Perryville, and yet removed from
these towns by short distances only.

The site selected requires about the same length of structure as would be
required at any other site between the railroad bridges when grade separa-
tion of railroads paralleling the river is made a part of the requirements.
The site provides excellent alignment in the completed highway, and utilizes
undeveloped or inexpensively developed properties for the right-of-way.

Complete topographical surveys have been made and permanent trian-
gulation stations, hubs and bench marks established.

BORINGS

The entire site of this bridge is underlaid with a dense gray granite known
as Port Deposit Granite as indicated by borings taken at intervals along
the center line of the bridge and as shown on Plates 4 to 10 inclusive, ‘“Gen-
eral Plan and Elevation.” The granite is covered by an overburden of sand
of varying thickness in the river channel sections and by various other strata
on the island and shore sections. The subsurface explorations indicate the

cepted by the engineering profession in connection with the long span

and in such number as to produce the maximum stress which might occur

BORINGS

The entire site of this bridge is underlaid with a dense gray granite known
as Port Deposit Granite as indicated by borings taken at intervals along
the center line of the bridge and as shown on Plates 4 to 10 inclusive, ‘“Gen-
eral Plan and Elevation.” The granite is covered by an overburden of sand
of varying thickness in the river channel sections and by various other strata

field_edited_text_processed:
20 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

advisability of using piers extending to rock except in the case of piers where
rock is excessively deep and pile foundations have been adopted. The
borings were made by driving a pipe casing to rock, removing the material
in the casing by jetting, sampling and recording the strata through which
the casing was driven, and by core drilling the bed rock a depth of 15 feet
in a majority of the holes, with 1 inch diameter diamond drills to insure
reaching solid rock and not thin ledges or boulders

The character of the rock and of the strata overlying the rock at the site
of this bridge indicates that piers can be constructed by well proven methods
involving no special difficulties.

FOUNDATIONS

After studying various methods for building the foundations for this
bridge, it was decided to use open cofferdam methods for removing the over-
burden on the rock at the site of piers to be founded on rock. The estimates
of pier costs hereinafter presented are based on the use of cofferdams, in
order that the rock foundations may be cleaned off, roughly benched, leveled
and inspected and the concrete foundations for the piers poured directly on
the prepared rock surface. Cofferdams instead of caissons seem to meet the
conditions, because the rock surface is expected to be very irregular. Such
irregularities would cause possible extra cost and delay in case caissons were
used. Due allowance has also been made in the estimates for grouting
seams and fissures. Out-crops in this granite elsewhere indicate that seams
and fissures are to be expected. It has been decided to protect the con-
crete of the river piers at the water line by band courses of rock faced granite
ashlar masonry to protect the piers against the severe ice conditions oc-
casionally occurring in the Susquehanna River. This decision was partially
influenced by the available granite quarries in the vicinity.

Where rock was found to be excessively deep, it was decided to use steel
pile foundations. Since the steel piles for these piers after being driven will
be fully supported for their full length, and will be driven to rock for end
bearing, they have been designed to carry a maximum load of 108 tons.
The capping of the piles and the construction of the remaining portions of
these pile piers will be done in a manner similar to that above deseribed for
foundations on rock, and in accordance with the plans for the piers, as shown
on Plates 12 and 13, “Typical Piers” and ‘“Typical River Piers.”

For purposes of illustration, following are Figures 2 and 3, Typical Piers
supported on rock and on steel piles, accompanied by typical design com-
putations for the two types. ;

SUPERSTRUCTURE

The superstructure for this bridge is steel throughout. Structural grade

steel will be used in all except the main channel truss units. The main

field_edited_text_processed:
26 SUSQUEHANNA RiIVER BRIDGE

channel spans over the east and west channels are each 456 feet long, flanked
with side spans 333 feet 6 inches long forming a three span continuous unit,
illustrated by Figure 7 and on Plates 3, 6 and 8. Certain of the truss mem-
bers of these units will consist of silicon alloy steel. The channel span in
each case is a through span and the side spans are part through. Other
spans in the channel sections consist of spans 261 feet 6 inches long ar-
ranged in two span continuous units, as shown in Figure 5; one such unit
over the east channel and two such units over the west channel as shown on
Plate 3. These two span continuous units are deck trusses. See Figure 4
and Plate 11. The remaining portions of the structure are deck plate
girders, or rolled beam spans. See Plate 3. As hereinbefore stated under
the description of the bridge, the girder and beam span sections of the bridge
are supported on concrete pedestals and steel bents with the concrete pedes-
tals extending up to form the bridge seat in all cases where the superstruc-
ture is to be anchored longitudinally. Typical sections of the superstruc-
ture are shown on Plate 11, “Typical Sections.”

ANALYSIS OF MAIN TRUSS SPANS

The following analysis is herein presented to show the methods used in
determining the weight of steel required in the superstructure.

General

Flooring.—The depth of the filled open mesh steel flooring is 5 inches and
the weight used in the estimate is 90 pounds per square foot, which in-
cludes an allowance for a future additional wearing surface.

Crossbeams.—The floor is supported on crossbeams spaced about 6 feet
to 6 ft. 6 in. longitudinally on centers. These beams cantilever out over
longitudinal stringers to support walkway and railing.

Longitudinal Stringers.—Four longitudinal stringers spaced 13 feet on
centers symmetrical about center line of bridge support the crossbeams.
These stringers are from 30 to 33 inches depth, and are varying weights for
different panel lengths.

Floorbeams.—The floorbeams are plate girders 54 inches back to back of
angles on 260 feet spans, and 66 inches back to back of angles on three span
continuous units.

Design.—The floor system is designed for H-20 truck loading. The dead
load of walkway, railing, curbs, etc. is 190 pounds per lineal foot, or 380
pounds per lineal foot of bridge.

fications, and to provide rigidity. The weights of the various members
were computed including lacing and 35 per cent added for details.

Shoes and Expansion Dams.—The total weight of shoes was estimated by
comparison with weights in similar trusses previously designed. The
weight of expansion dam material was calculated from the number and
length of expansion joints and unit weights of such material from pre-
viously designed trusses.

ROADWAY

The roadway for this bridge is 46 feet wide between curbs and consists of a
steel mesh type flooring, filled with concrete which, when completed, will
present the appearance of a concrete roadway surface. The weight of the
floor in the design of the bridge includes an allowance for the future addition
of 2 inches of asphalt or other wearing surface.

The plans provide for dividing the roadway into four lanes, by the con-
struction of permanent roadway markers in the surface of the roadway slab.
The central marker will be a wide white stripe, obtained by the use of white
cement and white aggregates laid monolithically with the other concrete.
This stripe will divide the bridge into lanes operating in opposite directions.
The lanes operating in the same direction will also be divided by permanent
stripes constructed in the roadway, using colored aggregates to contrast with
the color of the normal concrete. Similar stripes will also be constructed
immediately adjacent to and parallel with the curbs.

The footways for this bridge have been designed 2 feet 6 inches wide and
are intended as emergency footways only, since little if any use by pedes-
trians is to be expected.

TOLL PLAZA

The toll plaza will accommodate peak traffic loads of about 3,000 motor
vehicles per hour, on the basis of 2,000 vehicles operating in one direction and
1,000 operating in the opposite direction. These peaks are expected to occur
during the racing season at Havre de Grace and on other special occasions.
The plaza will provide six traffic lanes passing under the toll booth canopy,
and two traffic lanes passing in the clear outside of the canopy with three
toll islands, each equipped with two toll booths, making a total of six toll
booths and eight traffic lanes. The lanes outside the canopy are intended
to pass vehicles or equipment too high to clear the canopy.

field_edited_text_processed:
32 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

The plaza also includes a building for the administration of the mainte-
nance and operation of the bridge. This building is located off the toll plaza
in such location that the superintendent can continually oversee the toll
taking operations. The toll booths are designed to have complete glass
sections between the limits required for visability from one side to the other
side of the plaza. The estimates of cost for the administration building,
toll booths, toll taking equipment, and furnishings are based on the use of
the most recently developed and up-to-date toll taking recording devices,
designed for the speedy and efficient handling of traffic and the safe collec-
tion and recording of all tolls paid by the traveling public. The toll
plaza layout is shown on Plate 10, “General Plan and Elevation.”

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME OF COMPLETION

The estimated construction cost of this bridge is based on construction
beginning in December, 1938, and completion, ready for operation, in June
1940. The accompanying Plate 15, ‘“Progress Chart,” indicates in sequence
the time required for each phase of the project. Estimated construction

field_edited_text_processed:
CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME oF COMPLETION 37

costs are based on this schedule and the use of the necessary equipment to
complete the work within the time specified.

The construction procedure outlined contemplates the division of the
actual construction work into the following main contracts.

(1) Substructure

(2) Superstructure

(3) Approach Highways

(4) Toll Booths, Administration Building, Lighting, Etc.

The progress chart indicates substructure work commencing in' December,
1938, and completion in December, 1939, in order that superstructure erec-
tion beginning in October, 1939, may be completed during May, 1940.
Since the substructure and the superstructure contracts require the major
portion of the allotted time, the construction schedule for these two con-
tracts have been illustrated in detail on Plate 16, ‘“‘Construction Schedule of
Substructure and Superstructure.” This schedule contemplates the use of
two river outfits commencing work on cofferdams simultaneously, with three
land outfits commencing work on excavation for abutments and land piers.
It is contemplated that one land outfit will begin work at the west abutment
and proceed in order of completion with piers 1 to 15 inclusive, one land out-
fit working on island piers 40 to 22, and one land outfit beginning work at
east abutment and proceeding in order of completion with piers 61 to 45.
As indicated, it is contemplated that the two river outfits will proceed with
the river piers in the following order: 16 to 19; 42, 21 and 20; and 44, 43
and 41.

The schedule indicated for superstructure erection contemplates the use
of three travelers. Traveler No. 1 will begin erection at the west abutment
and proceed with erection to the closing point in the main west channel span.
Traveler No. 2 will be set up on anchor span between piers 40 and 41, pro-
ceed to the closing point in main east channel span, back up to starting point,
turn and proceed with erection across the island to closing point in main
west channel span where traveler No. 1 ended. Traveler No. 3 will begin
erection in span over Baltimore and Ohio tracks at east abutment and pro-
ceed with erection to closing point in east channel span where traveler No. 2
ended. Water delivery to traveler No. 1 is optional after reaching pier
No. 16. Water delivery to the island for traveler No. 2 is required. Water
delivery to traveler No. 3 is optional after traveler has reached a point be-
tween piers 44 and 43. As indicated by schedule, erection beginning in
October, 1939, will be completed during May, 1940. ' Floor construction on

field_edited_text_processed:
38 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

bridge will commence in January, 1940, and be completed during June,
1940. Painting will be done during months of March, April, May and June,
1940.

The contracts for Approach Highways and Toll Booths, Administration
Building, Ete. can be executed very readily, as indicated by the schedule,
during the time from September, 1939, to May, 1940, thus assuring the com-
pletion of the bridge, ready for traffic, no later than June 30, 1940.

46 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

determinate continuous truss units of this patented design will effect a
saving. The question of royalties, which the Commission might have to
pay for a license to use the patented type of trusses, will be an element in
determining possible savings.

CONCLUSIONS

The conclusions to be drawn from the foregoing report may be sum-
marized as follows:

1. The existing two lane double deck bridge is inadequate. The expendi-
ture of a large sum of money to completely rehabilitate this old structure
would still leave the problem of eliminating the circuitous route through the
developed sections of Havre de Grace and Perryville.

2. The site selected for the proposed new bridge embodies a number of
highly desirable features. It makes possible another well aligned and well
graded link in the final plan for a dual highway from Baltimore to the Dela-
ware line. It provides means for by-passing the more congested sections
of the towns of Havre de Grace and Perryville. Since it lies between the
Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad main lines, the necessity
for grade eliminations at the main line tracks is avoided. It requires a
structure of no greater length than that required at less desirable locations
and utilizes Garrett Island for a portion of the bridge crossing, making this
portion of the crossing less expensive.

3. It is proposed to provide four traffic lanes on the new bridge, four
lanes having been provided on the completed section of the Governor Nice
Highway and four lanes being proposed for the continuation and comple-
tion of this Highway to the Delaware line.

4. The total cost of this proposed bridge together with approaches,
extending from Ontario Street in Havre de Grace to the Perryville-Aiken
Road, in Cecil County, is estimated to be $4,639,000, exclusive of interest
during construction and bond discount.

5. The yearly maintenance, operation and insurance costs for this bridge
are estimated to be $62,000, not including administrative and overhead
expenses. .

6. The anticipated annual revenue from this bridge is estimated to be
$409,000 average for the first five years of operation from 1941 to 1945
if it is combined with a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay at Millers Island;
$419,000 if combined with a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay at Sandy
Point; or $448,000 if constructed as a single unit or combined with the
Patapsco and Potomac River Crossings.
field_edited_text_value:
46 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

determinate continuous truss units of this patented design will effect a
saving. The question of royalties, which the Commission might have to
pay for a license to use the patented type of trusses, will be an element in
determining possible savings.

CONCLUSIONS

The conclusions to be drawn from the foregoing report may be sum-
marized as follows:

1. The existing two lane double deck bridge is inadequate. The expendi-
ture of a large sum of money to completely rehabilitate this old structure
would still leave the problem of eliminating the circuitous route through the
developed sections of Havre de Grace and Perryville.

2. The site selected for the proposed new bridge embodies a number of
highly desirable features. It makes possible another well aligned and well
graded link in the final plan for a dual highway from Baltimore to the Dela-
ware line. It provides means for by-passing the more congested sections
of the towns of Havre de Grace and Perryville. Since it lies between the
Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad main lines, the necessity
for grade eliminations at the main line tracks is avoided. It requires a
structure of no greater length than that required at less desirable locations
and utilizes Garrett Island for a portion of the bridge crossing, making this
portion of the crossing less expensive.

3. It is proposed to provide four traffic lanes on the new bridge, four
lanes having been provided on the completed section of the Governor Nice
Highway and four lanes being proposed for the continuation and comple-
tion of this Highway to the Delaware line.

4. The total cost of this proposed bridge together with approaches,
extending from Ontario Street in Havre de Grace to the Perryville-Aiken
Road, in Cecil County, is estimated to be $4,639,000, exclusive of interest
during construction and bond discount.

5. The yearly maintenance, operation and insurance costs for this bridge
are estimated to be $62,000, not including administrative and overhead
expenses. .

6. The anticipated annual revenue from this bridge is estimated to be
$409,000 average for the first five years of operation from 1941 to 1945
if it is combined with a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay at Millers Island;
$419,000 if combined with a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay at Sandy
Point; or $448,000 if constructed as a single unit or combined with the
Patapsco and Potomac River Crossings.

field_edited_text_processed:
Patapsco River Crossing





SITE OF THE CROSSING

THE delay, congestion, and indirect routing of motor traffic through the
the City of Baltimore is notorious throughout the eastern part of the United
States. Various plans for by-passing the City have been considered.
Several of these plans have involved a by-pass to the north and west of the
City. Ways and means for financing such a by-pass have not been de-
veloped. There is at present no means provided for motor vehicular
traffic to move from the extreme southeast portions of the City to the
northeast portions of the City, except by traveling parallel to the river,
crossing on the existing Hanover Street Bridge, and then around the head
of the inner harbor.

The proposed crossing at the site selected not only will serve as a by-pass
for through north and south traffic, but will also serve to accommodate
local traffic between the industrial areas along the north and south banks
of the Patapsco River extending southeastward from the Hanover Street
Bridge. This bridge will be the only crossing over the Patapsco River,
which now divides the industrial areas of the City and the port develop-
ments along each bank of the river. By accommodating this local traffic
between the industrial areas, the proposed bridge at this site will help to
relieve the present and growing congestion on the Hanover Street Bridge
and on the east-west streets in the City of Baltimore, lying between Pratt
Street and the Orleans Street Viaduct.

At the present time all motor vehicular traffic originating in Baltimore
and to the North is obliged to pass through the streets of down town Balti-
more and over the Hanover Street Bridge Route to reach Anne Arundel
County, Annapolis and Southern Maryland generally. The new modern
dual highway, between the cities of Baltimore and Annapolis, has induced
additional traffic to use this route. By accommodating a portion of this
traffic between Southern Maryland and the City of Baltimore the proposed
bridge at the Canton-Fairfield Site will help to relieve the present and
growing congestion on the Hanover Street Bridge Route.

47

SITE OF THE CROSSING

THE delay, congestion, and indirect routing of motor traffic through the

At the present time all motor vehicular traffic originating in Baltimore
and to the North is obliged to pass through the streets of down town Balti-
more and over the Hanover Street Bridge Route to reach Anne Arundel
County, Annapolis and Southern Maryland generally. The new modern

47

field_edited_text_processed:
48 Patrarsco RivER CROSSING

In addition to serving the local traffic described above, and in addition
to relieving the traffic congestion on the Hanover Street Bridge caused by
the fact that the Hanover Street Bridge forms a main outlet from Baltimore
to the southern part of the State, a crossing of the Patapsco River at the
site selected will form a link to connect the existing new Governor Nice
Highway with the new Governor Ritchie Highway to Annapolis, with
Southern Maryland routes and with the existing Baltimore-Washington
Boulevard, thus forming a by-pass for the traffic now using these main
arterial routes into the City without forcing such traffic to pass through the
streets of the city. The congestion on the Hanover Street Bridge is ag-
gravated by the interruption caused when the bascule span in this bridge
is raised to allow ships to pass through into the northwest branch of Balti-
more’s Harbor.

There are other sites where a possible crossing of the Patapsco River
might serve as a relief to the dense traffic now crossing the Hanover Street
Bridge. Several sites for such a crossing have been studied. The proposed
site between Canton and Fairfield was selected as preferable to any of the
other sites studied and surveyed for the following reasons:

(1) The distance between the pier head lines in the river, established by
the United States War Department at the proposed site between Canton
and Fairfield, is shorter than at any other point across the river southeast
of this proposed site, thus providing the most economical crossing of the
river.

(2) The proposed site is more than two miles from the center of the
Municipal Airport. Any location selected for this crossing southeast of
the site proposed would involve a longer crossing and would interfere with
the free use of the airport by being located too close to it.

(3) It has been previously suggested, and an engineering report has been
prepared, for a bridge from the foot of Broadway, in Baltimore, to Locust
Point. Such a crossing would serve only such portion of traffic now con-
gesting the east-west streets between Pratt Street and the Orleans Street
Viaduect as is destined from the Locust Point area to points in East Balti-
more, and would in no way serve to relieve the Hanover Street Bridge route
for traffic originating or destined for any point south of the Hanover Street
Bridge in the Fairfield-Curtis Bay area or further south in the Counties of
the State.

In order to make such a crossing valuable for handling of this traffic,
another bridge across the main branch of the Patapsco River extending

In addition to serving the local traffic described above, and in addition
to relieving the traffic congestion on the Hanover Street Bridge caused by
the fact that the Hanover Street Bridge forms a main outlet from Baltimore
to the southern part of the State, a crossing of the Patapsco River at the

(1) The distance between the pier head lines in the river, established by

(3) It has been previously suggested, and an engineering report has been

Point. Such a crossing would serve only such portion of traffic now con-
gesting the east-west streets between Pratt Street and the Orleans Street

more, and would in no way serve to relieve the Hanover Street Bridge route
for traffic originating or destined for any point south of the Hanover Street
Bridge in the Fairfield-Curtis Bay area or further south in the Counties of
the State.

In order to make such a crossing valuable for handling of this traffic,
another bridge across the main branch of the Patapsco River extending

field_edited_text_processed:
SITE OoF THE CROSSING 49

south from the Locust Point area to the Brooklyn or Fairfield area would
be necessary. A crossing of both the northwest and main branches of the
Patapsco River would parallel the Hanover Street Bridge route, and would
relieve the traffic on said route, but would serve no purpose for connecting
the arterial routes which the crossing at the proposed site between Canton
and Fairfield will connect, namely: U. S. Route No. 40 and U. S. Route
No. 1 to the northeast, and State Routes Nos. 2 and 3 and U. S. Route No. 1
to the south and southwest. Furthermore, the bridge across the main
branch of the Patapsco River from the Locust Point area to the south bank
would involve a crossing at least as long and as expensive as the proposed
bridge between Canton and Fairfield, without considering the cost of the
crossing from the foot of Broadway to Locust Point. The two bridges
required for this crossing would cost a great deal more than the single
bridge proposed; and, as stated above, it would serve no purpose whatever
as a by-pass for through traffic. Its only advantage over that proposed
would be the accommodation of traffic into and out of the Locust Point
area destined for either the eastern section of the City of Baltimore or the
Canton-Fairfield area.

(4) The traffic surveys prepared in connection with Maryland’s Primary
Bridge Program show that the Hanover Street Bridge route carries the
greatest volume of traffic of any arterial route entering the City of Balti-
more. The congestion on this route during the hours of peak traffic volume
is gradually increasing to the point where public demand will insist upon
the construction of a new Patapsco River crossing to afford relief. The
necessity for such a crossing for the relief of the traffic congestion on the
Hanover Street Bridge route, when coupled with the enormous traffic value
which a crossing at this site will have as a by-pass and relief of traffic con-
gestion in the City streets named above, make this site the most advanta-
geous of any of the sites studied and surveyed for this crossing.

(5) Through-motorists from the City of Washington and Maryland’s
neighboring states avoid Baltimore whenever it is possible to do so. As
an illustration, it has been reported that the various travel bureaus have
frequently routed motorists from Philadelphia to Washington by way of
U. S. Route No. 30 through Gettysburg and thence to Washington in order
to avoid Maryland roads and particularly the congestion in Baltimore’s
streets.

The proposed crossing at this site, in conjunction with the new modern
highways recently completed and now under construction, will become a

field_edited_text_processed:
50 PaTarsco R1ivEr CROSSING

big factor in changing the attitude of the motoring public toward the use of
the Maryland Highways and toward the passage through the City.

For location of approach and connecting highways see Plate 17, “Vicinity
Map.”

(6) A study of the ‘“‘Baltimore City map,” Plate 18, shows that the in-
tersection and grade separation between the proposed northern approach
to this bridge and the Philadelphia Road is located at the existing inter-
section of the Philadelphia Road and Erdman Avenue. Erdman Avenue
extends northwest from the Philadelphia Road, crosses the Bel Air Road,
and intersects the Harford Road at a point in the vicinity of Lake Monte-
bello. This avenue, therefore, intercepts three important arterial routes
leading into the City, and would form an excellent beginning for a possible
future circumferential route passing around the outskirts of the City and
intercepting all of the radial routes leading intp the City, including the
York Road, Reisterstown Road, Liberty Road, Frederick Road, and finally
the Baltimore-Washington Boulevard. If the southern approach from the
Baltimore-Washington Boulevard to the proposed bridge were located as
proposed at a point near Elkridge, the logical point for the above mentioned
possible future circumferential route to intersect the Baltimore-Washington
Boulevard would be in the same vicinity. It can thus be seen that the
proposed bridge and its approaches, when extended to intersect with the
Philadelphia Road on the northeast and with the Baltimore-Washington
Boulevard on the southwest, together with the existing Erdman Avenue
as far as the Harford Road, could be a major beginning of a possible com-
plete circumferential route around the outskirts of Baltimore and inter-
secting all radial routes into the City, as shown on map of ‘“Baltimore and
Vicinity,” Fig. 8. '

TUNNEL VERSUS BRIDGE

The statements hereinbefore made with respect to the advantages of this
site for a crossing of the Patapsco River apply equally whether a tunnel or
a bridge is used. Either a tunnel or a bridge is feasible at this site from an
engineering standpoint, insofar as the actual construction of either of these
facilities is involved. The characteristics of the sub-strata as indicated
by the borings at this site lend themselves admirably to the construction of
a tunnel, and present no difficulties in the construction of a bridge. The
estimates of cost show that a two lane tunnel will cost 459, more than the
proposed four lane bridge will cost. Comparisons of tunnel and bridge

field_edited_text_processed:
TuNNEL VERSUS BRIDGE 53

estimates at sites where one or another has been constructed across the
waterways of the United States indicate that tunnels, in general, will cost
from two and one quarter to four times as much as bridges will cost per
lane of traffic.

It has been estimated that a two lane tunnel will carry about 6,500,000
vehicles per year, although a two lane highway will carry only about 4,000-
000 vehicles per year. The explanation for the increased capacity of a
tunnel is the control over traffic maintained in the case of tunnel traffic.
If many high peak traffic periods are to be expected, and if there are periods
of low traffic volume, even the control maintained over tunnel traffic would
make it impossible to handle 6,500,000 vehicles per year, and the tunnel
capacity would therefore be reduced. In the case of the Patapsco River
Crossing, the holiday and weekend peaks, and the relative low traffic volume
at certain times would most probably materially reduce the total annual
volume which could be handled through a two lane tube below the 6,500,000
vehicles estimated.

The Holland Tunnels in New York, which are parallel two lane tubes,
one operated in one direction and the other in the opposite direction, have
about reached their capacity, and in the year 1937 handled approximately
14,000,000 vehicles. A four lane bridge, controlled as the proposed bridge
at this site will be controlled, will be capable of carrying a volume of about
the same numer of vehicles, namely, 14,000,000. These statements show
that a four lane bridge will carry considerably more than twice as much
traffic as can be carried by a two lane tunnel. ' '

It is impossible to foretell the date when the full capacity of a tunnel
will be reached, and when it will be necessary for the State to consider the
construction of an additional parallel tube, in order to accommodate the
traffic using this crossing. However, under the method of financing pro-
posed for this program the construction of an additional tube at any time be-
fore the bond issue, under which the present program is financed, has been
amortized, involves serious disadvantages and difficulties. It is obvious
that it would be impossible to charge tolls on a tunnel carrying traffic in
one direction and allow the previously constructed tunnel carrying traffic
in the opposite direction to be operated as a free facility. The above state-
ments stress the many advantages which a bridge at this site has over a
tunnel. ,

In addition to the difference in cost, as shown in the accompanying es-
timates, the annual expense for maintaining and operating a tunnel is con-

tunnel is the control over traffic maintained in the case of tunnel traffic.
If many high peak traffic periods are to be expected, and if there are periods
of low traffic volume, even the control maintained over tunnel traffic would
make it impossible to handle 6,500,000 vehicles per year, and the tunnel
capacity would therefore be reduced. In the case of the Patapsco River
Crossing, the holiday and weekend peaks, and the relative low traffic volume
at certain times would most probably materially reduce the total annual
volume which could be handled through a two lane tube below the 6,500,000
vehicles estimated.

The Holland Tunnels in New York, which are parallel two lane tubes,
one operated in one direction and the other in the opposite direction, have
about reached their capacity, and in the year 1937 handled approximately
14,000,000 vehicles. A four lane bridge, controlled as the proposed bridge
at this site will be controlled, will be capable of carrying a volume of about
the same numer of vehicles, namely, 14,000,000. These statements show
that a four lane bridge will carry considerably more than twice as much
traffic as can be carried by a two lane tunnel. ' '

It is impossible to foretell the date when the full capacity of a tunnel
will be reached, and when it will be necessary for the State to consider the
construction of an additional parallel tube, in order to accommodate the
traffic using this crossing. However, under the method of financing pro-
posed for this program the construction of an additional tube at any time be-
fore the bond issue, under which the present program is financed, has been
amortized, involves serious disadvantages and difficulties. It is obvious
that it would be impossible to charge tolls on a tunnel carrying traffic in
one direction and allow the previously constructed tunnel carrying traffic
in the opposite direction to be operated as a free facility. The above state-
ments stress the many advantages which a bridge at this site has over a
tunnel. ,

In addition to the difference in cost, as shown in the accompanying es-
timates, the annual expense for maintaining and operating a tunnel is con-

field_edited_text_processed:
54 Pararsco RivEr CROSSING

siderably greater than similar expense for a bridge. The items of expense
for maintaining and operating a tunnel include continuous twenty-four
hour lighting, continuous operation of ventilation equipment to remove
automobile exhaust fumes, continuous availability of fire extinguishing
equipment in order to prevent a catastrophe in the tunnel, continuous avail-
ability of wrecking equipment in order to clear a traffic lane in case of
breakdown, and continuous patrolling and policing in order to maintain
constant communication with the fire protection and wrecking equipment.
These items of maintenance and operation expense would not be required
for a bridge.

field_edited_text_processed:
NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS 55

From the high point in the main span over the channel, the bridge and
approaches descend on 4 per cent grades in both directions, so that at the
north pierhead line a vertical clearance of 149 feet is provided, and at the
south pierhead line a vertical clearance of 91 feet is provided.

The main cantilever unit is comprised of a main river span 1224 feet long,
flanked on each side by anchor spans 668 feet long. The 2180 feet of spans
approaching the main cantilever unit from the south are two spans of 350
feet, two spans of 480 feet, and one span of 520 feet. The 2050 feet of
bridge approaching the main cantilever unit from the north is comprised of
one span of 520 feet, one of 480 feet and three of 350 feet. The main can-
tilever unit and side spans are shown in perspective on Plate 20.

The roadway is 46 feet wide between curbs, to accommodate four lanes
of traffic with two emergency footways, each 1 foot 6 inches wide. The
vertical curve over the main channel is 1534 feet long, and provides a
minimum sight distance of 875 feet. The alignment is straight, except for
a 3 degree and 30 minute curve immediately south of Boston Street.

The bridge has been designed for Standard H-20 loading, in accordance
with the Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges, adopted and pub-
lished by the American Highway Officials Association in 1935, except for
slight modifications, which are made necessary because the above named
specifications are intended to cover span lengths of 300 feet or less only.
The design of long span highway bridges involves the use of special design
provisions which have not been published as standard, but which have been
accepted by the engineering profession in connection with the long span
bridges recently built in this country.

The Standard H-20 loading referred to above is intended to provide for
trucks with maximum loads of 20 tons, placed anywhere on the roadway,
and in such number as to produce the maximum stress which might occur
in any member of the bridge or portion of the structure.

NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS

since the year 1881, have been 600 feet wide. For 33 years, since 1905,
- these channels have been 35 feet deep. In 1929 other improvements to
the main ship channels, consisting principally of widening turns, etc., were
effected.

District Engineer of Baltimore, the Export and Import Bureau of the

District Engineer of Baltimore, the Export and Import Bureau of the

field_edited_text_processed:
56 Paraprsco River CROSSING

Baltimore Association of Commerce recommended the following harbor
improvements:—

a. The widening of the channel from Sandy Point to Fort McHenry

from 600 feet to 1000 feet.

b. The widening of the Port Covington channel from 400 feet to 600 feet.

c¢. The widening of the Curtis Bay channel from 400 feet to 600 feet.

The following deepening was also recommended :—

a. The deepening of the main channel from Sandy Point to Sparrows

Point from 37 feet to 40 feet.

b. From Sparrows Point to Fort McHenry from 35 feet to 38 feet—40 feet.

Additional anchorages were recommended as follows:—An extension
of the existing River View anchorage 1500 feet x 4500 feet which will double
the size of the existing anchorage, making a new anchorage 1500 feet x 9000
feet. The old portion of this anchorage to be deepened to 38 feet-40 feet,
and the new portion to be dredged to this new deepened depth.

The section of the channel as it exists at the present time, between the
northwesterly end of the existing River View anchorage and Fort McHenry,
1s 1000 feet wide. At Fort McHenry the channel branches with one section
extending northerly into the northwest branch, and the other section ex-
tends westerly to Port Covington.

The Export and Import Bureau has made no request for widening the
northwest channel. This may be because of the location of Fort McHenry
which does not lend itself to commercial or pier development and will for
all time, be held more or less sacred to Baltimoreans and to the country as
a whole, with opposition against dredging operations which might tend to
the possible injury of this historic point. The channel opposite Fort
MecHenry is only 910 feet wide, being limited on the east by the pierhead
line in the vicinity of Lazaretto light. Since it is most unlikely that dredg-
ing operations will be conducted on the west side of this northwest entrance
in the vicinity of Fort McHenry, where no commercial developments are
practicable, the entrance to the northwest branch is limited to its present
910 feet width. TFederal jurisdiction over the channels in this port ends at
this point.

The recent widening and deepening of the C&D Canal has effected mate-
rial changes in the channels leading into Baltimore. In addition to the
improvements listed, as recommended by the Association of Commerce,
the Association also recommended a proposed new short cut channel to
connect Brewerton channel with the natural eastern ship channel of the

the Association also recommended a proposed new short cut channel to
connect Brewerton channel with the natural eastern ship channel of the

field_edited_text_processed:
NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS 57

Chespeake Bay. This recommendation was made in order to accommodate
the large volume of shipping which is expected to use the C&D Canal,
destined for Baltimore and for points farther south in the Chesapeake Bay.
The channel proposed by the Association was to have been 400 feet wide,
dredged to 27 feet-30 feet in depth.

The proposed bridge structure crosses the main ship channel between
Canton and Fairfield at a point immediately southeast of the intersection
of the Northwest Branch Channel and the Port Covington Channel. The
point where this bridge crosses the channel is 3380 feet from the end of the
Federal Channel into the Northwest Branch, and is 2.6 miles from the
‘westerly end of the Port Covington Channel now maintained by the Federal
Government. '

The distance from the existing entrance to the Craig Hill Channel south
of the Baltimore Light to Fort McHenry is 18 miles and the distance from
this entrance to the bridge crossing is 17.3 miles. It is therefore obvious
that the proposed bridge affects movements in the Upper Harbor only and
harbor movement into the Northwest Branch and Port Covington Channel
which serve the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the Pennsylvania Rail-
road Piers in one case, The McComas Street Terminal and Port Covington
Terminal of the Western Maryland Railway in the other case.

Study showed that a vertical clearance of 175 feet would be ample for
any ship which could be navigated or turned around in Baltimore Harbor
above this site. Available records indicate that there are approximately
twenty super-liners, the masts of which would not clear this proposed ver-
tical clearance. These records show also that the funnels of all ships, in-
cluding super-liners, would clear this height. Ships of these great heights
would range from 750 feet to 1100 feet in length whereas the longest ship
recorded to have entered Baltimore Harbor is less than 600 feet in length.

The entire United States Navy, it is reported, could pass under this
bridge if there were sufficient water depths beyond, for the reason that it
has been the practice, during the past fifty years of Naval construction, to
design all Naval craft to clear the Brooklyn Bridge over the East River in
New York Harbor, which has a vertical clearance of 135 feet.

The vertical clearance provided at other points between the pierhead
lines are more than ample to provide vertical clearances for craft with
limited draft capable of plying the shallow water on each side of the main
channel.

AVIATION CONSIDERATIONS

The center line of the proposed bridge is more than two miles from the
center of the Municipal Airport, as shown on the accompanying chart,
“Baltimore Harbor and Airport Map”” Plate 19. The highest points in the
proposed bridge are the cantilever towers over the main channel piers,
which are 337 feet high above the water, and a line from the top of these
towers to the center of the airport would have a slope of 1-34.

The Maryland Law provides that the slope of the line to the nearest
established perimeter of an airport from the top of any structure within
5000 feet of such airport, shall not be steeper than 1-15. It therefore
appears that, in the first place, the bridge is located nearly a mile outside
the protected area; and, in the second place, even if the protected area were
extended to include the bridge, the bridge towers are only about half as
high as they could be under the established legal gradient of 1-15. The
grain elevators of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, located little more
than one mile from the airport and costing about $8,000,000 at the time
they were constructed, are 221 feet high and have a slope of 1-39 from the
top of the elevators to the center of the airport, or a slope of 1-28 to the
nearest runway of the airport. If a gliding angle or gradient of 1-20 to the
nearest runway were established for the Baltimore City Municipal Airport,
the top of the bridge towers would be 134 feet below such gradient, and the
grain elevators would be 91 feet below such gradient. Two obstructions to
aviation in the vieinity of the airport are smoke stacks, one of which forms
a gradient of 1-16 from the top to the nearest runway, and the other a
gradient of 1-73.

and is herein presented as a matter of reference. The report was made on
August 27, 1938 to the State Roads Commission by Mr. Charles F. Thomp-
son, President of Thompson Airways, Inc.

imately two miles from the center of the Baltimore Municipal Airport.

THE PATAPSCO RIVER BRIDGE
' AND
ITS RELATION TO AERIAL NAVIGATION
IN CONNECTION WITH
THE BALTIMORE CITY MUNICIPAL AIRPORT

““The Patapsco River Bridge, one of the proposed bridges in Maryland’s
Primary Bridge Program is located in Baltimore Harbor at a point approx-
imately two miles from the center of the Baltimore Municipal Airport.

field_edited_text_processed:
AviaTioON CONSIDERATIONS 59

There are certain points and facts pertinent to the effect that this proposed
bridge will or will not have, on air commerce using this airport.

“Water areas adjacent to the airport are at present being used for the
operation of seaplanes. The location of the proposed bridge will un-
doubtedly be somewhat of a detriment to the use of the upper Patapsco
River for seaplane operation. This part of the river would also offer further
hazards by the presence of floating debris and the movement of many
large ships, small craft and ships in the anchorage basins.

“It is the present plan of the U. S. Government to prohibit the operation
of large seaplanes in the Patapsco River. In the near future, all seaplane
operations must necessarily be confined to a designated area to be layed out
by the Civil Aeronautics Authority. Such a restricted area south of the
airport is proposed for seaplanes operating in and out of Baltimore, and this
area is to be patrolled in order to insure that this area will be clear at all
times for taking off and landing. The regulations proposed will also pro-
hibit the use of any of the buoyed ship channels for take offs and landings,
which might cross the channels. This proposed seaplane area is located as
follows: From the southwestern tip of the airport to the F. L. R. “10 M”’
buoy, thence down the left side of the Fort McHenry Channel to the chan-
nel leading into Sparrows Point, thence up the left side of this channel to
the S. T. K. “S-5" buoy, then in a north-westerly direction to Sollers Point
Pier and thence to the airport. An official of the Civil Aeronautics Author-
ity, in charge of seaplane operations, states that a 41 mile straight-away
will be required for the transatlantic seaplanes now under construction and
those to be constructed in the near future. This 4% mile straight-away will
be separated into three units. The first mile and one-half being for take
off ; the next mile for acceleration; and the next two miles for climb. The
Authority claims that the ships used for long range flying will have obtained
an altitude of not more than 350 feet at the completion of the 4% mile
stretch. 'This i1s due to the heavy loads. Thus the Airport, situated as it
is, is adjacent to but one area or course available for these 4} mile take offs.
This course is in a south-easterly direction and would require very little
taxying. The bridge would therefore be no hazard to a plane using this
direction or course.

“The proposed long range flying boats will be required to taxi to an area
below Sparrows Point before enough open water is available for a take off.
Certainly from this point a proposed bridge would be no more of a hazard
to these large planes than other hazards in the industrial and commercial
districts adjacent to the bridge. It would be a very dangerous practice to

stretch. 'This i1s due to the heavy loads. Thus the Airport, situated as it
is, is adjacent to but one area or course available for these 4} mile take offs.
This course is in a south-easterly direction and would require very little
taxying. The bridge would therefore be no hazard to a plane using this
direction or course.

“The proposed long range flying boats will be required to taxi to an area
below Sparrows Point before enough open water is available for a take off.
Certainly from this point a proposed bridge would be no more of a hazard
to these large planes than other hazards in the industrial and commercial
districts adjacent to the bridge. It would be a very dangerous practice to

field_edited_text_processed:
AviaTioN CONSIDERATIONS 61

the minimum height to bank long before the bridge is reached. The law
requires that instrument flights shall be conducted 1000 feet above the
ground or any obstructions, and therefore during blind flying, the bridge
will in no way become a hazard. The law further states that no flights
within the controlled zone shall be made where the ceiling is less than 500
feet or where visibility is less than one mile. Under such conditions the
towers of the bridge would be visible to the pilot.

““The main channel span of the proposed bridge is designed with two
towers, each extending 337 feet above mean low water. A line extending
from the top of these towers to the nearest run-way on the airport estab-
lishes a gradient of 28 to 1. The Civil Aeronautics Authority requires
that all obstructions adjacent to an airport must be below a gradient of
20 to 1 from all sides of the airport. An official of the Authority in charge
of the airport inspection for land plane operations has stated that the pro-
posed location of the bridge will not interfere with airplanes using the
Baltimore Municipal Airport. Government requirements provide control
over the area within a radius of 11 miles from the center of the Airport.
The nearest part of the proposed bridge will be located more than 2 miles
from the center of the airport and the entire bridge runs almost parallel
to the nearest side of the airport.

“There are certain obstructions at present which will offer more of a
hazard to planes approaching and taking off from the airport than the
proposed bridge. The Pennsylvania Railroad Grain Elevator is located
at a distance of approximately 6,240 feet from the nearest run-way and in
the direction of the bridge. A line from the top of this elevator to the air-
port makes a gradient of 1 to 28, which is the same as for the bridge towers.
This grain elevator has a value of about $8,500,000.00. The power house
of the Western Electric Company is 3,740 feet from the northwest end of
the northwest-southeast run-way, and it makes a gradient to the airport
of 1 to 16.

“The stack of the Chemical and Pigment Company is 1520 feet from the
north end of the north-south runway, and the gradient from its top to the
runway 1s 1 to 73. A gliding angle of 1 to 20 will clear the bridge towers
by 134 feet and will clear the grain elevator by 91 feet. On the other hand,
the Western Electric stack will project 50 feet above a 1 to 20 gliding angle,
and the Chemical and Pigment Company’s stack will project 138 feet above
a 1 to 20 gliding angle.

‘““Also, the bridge actually subtends an angle of 30° in azimuth from the

‘““Also, the bridge actually subtends an angle of 30° in azimuth from the

field_edited_text_processed:
62 Pararsco River CROSSING

airport. This 30° in azimuth includes the entire length of the bridge.
The angle in azimuth between the towers from the airport is only 7°, com-
pared to 50° for the other obstacles herein named. The maximum ob-
struction, of course, is the central portion, including the towers over the
main channel piers, but since the grades of the bridge descend from these
points, it is obvious that the part of the bridge on the ascending grades
present no greater hazard than the other buildings in this locality. The
City of Baltimore has no intention of condemning or destroying the build-
ings in Canton and Fairfield which offer as much obstruction to the use of
airplanes as the proposed bridge approaches, because these buildings are
worth many millions of dollars.

“Land planes are required to take off within 1000 feet in standard calm
air at sea level, and shall climb in feet the first minute after leaving the
ground at least eight times the measured power-on stalling speed in miles
per hour. Therefore, the ships most commonly used in airlines would have
attained an altitude of over 1000 feet before reaching the bridge—if headed
in that direction. Seaplanes are required to take off from the water at
sea level in 45 seconds or less, with a wind velocity not exceeding ten miles
per hour under moderately smooth water conditions, and shall climb in
feet the first minute after leaving the water at least six times the measured
power—on stalling speed in miles per hour. Therefore, the ships that are
in use today would be 1000 feet above the bridge, providing the take off
was from the proposed area south of the airport and headed toward the
bridge.

“The above statement, referring to seaplanes, will be somewhat changed
in order to take care of the future ships that will be in Trans-atlantic
service.

“A blind landing strip on the present airport will run north and south,
and a radio control station is now being constructed at Hawkins Point.
Land planes approaching for blind landings will use the north-south strip
which is almost parallel to the bridge and at a distance of approximately
2 miles from the bridge. Should an unsuccessful approach to the field
necessitate circling, an airplane must continue on a straight flight until an
altitude of 1000 feet has been reached. It must then make a left turn or
approximately 180 degrees into the approach zone. During this operation,
the plane would be 663 feet above the highest point on the proposed bridge.
A study of the airport plan indicates that the runways are so laid out that a
land plane will be able at all times to take off in eight directions without
passing over any portion of the bridge.

field_edited_text_processed:
AvVIATION CONSIDERATIONS 63

““An airplane taking off from the airport should not fly over any congested
harbor or built-up area of the city until it has attained sufficient altitude
for safety. Air regulations require that when flying over the congested
area of cities, towns or settlements, sufficient altitude should be maintained
in order to permit the possibility of an emergency landing at any time out-
side of these areas in the event of complete motor failure, but in no case is
an airplane allowed to operate at less than 1000 feet above the ground over
these areas. To comply with this restriction, it would be necessary that
an airplane should circle the field after a take off in order to attain this 1000
feet altitude before continuing its flight. The bridge is located in such a
built-up area and would therefore be automatically eliminated as a hazard.

“Engineers tell us that the science of aeronautics has just begun to un-
fold its infinite possibilities and in order to serve the increasing needs of
aviation, it is clear that as the size of seaplanes is increased, they will need
more and greater areas of unobstructed water to provide them with miles
of straight aways in all directions to make it possible for them to take off
with their heavy loads. To provide this adequate space, it will be neces-
sary to utilize larger water areas such as that south of Sparrows Point.

64 Paraprsco River CrossiNGg

“The Martin 130 China Clipper was looked upon two years ago as a
marvel. Its gross weight was 52,000 pounds. A year later came the Mar-
tin 157-F with a weight of 70,000 pounds. Today, we have the new Boeing
314, with a weight of 82,500 pounds and in the very near future flying boats
will be constructed by Consolidated, Sikorsky, and others, weighing more
than 100,000 pounds. The gross weight having doubled in the last two
years, we can therefore look forward to the construction of even larger
seaplanes. It is safe to say that we do not know what to predict for the
next five years, except that the trend seems to be upward as far as size and
weights are concerned. Obviously not one of these enormous seaplanes of
the future could be used in the waters adjacent to the Baltimore Municipal
Airport. Whether or not the bridge is built, large areas of open water must
be used for the navigation of these super-airliners to insure the safety of
passengers and property. Baltimore is so located that perfect facilities for
the seaplanes of today and tomorrow can be found in the open waters just
off Sparrows Point.

“From the foregoing, it is evident that the operation of seaplanes will
always be restricted to areas sufficiently removed from the bridge site,
and due to the fact that the bridge will be located well within the built-up
areas of the city, it can not offer any obstruction to the operation of land
planes, which are required to use the run-ways of the Baltimore Munic-
ipal Airport and operate under the regulations of the Civil Aeronautics
Authority.”

August 27, 1938.

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED TUNNEL

The tunnel considered as a vehicular crossing at this site is shown on
Tunnel Studies, Plates 48,49 and 50. Two methods for the construction of
this tunnel were considered, the first involved the use of the Shield Method,
shown on Tunnel Study Number 1, Plate 49, and the other, the Open Trench
Method, shown on Tunnel Study Number 2, Plate 50. The completed tun-
nels in either case would have identically the same appearance from the road-
way. The difference between the two is in the type of construction of the
structural tube itself. Studies made by Mr. Ole Singstad showed that the
latter type of construction was the more economical of the two, and the
description herein will refer to the latter, Tunnel Study Number 2, Plate 50.

The tunnel is designed to carry two lanes of traffic, with a 22 feet wide

field_edited_text_processed:

roadway, and one walkway, with the section of structural concrete floor
slab, and exhaust and fresh air ducts as shown on the drawing. The clear-
ance below mean low water provided beneath the ship channel is 53 feet,
and the clearance at each of the pierhead lines is 44 feet, with approaches
rising toward the shores from these points at the rate of 3% per cent grades.
These conditions require a total length between portals of 7110 feet, of
which the Open Trench Tunnel construction would occupy 6140 feet, and
the ventilating shafts and standard subway construction would occupy the
remaining 970 feet.

The Fairfield open cut approach to reach the existing ground surface
would be 740 feet long, and the similar approach in Canton would be 760
feet long. The entire length of the tunnel between the ends of the open
cut approaches is 8610 feet. The estimates of cost include the ventilating
buildings, ventilation equipment, interior finish and trim, and all structural
portions of the completed tunnel between the limits above described. In
addition to the actual tunnel, the approaches to connect it with the points
used as the limits for the bridge and its approaches proposed at this site,
would have to be extended for a distance of 6350 feet on the Canton side,
and a distance of 4690 feet on the Fairfield side, in order to make up a total
distance of 19,650 feet for the limits of construction in the case of the tunnel
and 19,020 feet for the bridge.

The estimates of cost of the tunnel, include also the approaches from the
intersection of Quail and Boston Streets to the tunnel plaza in Canton and
from the intersection of Patapsco Avenue and Shell Road near Pennington
Avenue to the tunnel plaza in Fairfield. Mr. Ole Singstad, Consult-
ing Engineer of New York City, prepared the Tunnel Studies and esti-
mates shown on Plates 48, 49, and 50, in collaboration with J. E. Greiner
Company.

TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS

The topographical and other surveys required for the Patapsco River
Crossing consist of the following:

Location of the Main Bridge Crossing.—As previously described under
“Site of the Crossing,” the approximate location of the crossing was defi-
nitely fixed. It was necessary to establish exactly the alignment of the
bridge, whereby the bridge and its approaches could be constructed between
the limits of the ends of the project, without interfering seriously with any
property in Canton or Fairfield. This proposed alignment also made it
