TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS

The topographical and other surveys required for the Patapsco River
Crossing consist of the following:

Location of the Main Bridge Crossing.—As previously described under
“Site of the Crossing,” the approximate location of the crossing was defi-
nitely fixed. It was necessary to establish exactly the alignment of the
bridge, whereby the bridge and its approaches could be constructed between
the limits of the ends of the project, without interfering seriously with any
property in Canton or Fairfield. This proposed alignment also made it

field_edited_text_processed:
66 Patarsco RivEr CROSSING

possible to construct the project on a tangent between Shell Road and
Patapsco Avenue in Fairfield, and Ponca Street near Holabird Avenue in
Canton. From this point in Canton the only curve on the project con-
nected this long tangent with the terminal intersection at Boston Street.

Triangulation of Control Points in Canton and Fairfield.—After establish-
ing the center line of the main crossing, large target towers were erected on
the center line near the shores in Canton and Fairfield. These targets were
easily visible across the mile of open water at the site. Hubs were estab-
lished between these targets and the shore line for triangulation procedure.
The City of Baltimore has a very complete triangulation network, and it
was found advisable to use this network of triangulation points to tie in
with the survey for the bridge. The U. S. Army Engineers have also es-
tablished a triangulation network, and it was necessary to coordinate this
network with the City network, in order to establish the pierhead, bulk-
head, and channel range lines in relation to the center line stations on the
bridge. The hubs established on the Canton and Fairfield shores were
triangulated in from a station on Fort McHenry, and the distance between
them was computed. In addition to the coordination of the surveys for
this crossing with those hereinbefore named, the entire survey system is
coordinated with and tied into the U. S. Coast and Geodetic Survey herein
described under ‘“Engineering Procedure.”

Soundings of the Patapsco River Along the Center Line.—A complete set
of sounding equipment was next assembled, and centerline soundings were
taken from a boat at approximately 20 feet intervals. The boat was kept
on the center line by means of ranges. Through a system of signals, the
exact location of each sounding was fixed by an angle reading cut in with
a transit located at Fort McHenry. The distances along the center line
were then computed, and the profile of the river bottom plotted.

Reconnaissance and Preliminary Topographical Surveys on Several Pro-
Jected Lines for the Faurfield Approach between the Patapsco River and the
City Limits.—The terminus of the bridge proper in Fairfield was definitely
established, but it was difficult to decide upon a line for the continuation of
the approach to connect with the proposed extension to Elkridge at the
City limits near Church Street. Several lines were run from Chesapeake
Street to the City limits with various studies being made for a crossing over
or under the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks near Patapsco Avenue and
the proper intersection at Pennington and Patapsco Avenues. It was
finally decided to continue the tangent of the bridge and to terminate the
field_edited_text_value:
66 Patarsco RivEr CROSSING

possible to construct the project on a tangent between Shell Road and
Patapsco Avenue in Fairfield, and Ponca Street near Holabird Avenue in
Canton. From this point in Canton the only curve on the project con-
nected this long tangent with the terminal intersection at Boston Street.

Triangulation of Control Points in Canton and Fairfield.—After establish-
ing the center line of the main crossing, large target towers were erected on
the center line near the shores in Canton and Fairfield. These targets were
easily visible across the mile of open water at the site. Hubs were estab-
lished between these targets and the shore line for triangulation procedure.
The City of Baltimore has a very complete triangulation network, and it
was found advisable to use this network of triangulation points to tie in
with the survey for the bridge. The U. S. Army Engineers have also es-
tablished a triangulation network, and it was necessary to coordinate this
network with the City network, in order to establish the pierhead, bulk-
head, and channel range lines in relation to the center line stations on the
bridge. The hubs established on the Canton and Fairfield shores were
triangulated in from a station on Fort McHenry, and the distance between
them was computed. In addition to the coordination of the surveys for
this crossing with those hereinbefore named, the entire survey system is
coordinated with and tied into the U. S. Coast and Geodetic Survey herein
described under ‘“Engineering Procedure.”

Soundings of the Patapsco River Along the Center Line.—A complete set
of sounding equipment was next assembled, and centerline soundings were
taken from a boat at approximately 20 feet intervals. The boat was kept
on the center line by means of ranges. Through a system of signals, the
exact location of each sounding was fixed by an angle reading cut in with
a transit located at Fort McHenry. The distances along the center line
were then computed, and the profile of the river bottom plotted.

Reconnaissance and Preliminary Topographical Surveys on Several Pro-
Jected Lines for the Faurfield Approach between the Patapsco River and the
City Limits.—The terminus of the bridge proper in Fairfield was definitely
established, but it was difficult to decide upon a line for the continuation of
the approach to connect with the proposed extension to Elkridge at the
City limits near Church Street. Several lines were run from Chesapeake
Street to the City limits with various studies being made for a crossing over
or under the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks near Patapsco Avenue and
the proper intersection at Pennington and Patapsco Avenues. It was
finally decided to continue the tangent of the bridge and to terminate the

field_edited_text_processed:
TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS 67

project at the intersection of Shell Road and Patapsco Avenue and utilize
the present Baltimore and Ohio underpass at that point, since it is possible
to widen and improve this underpass in the future for an increased volume
of traffic. The projection of this final alignment beyond Shell Road was
continued with one curve to the City limits.

Final Topographic Survey for the Fairfield Approach between the Patapsco
River and the Intersection of Pennington and Patapsco Avenues.—After es-
tablishing the alignment on the Fairfield side, a complete topographical
survey, including property lines, railroad tracks, and profiles, was made
between Pennington Avenue and the Patapsco River. Stations were
established, running from south to north, allowance being given for the
extension of the station numbering as far as the Washington Boulevard
near Elkridge.

Survey of Proposed Line for the Bridge Approach in Anne Arundel County
and Howard County between the Baltimore City Line and the Washington
Boulevard Connection mear Elkridge.—The proposed connection between
the City Line and Elkridge was surveyed by—first, making a reconnais-
sance of the entire area to establish the best practical alignment for a
modern dual highway; and secondly, a random line survey was run all the
way from the intersection of the City Line near Church Street to the Wash-
ington Boulevard about one-half mile past Elkridge.

Final Complete Topographical Survey for the Canton Approach between the
Patapsco River and the Intersection of the Center Line and Boston Street.—A
continuation of the center line tangent intersects Quail Street about 1400
feet north of Holabird Avenue. From this P.I. another tangent was pro-
jected north along Quail Street to Boston Street. For this total distance a
complete topographical survey was made, showing all railroad tracks in the
Canton property and a profile of the entire distance was run.

Triangulation for Boring Locations.—Additional borings at three sites
in the river were made, and it was necessary to set buoys at predetermined
stations, in order that the boring crew could locate the proposed holes.
These buoys were triangulated on line, and after the boring equipment was
in place, further checks were made to establish the exact stations at which
the borings were taken. At the same time tide gauges were set, in order
to establish elevations of the borings.

Center Line Survey and Profile between Boston Street and the Intersection of
the Proposed N orth Approach and the Philadelphia Road at Erdman Avenue.—
From the intersection of the center line of the proposed project, and Boston

project at the intersection of Shell Road and Patapsco Avenue and utilize
the present Baltimore and Ohio underpass at that point, since it is possible

field_edited_text_processed:
68 PaTarsco RivEr CROSSING

Street the center line was surveyed on Quail Street all the way to an inter-
section with the Philadelphia Road at Erdman Avenue. On this alignment
complete topography and profile was taken for the entire distance.

BORINGS

The State Roads Commission obtained from the Pennsylvania Railroad
Company boring data from borings made by the Railroad between the
years 1908 and 1913, for a crossing of the Patapsco River proposed by the
Railroad Company thirty years ago. The Railroad Company had at that
time selected a site for their crossing within a short distance of the site
proposed for this highway crossing. In fact, the proposed Railroad cross-
ing was only 110 feet from the proposed crossing at the north end and 50
feet at the south end. The borings made at that time were supplemented
by additional borings made in August, 1938 by the State Roads Com-
mission, for the purpose of checking the original data secured from the
Railroad Company, and for the additional purpose of securing undisturbed
samples for the determination of soil characteristics with particular respect
to the effect the soil conditions will have upon the cost of the tunnel con-
struction, and also with respect to the requirements for Bridge foundations.
The undisturbed samples taken by the State Roads Commission this year
were taken in sealed cylinders 3 inches in diameter and 12 inches long, at
frequent intervals, one in the location of the deepest mud area, and the
others in the locations of the main channel piers of the proposed bridge.

The results of the borings at this site show that a tunnel can be con-
structed without undue expense, and with comparatively little risk of
construction difficulties, and show also that bridge foundations at this site
present no unusual or difficult construction conditions.

FOUNDATIONS

The main section of the Patapsco River Crossing consists of 6790 feet of
through truss spans supported by steel bents and towers on concrete piers.
There are 14 piers in this group. Piers Numbers 1, 11, 12, 13 and 14 are
on shore and piers 2 to 10 inclusive are in the Patapsco River. Piers
Numbers 7 and 8 support the main cantilever span over the channel.

Soundings in the Patapsco River show water depths not over 40 feet and
sub-strata as shown by the borings on Plates 28 to 31 inclusive, indicate
that foundation conditions are favorable to the use of a standard type of
pler construction consisting of tremie concrete seals encasing steel bearing
field_edited_text_value:
68 PaTarsco RivEr CROSSING

Street the center line was surveyed on Quail Street all the way to an inter-
section with the Philadelphia Road at Erdman Avenue. On this alignment
complete topography and profile was taken for the entire distance.

BORINGS

The State Roads Commission obtained from the Pennsylvania Railroad
Company boring data from borings made by the Railroad between the
years 1908 and 1913, for a crossing of the Patapsco River proposed by the
Railroad Company thirty years ago. The Railroad Company had at that
time selected a site for their crossing within a short distance of the site
proposed for this highway crossing. In fact, the proposed Railroad cross-
ing was only 110 feet from the proposed crossing at the north end and 50
feet at the south end. The borings made at that time were supplemented
by additional borings made in August, 1938 by the State Roads Com-
mission, for the purpose of checking the original data secured from the
Railroad Company, and for the additional purpose of securing undisturbed
samples for the determination of soil characteristics with particular respect
to the effect the soil conditions will have upon the cost of the tunnel con-
struction, and also with respect to the requirements for Bridge foundations.
The undisturbed samples taken by the State Roads Commission this year
were taken in sealed cylinders 3 inches in diameter and 12 inches long, at
frequent intervals, one in the location of the deepest mud area, and the
others in the locations of the main channel piers of the proposed bridge.

The results of the borings at this site show that a tunnel can be con-
structed without undue expense, and with comparatively little risk of
construction difficulties, and show also that bridge foundations at this site
present no unusual or difficult construction conditions.

FOUNDATIONS

The main section of the Patapsco River Crossing consists of 6790 feet of
through truss spans supported by steel bents and towers on concrete piers.
There are 14 piers in this group. Piers Numbers 1, 11, 12, 13 and 14 are
on shore and piers 2 to 10 inclusive are in the Patapsco River. Piers
Numbers 7 and 8 support the main cantilever span over the channel.

Soundings in the Patapsco River show water depths not over 40 feet and
sub-strata as shown by the borings on Plates 28 to 31 inclusive, indicate
that foundation conditions are favorable to the use of a standard type of
pler construction consisting of tremie concrete seals encasing steel bearing

field_edited_text_processed:
FounpATioNs 69

piles. The sub-strata for the most part consists of a mixture of sand and
very stiff clay overlaid with varying depths of mud or alluvial deposits.
In one section of the river near the vicinity of boring Number 7, there is a
deep mud area about 1500 feet long on the centerline of the bridge where
the mud extends to depths as much as 90 feet below mean low water. This
mud is soft for a depth of about 20 feet, but the remaining portion is very
stiff being almost the consistency of clay. Underneath this mud is very
firm material which would offer effective resistence to the driving of bearing
piles.

The design of the piers has been based upon the use of steel H piles driven
to their load capacity in this very firm material. It is planned to drive
these piles inside of a steel cofferdam in which the river bottom has been
excavated to the bottom of the tremie seal. Either a steel follower or an
under water hammer could be used whereby the piles would receive prac-
tically the same impact as if they were driven with the hammer or the top
of the pile in air. After the piles have been driven to proper grade, the
tremie seal would be poured and the cofferdam unwatered to expose the top
of the piles. A reinforced pier base would then be poured upon the top of
the tremie seal and pile caps, and on this base would be built the pier stems
to elevation +20. Stone facing extending from elevation —3 to elevation
+5 would be used on the pier stems to protect the concrete from the action
of water and ice. The footings of the piers have been so designed that they
will be below the bottom of the harbor in the event that it is ever dredged
to a depth of 40 ft. over its entire area. These main river piers consist of
two separate stems founded on separate footings and groups of piles and
tied together with massive reinforced concrete struts in order to insure that
they will act as a unit. A complete design of one of the main channel piers
is included herein together with a sketch of this pier as shown on Figure 9.
Details of typical piers are shown on Plate 37.

The approaches to the main part of the Patapsco River Bridge consists
essentially of girder spans with steel bents supported on concrete pedestals.
The Fairfield approach has 26 pairs of pedestals and the Canton approach
has 62 pairs of pedestals. These pedestals are of reinforced concrete sup-
ported on timber piles. The piles are designed for a load capacity of 20
tons. Details of a typical pedestal are shown on Plate 37. There are
several roadway fills on the approaches leading up to the girder spans and
these fills are retained by concrete abutments A, B, C and D. The rein-
forced concrete abutments are designed to be founded on timber piles.

field_edited_text_processed:
BRIDGE SUPERSTRUCTURE 73

BRIDGE SUPERSTRUCTURE

The superstructure of the Patapsco River Bridge is divided into two
parts: (1) the elevated Canton and Fairfield approaches; and (2) the main
river bridge. A plan and profile of the proposed bridge and approaches
is shown on Plate 23. The Fairfield approach superstructure consists of
one railroad grade elimination 1313 feet in length over the freight tracks
of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad and an elevated approach to the main
bridge from grade for a distance of 1120 feet. The Canton approach con-
sists of an elevated highway approach extending from the end of the main
bridge trusses to Ponca Street for a distance of 4970 feet and includes a
triple truss span crossing over the numerous railroad tracks encountered
just to the south of Newkirk Street.

The elevated structures on these approaches are all deck spans except for
the through trusses mentioned above. Some of the spans are of lengths
longer than 70 feet and those extending to elevations 30 feet or more above
the ground consist of simple girder spans, three in number, connected with
curved bottom flanged floor beams. The major portion of the approaches
consists of multiple units of three span rigid frames. The average spanlength
being 70 feet. These rigid frame spans are made up of two girders per span
connected at their supports with a rigid frame bent. The roadway is
cantilevered beyond the outside of the supporting girders and is carried on
brackets placed at the third points and which are opposite the interior
floor beams. This type of construction is shown on the perspective sketch
on Plate 21.

Three simple span through trusses are utilized to carry the roadway over
the railroad tracks south of Newkirk Street on the Canton approach and as
shown on Plate 34. .

The main bridge crossing of the Patapsco consists of a series of simple
through truss spans on either side of the main channel span, which is a three
span cantilever unit. The trusses in these spans are 53 feet center to center
and have curved top chords and sub-divided panels in the longer spans.
Design details of these trusses are shown on Plates 44, 45 and 46.

The main cantilever unit has a suspended span of 576 feet, with anchor
and cantilever arms of 668 feet and 324 feet, respectively. The trussesin
this unit are also 53 feet center to center throughout. The chord members
over the main towers have been dropped below the bottom chord of the
bridge in order to relieve the monotony of the alignment and to somewhat

one railroad grade elimination 1313 feet in length over the freight tracks
of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad and an elevated approach to the main
bridge from grade for a distance of 1120 feet. The Canton approach con-
sists of an elevated highway approach extending from the end of the main
bridge trusses to Ponca Street for a distance of 4970 feet and includes a
triple truss span crossing over the numerous railroad tracks encountered
just to the south of Newkirk Street.

The elevated structures on these approaches are all deck spans except for
the through trusses mentioned above. Some of the spans are of lengths
longer than 70 feet and those extending to elevations 30 feet or more above
the ground consist of simple girder spans, three in number, connected with
curved bottom flanged floor beams. The major portion of the approaches
consists of multiple units of three span rigid frames. The average spanlength
being 70 feet. These rigid frame spans are made up of two girders per span
connected at their supports with a rigid frame bent. The roadway is
cantilevered beyond the outside of the supporting girders and is carried on
brackets placed at the third points and which are opposite the interior
floor beams. This type of construction is shown on the perspective sketch
on Plate 21.

Three simple span through trusses are utilized to carry the roadway over
the railroad tracks south of Newkirk Street on the Canton approach and as
shown on Plate 34. .

The main bridge crossing of the Patapsco consists of a series of simple
through truss spans on either side of the main channel span, which is a three
span cantilever unit. The trusses in these spans are 53 feet center to center
and have curved top chords and sub-divided panels in the longer spans.
Design details of these trusses are shown on Plates 44, 45 and 46.

The main cantilever unit has a suspended span of 576 feet, with anchor
and cantilever arms of 668 feet and 324 feet, respectively. The trussesin
this unit are also 53 feet center to center throughout. The chord members
over the main towers have been dropped below the bottom chord of the
bridge in order to relieve the monotony of the alignment and to somewhat

field_edited_text_processed:
74 Patarsco RivEr CROSSING

lower the height of the top of the bridge towers. Design details of the
cantilever unit are shown on Plates 38 to 42 inclusive. The main canti-
lever span is supported on battered tower bents over piers Numbers 7 and
8. These towers are 144 feet in height and are spread 89 feet transversly
and 38 feet longitudinally at their base. The two tower legs are composed
of three sections. The straight center section is designed to carry the super-
imposed load and the two curved outside legs come into action to overcome
the effect of longitudinal forces on the bridge. Design details of the canti-
lever span towers are shown on Plate 43. All expansion due to temperature in
the main span between pier 7 and pier 8 is taken by an expansion joint placed
at one end of the suspended span. The other end of the suspended span
being pinned directly to the cantilever arm. The ends of the anchor arms
are carried on split flexible bents over piers Numbers 6 and 9. At this
point the expansion in the roadway takes place for the entire distance be-
tween piers Numbers 5 and 7, and 8 and 10.

The roadway for the entire main bridge and approaches is 46 feet wide
between curbs and consists of a steel grid type floor filled with concrete and
with a 3/4 inch concrete overfill. Integral colored concrete traffic lines
will be placed monolithically with the concrete wearing surface. The curbs
and 1 foot 6 inch walkways on either side of the roadway are made of steel
plates supported on diaphragms. The roadway slab on the main bridge is
supported on steel cross beams which rest on the longitudinal stringers.
On the approach spans the roadway slab rests directly upon the floor beams,
stringers and brackets. The railing on the main bridge consists of channels
supported by steel posts fastened to each cross beam. On the approach
spans the railing is a solid plate girder type stiffened with longitudinal
angles and spanning from post to post over the brackets about 23 feet
center to center.

The bridge and approaches will be lighted by high efficiency lights placed
on poles and at sufficient height above the roadway to prevent glare and
yet flood the roadway with a uniform light throughout.

BRIDGE ROADWAY

The roadway for this bridge consists of an open mesh type flooring filled
with concrete, which when completed will present the appearance of a
concrete roadway surface. The weight of the floor in the design of the
bridge includes an allowance for the future addition of two inches of asphalt
or other wearing surface.

field_edited_text_processed:
ToLL PrAzA 75

The plans provide for dividing the roadway into four lanes by the con-
struction of permanent roadway markers in the surface of the roadway slab.
The central marker will be a wide white stripe obtained by the use of white
cement and white aggregates laid monolithically with the other concrete.
The stripe will divide the bridge into two lanes operating in opposite direc-
tions. The lanes operating in the same direction will also be divided by
permanent stripes constructed in the roadway using colored aggregates to
contrast with the color of the normal concrete. Similar stripes will also
be constructed immediately adjacent and parallel to the curbs. The
footways for this bridge have been designed 1 foot 6 inches wide and are
intended as emergency footways only since little, if any, pedestrian use is
to be expected.

TOLL PLAZA

The toll plaza will accommodate peak traffic loads of about 3,000 motor
vehicles per hour on the basis of 2,000 vehicles operating in one direction
and 1,000 operating in the opposite direction. These peaks have been
estimated by the Highway Planning Survey of the State Roads Commission
and are expected to occur during the racing seasons in Maryland, on other
special occasions, and on week-ends and holidays when thousands of city
dwellers in Baltimore return from the shores and beaches on the Chesa-
peake Bay and its tributaries. The plaza will provide six traffic lanes
passing under the toll booth canopy and two traffic lanes passing in the
clear outside of the canopy. Three toll islands will be provided, each
equipped with two toll booths. The lanes outside the canopy are intended
to pass vehicles or equipment too high to clear the canopy.

The plaza also includes a building for the administration of the main-
tenance and operation of the bridge. This building is located off the toll
plaza in such location that the superintendent can continually oversee the
toll taking operations. The toll booths are designed to have complete
glass sections between the limits required for visability from one side to the
other side of the plaza. The estimates of cost for the administration build-
ing, toll booths, toll taking equipment and furnishings are based on the use
of the most recently developed and up-to-date toll taking and recording
devices designed for speedy and efficient handling of traffic and the safe
collection and recording of all tolls paid by the traveling public. The toll
plaza layout is shown to a small scale in plan and elevation on Plate 25
and is shown in perspective on the sketch on Plate 22.

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE

The engineering procedure hereinbefore described has been scheduled with
a view of beginning actual construction on this bridge and its approaches in
time to complete the entire work by June, 1940. The construction is di-
vided into main construction items as follows:
Substructure
a. Pedestals for the approach in Fairfield.
b. Piers starting with 1 and 14 and proceeding with 2 and 13,
3 and 12,4 and 11, 5 and 10, 6 and 9, 7 and 8, and including
abutments A, B, C and D and the Canton pedestals and
plers in order that simultaneous operations on two piers
and on the groups of abutments and pedestals may be in
progress on each side of the river with a minimum number
of equipment units.
Superstructure
a. Erection and riveting of the various steel spans.
b. Construction of roadway slab.
c. Painting.

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE

The engineering procedure hereinbefore described has been scheduled with
a view of beginning actual construction on this bridge and its approaches in
time to complete the entire work by June, 1940. The construction is di-
vided into main construction items as follows:
Substructure
a. Pedestals for the approach in Fairfield.
b. Piers starting with 1 and 14 and proceeding with 2 and 13,
3 and 12,4 and 11, 5 and 10, 6 and 9, 7 and 8, and including
abutments A, B, C and D and the Canton pedestals and
plers in order that simultaneous operations on two piers
and on the groups of abutments and pedestals may be in
progress on each side of the river with a minimum number
of equipment units.
Superstructure
a. Erection and riveting of the various steel spans.
b. Construction of roadway slab.
c. Painting.

field_edited_text_processed:
82 Patarsco RivEr CROSSING

Roadway construction
a. Highway fills and grading.
b. Highway paving, guard rails and markers.
Toll booths and administration building.
Pier fenders.
Lighting.

The above work as shown on the Progress Chart, Plate 47, is shown as
being started by December 15, 1938 when the pedestals 1 to 26 under a
contract previously prepared in accordance with the engineering pro-
cedure hereinbefore described, can be started in order to be completed by
September 30, 1939. The construction of piers 1 to 14 inclusive, is begun in
pairs at one month intervals, starting with January 20, 1939 and completing
all piers by January 31, 1940. During this period piles would be in the course
of driving in 2 piers and other stages of construction would be in progress
on 4 piers simultaneously. The completion of substructure plans and
specifications, award of substructure contracts, approval of shop drawings
and the beginning of shop fabrication for the truss spans, cantilever units
and approach spans in Canton and Fairfield would be in simultaneous
progress as shown on the progress chart referred to above.

The estimates of cost of construction are based upon the necessary equip-
ment and labor requirements to insure the completion of the work in ac-
cordance with the schedule outlined above and shown on the chart.

The above construction procedure and the Progress Chart, Plate 47,
pertains to the use of a bridge crossing only. The Progress Chart and the
construction procedure for a tunnel would be entirely different and is not
herein presented.

incurred or to be incurred by the State Roads Commission for surveys,
borings, traffic report, test piles, soil analysis for the determination of soil
mechanics of the sub-strata underlying the site of the bridge, preliminary
legal and administrative expenses. These preliminary expenses, with esti-
mates to cover all costs in connection therewith, are listed below. See
Table 29.

The proposed tunnel for this crossing, as previously described, has two
traffic lanes, and the tunnel section, as estimated and tabulated in Table 40,
is 8,610 feet long from a point at grade in Fairfield to a point at grade in
Canton.

Road and Patapsco Avenue and extends for a distance of 2,487 feet with a
filled approach to abutment “A”, where the overpass over the Baltimore

CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

The conclusions which may be drawn from the report on this crossing,
herein presented, may be summarized as follows:

1. The site selected for this crossing utilizes the shortest suitable crossing
of the Patapsco River, southeast of the Hanover Street Bridge.

2. The bridge or tunnel located at this site will serve three primary traffic

field_edited_text_processed:
CONCLUSIONS 93

functions; by affording a short connection for local traffic between the two
industrial areas separated by the Patapsco River; by furnishing an addi-
tional connection between Baltimore and Anne Arundel County and the
southern sections of the State, thus relieving the congestion on the existing
Hanover Street Bridge route; and by forming a by-pass for connecting
Route No. 40 to the north with Route No. 1 to the south, a sorely needed
traffic facility to relieve the congestion and delay in the City of Baltimore
for through traffic.

3. A tunnel carrying two lanes of traffic will cost $15,977,000 and a
bridge to carry four lanes of traffic will cost $11,050,100, a difference of
$4,926,900 before interest during construction and bond discount. The
capacity of the tunnel is considerably less than one-half the capacity of the
bridge since traffic experts have estimated that a maximum two lane tunnel
capacity is approximately 6,500,000 vehicles per year, whereas the maximum
capacity of a four lane bridge is 14,000,000 vehicles per year.

4. Due to the fact that there is no natural deep water in Baltimore Harbor
and the only available deep water for navigation is in the Federally main-
tained ship channels, a bridge across the river at this point need span not
more than the artificially maintained channel, which is 1,000 feet wide, thus
creating a condition where a bridge can be constructed much more eco-
nomically than could be done if a greater width of deep water existed, and
if it were necessary to span considerably more than 1,000 feet with vertical
clearances of 175 feet.

5. While the objection has been made that the construction of this bridge
will constitute an additional obstacle to the future use of the upper harbor
of Baltimore City for the landing and take-off of large seaplanes, it is diffi-
cult to see how the upper harbor could be used for landings and take-offs of
large seaplanes, even without the presence of this bridge. Certainly it
could not be so used without eliminating all ship traffic from a very large
water area. This being impracticable, actually the upper harbor could be
used only for occasional emergency landings. For this purpose a bridge
would not seem to offer any greater hazard than those hazards already
existent.

Even if it be assumed that the upper harbor could be set apart for the
exclusive use of seaplanes, nevertheless the City of Baltimore is confronted
with the absolute necessity of devising some means of diverting through
traffic from the congested streets of the City and relieving the congested
traffic conditions on the Hanover Street Bridge. This is a problem which is

field_edited_text_processed:
94 PAaTaprsco RivEr CROSSING

daily becoming more acute, and the construction of a bridge at this site
seems to offer the only wholly practicable solution. When weighed in the
balance against the absolute necessity of adequately providing for millions
of vehicles which will use this bridge, the somewhat dubious possibility that
the bridge might adversely affect the future use of the upper harbor for
seaplanes becomes of secondary importance.

6. It will cost $100,000 per annum to operate, maintain, and provide the
necessary insurance for a bridge and its approaches at this site. To this
sum there must be added an additional annual expense to cover general and
administrative expense.

7. The maintenance, operation and insurance expenses for a tunnel are
estimated to be $187,000 per annum.

8. In case this bridge and its approaches were combined with one
other bridge in the Maryland Bridge Program the general and admin-
istrative expense would amount to $28,500 per year unless the salary of
the treasurer, accountant, clerk-stenographer, and legal, engineering, and
other special services, office rentals, supplies and equipment, and sundry
administrative expenses were borne by the State Roads Commission from
funds other than bridge revenues,in which case the general and administrative
expense would then amount to only $13,500 per annum. General and
administrative expense in case this bridge is combined with two or more
other bridges is estimated hereinbefore.

9. The Traffic Report submitted to the State Roads Commission by
Coverdale & Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, on September
3, 1938, estimates that the gross revenue for a bridge or a tunnel at this site
if combined with a crossing of the Susquehanna River at Havre de Grace, a
crossing of the Potomac River at Dahlgren, and a crossing of the Chesapeake
Bay at Sandy Point, with a base toll rate of $0.25 per passenger car, would
amount to $420,000 per annum for the average of five years, beginning with
the year 1941.

10. The engineering procedure and construction work for a bridge has been
so scheduled that the work of construction can be started on or before
December 31, 1938 and completed on or before June 30, 1940, as illustrated
graphically on the Progress Chart, Plate 47.

11. Finally, the cost of a bridge and approaches to connect the corner
of Boston and Quail Streets, in Canton, with the corner of Patapsco Avenue
and Shell Road, in Fairfield, is $11,050,100, and a tunnel with its approaches

field_edited_text_processed:
CONCLUSIONS 95

between the same limits is $15,977,000 before interest during construction
and bond discount.

The above summary of conclusions reached in this report, covering a two
lane tunnel crossing and a four lane bridge crossing of the Patapsco River,
in Baltimore Harbor, leads to the definite recommendation that this crossing
be built as a bridge now, or at any time in the future when the money
becomes available for its construction.

field_edited_text_processed:
Potomac River Bridge





SITE OF THE BRIDGE

THIS bridge crosses the Potomac River from a point in Charles County,
Maryland, at or near Ludlow’s Ferry, to a point approximately opposite
in the State of Virginia near Dahlgren; and is shown on ‘“‘Vicinity Map,”’
Plate 51. It will form a link connecting the Maryland and Virginia High-
ways Systems between La Plata, Charles County, Maryland and King
George County, Virginia.

Under date of June 22, 1935 Mr. H. G. Shirley, Commissioner, Depart-
ment of Highways, Richmond, Virginia, addressed J. E. Greiner Company
in part as follows:

“It will require about 3% or 4 miles to connect it (a bridge over the Potomac River at
Dahlgren) up with our system. A greater mileage than this will make a straight line
through from Bowling Green. The road from Bowling Green over to the Port Conway
Bridge through to near King George C. H. is almost complete with a short strip leading
into Bowling Green, which is in serviceable condition.

No doubt by the time the bridge over the Potomac can be constructed, a direct line in
Virginia would be well under way leading up to it.”

This bridge will be the only bridge crossing the Potomac River between
the District of Columbia and the mouth of the river at the Chesapeake Bay,
and will provide access and uninterrupted communication between the two
states now separated by the river. It will provide an alternate route for
tourists traveling from Baltimore and the north to Richmond, Norfolk, and
the south. It will provide easier and cheaper access for marketing of pro-
duce in the section of Virginia known as the Northern Neck and points
south to the markets of Washington, Baltimore, and the north. It will
connect Baltimore, Washington, and the north with the historic points of
Virginia, such as Williamsburg, Yorktown, Jamestown, Wakefield, and
Stratford by a shorter route than the existing route via Fredericksburg. It
will constitute an important link in the national north-south coastal high-
way, with easy grades and straight alignment from New England to Florida.

96

duce in the section of Virginia known as the Northern Neck and points

96

field_edited_text_processed:
SITE OF THE BRIDGE 97

The bridge forms a direct connection between the highway systems of
Maryland and Virginia, and lies very close to a straight line between Balti-
more and Richmond. The Maryland route from Baltimore to the bridge
site is Maryland Route Number 3, and the connection on the Virginia
side would be a new route, as set forth in Commissioner Shirley’s letter
quoted above.

The economic and social values of this bridge can be summarized in the
following statement: The advantages to the people of the adjacent Mary-
land and Virginia counties in expediting the natural interchange of social
and commercial relations must be apparent, and since the advent of the
automobile, the need for a physical connection of the highways has become
pressing. Prior to the advent of the automobile, the river itself formed the
connection by furnishing means for transportion by boat, and, since the
advent of the automobile, transportation by boat no longer exists because
it is too slow as compared with the speed of motor traffic.

The interest developed in recent years in historic Virginia is shown by
the thousands of visitors annually to Williamsburg, where large sums of
money have been spent by the Rockefeller interests to reconstruct the city,
in order to perpetuate this early colonial settlement for the people of
America. National patriotic organizations have rehabilitated Wakefield
and Stratford, which are twenty-six miles and thirty-two miles, respectively,
from the site of this bridge. As a result of the interest of the people of the
country in these historic places, the increase in traffic in the Northern Neck
of Virginia has been tremendous.

Ludlow’s Ferry is the site of the ferry first established in early colonial
days and used in connecting the north and south seaboard road between
the early colonies. This ferry was used by George Washington and the
Revolutionary troops, and helped to expedite the transportation of troops
to Yorktown preceding that battle and the surrender of Cornwallis. Fig-
ure 10 is a reproduction of a map prepared in the year 1757, which shows
the old colonial routes. This map shows the routes in Maryland and
Virginia leading to Ludlow’s Ferry or Hooes Ferry.

Prior to 1934 the Rappahannock River was not bridged between Fred-
ericksburg and Tappahannock, but in that year a new highway bridge was
built across the Rappahannock at Port Royal, known as the James Madison
Memorial Bridge. This bridge lies near a straight line between Dahlgren
and Bowling Green, Virginia.

field_edited_text_processed:
98 Poromac RivEr BRIDGE

NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS

The plans for this structure, as submitted by the State Roads Commis-
sion for the approval of the War Department, contemplated one ship channel
span over the existing natural channel in the Potomac River, in water about
40 feet deep. The channel span was proposed 650 feet long, 470 feet of
which was 135 feet clear above mean high water, with 50 feet additional
having a minimum vertical clearance of 105 feet. This made the total
lateral clearance 570 feet. The two side spans flanking this main cantilever
span were each 3573 feet long, with a minimum of 85 feet vertical clearance
above mean high water. This proposed channel crossing was located along
the westerly edge of the natural channel, in order to maintain the shortest
bridge structure possible, for the reason that if this span were shifted farther
east and 4 per cent approach grades were maintained, the overall bridge
length would be increased. '

The Engineers of the War Department have determined that the plans
submitted are inadequate to properly meet navigation requirements, and
have indicated that a change in the plans is necessary. The War Depart-
ment Engineers have stated to the J. E. Greiner Company that they will
approve plans to provide 700 feet lateral clearance and 135 feet vertical
clearance, as proposed in the plans accompanying this report, provided such
span of increased length is moved eastward, in order to place the span di-
rectly over the channel used by pilots in navigating this portion of the
Potomac River. The shifting of this span eastward and the increasing of
the channel span from 650 feet to 800 feet has materially increased the
cost of this bridge, and therefore the estimates of cost herein presented
are considerably higher than the estimates prepared in connection with the
P.W.A. Application now pending.

DESCRIPTION OF PROPOSED BRIDGE

The proposed structure is a high level bridge the main span of which
is shown on Plate 52 “Sketch of Main Span.” 1t provides a horizontal
clearance of 700 feet and a vertical clearance of 135 feet over the main ship
channel of the Potomac. The main span over the channel forms the high-
est point in the roadway with 3.75 per cent grade approaches. The main
channel span and the two side spans flanking it, comprise a cantilever unit,
the main span of which is 800 feet long and the side spans of which are
anchor spans each 366 feet 8 inches long. The cantilever units forming the

field_edited_text_processed:
TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS 101

approaches to this central unit are made up of alternate anchor spans and
cantilever spans 437 feet 6 inches and 500 feet long respectively.

The main section of the bridge is approached from the Virginia end by
sixty-three spans of concrete pile bent and steel beam trestle construction
3873 feet long, and four plate girder spans 100 feet long, connecting the
trestle with the main cantilever section. On the Maryland side of the
river, the main cantilever section of the bridge is approached by three
100 feet plate girder spans and two 250 feet simple truss spans connecting
the filled approach, with the main cantilever section. The bridge is 9918.84
feet long from abutment to abutment. The Maryland approach extends
inland for a distance of 1527.56 feet. The toll plaza, with the administra-
tion building and toll booths, is included as a part of the Maryland approach.

The total length of the project, from the Virginia abutment to the end
of the Maryland approach, is 11,446.40 feet.

The Virginia approach is not included as a part of the work of the construc-
tion of this bridge, but is to be designed and constructed by the Virginia
Highway Department, in accordance with the existing agreement between
that Department and the Maryland State Roads Commission.

The bridge is designed for a roadway 24 feet wide, to accommodate two
lanes of traffic, with two emergency footways, each 1 foot 6 inches wide.
The vertical curve connecting the 3.75 per cent grades over the main channel
span provides a minimum sight distance of 654 feet. The alignment is
straight for the full length of the bridge and the Maryland approach.

The bridge has been designed as a high level structure, to eliminate the
necessity for a movable span. The bridge and Maryland approach are
above the elevation of the highest recorded ﬁoocl in the Potomac River.
On “Plan and Profile,” Plate 53, the entire bridge 1s shown, and to a larger
scale on “General Plan and Elevation,” Plates 54 to 61 inclusive.

TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS

In 1932 the State Roads Commission made surveys, borings, and estimates
for bridges at the site at present proposed and upstream at Mathias Point.
The Ludlow’s Ferry location was selected at that time as being preferable
to the Mathias Point location, primarily because the river is about 2,000
feet narrower at Ludlow’s ferry than at Mathias Point. Complete topo-
graphical surveys have been made at this site, and permanent triangulation
stations, hubs, and bench marks have been established.

field_edited_text_processed:
102 Poromac RiveEr BRIDGE

BORINGS

Borings have been made along the center line of the proposed bridge at
different times since 1932. Up until September, 1932, eleven borings had
been made at intervals across the river, the deepest of which extended about
190 feet below water level, at which elevation a hard stratum was encoun-
tered, which prevented extensions of the borings deeper. No attempt was
made to drill into this hard stratum to determine its character and geo-
logical origin. Since September, 1932, additional borings have been com-
pleted, so that there are at present, records of twenty-four borings made at
this site, the data for which are shown on Plates 54 to 59, inclusive, “General
Plan and Elevation.” The depth and consistency of the mud has lead to
the adoption of seamless steel tube piles for the foundations for the main
piers of the bridge.

The borings were made by driving a pipe casing to rock or to refusal,
removing the material in the casing by jetting, and sampling and recording
the strata through which the casing was driven.

FOUNDATIONS

Various methods for constructing the foundations for this bridge have
been studied, and the cost of construction by different methods has been
estimated. Those found best suited to meet the difficult foundation condi-
tions and most economical in construction cost as shown on Plate 63 ‘‘Piers
and Abutments”” have been adopted for use. The main channel piers and
those piers designed to anchor the cantilever units longitudinally, have
been designed with four cylinders forming the pier stems supported on long
steel seamless tube piles, with the cylinders and pile clusters tied together
below the mud line by means of tremie concrete deposited under water and
with the tops of the concrete cylinders tied together by means of reinforced
concrete struts or diaphragm walls.

Seamless steel tubes are manufactured in maximum sizes of 24 inches
and 26 inches diameter, with metal thicknesses up to £ inch. Both sizes
of tubes with 1 inch metal have been used in the design. These tubes are
manufactured in lengths from 35 feet to 40 feet long, and the design provides
for splicing them together to make piles sufficiently long to extend from
above the water line to hard-pan, rock or refusal about 190 feet below the
surface of the water.

102 Poromac RiveEr BRIDGE

BORINGS

Borings have been made along the center line of the proposed bridge at
different times since 1932. Up until September, 1932, eleven borings had
been made at intervals across the river, the deepest of which extended about
190 feet below water level, at which elevation a hard stratum was encoun-
tered, which prevented extensions of the borings deeper. No attempt was
made to drill into this hard stratum to determine its character and geo-
logical origin. Since September, 1932, additional borings have been com-
pleted, so that there are at present, records of twenty-four borings made at
this site, the data for which are shown on Plates 54 to 59, inclusive, “General
Plan and Elevation.” The depth and consistency of the mud has lead to
the adoption of seamless steel tube piles for the foundations for the main
piers of the bridge.

The borings were made by driving a pipe casing to rock or to refusal,
removing the material in the casing by jetting, and sampling and recording
the strata through which the casing was driven.

FOUNDATIONS

Various methods for constructing the foundations for this bridge have
been studied, and the cost of construction by different methods has been
estimated. Those found best suited to meet the difficult foundation condi-
tions and most economical in construction cost as shown on Plate 63 ‘‘Piers
and Abutments”” have been adopted for use. The main channel piers and
those piers designed to anchor the cantilever units longitudinally, have
been designed with four cylinders forming the pier stems supported on long
steel seamless tube piles, with the cylinders and pile clusters tied together
below the mud line by means of tremie concrete deposited under water and
with the tops of the concrete cylinders tied together by means of reinforced
concrete struts or diaphragm walls.

Seamless steel tubes are manufactured in maximum sizes of 24 inches
and 26 inches diameter, with metal thicknesses up to £ inch. Both sizes
of tubes with 1 inch metal have been used in the design. These tubes are
manufactured in lengths from 35 feet to 40 feet long, and the design provides
for splicing them together to make piles sufficiently long to extend from
above the water line to hard-pan, rock or refusal about 190 feet below the
surface of the water.

TypicaL P1Er DEsigN 103

TYPICAL PIER DESIGN
Prer No. 9
Point of Fixity of Piles against lateral movement assumed to be at a point
one-third up from the bottom of the mud layer to the bottom of the tremie.
Center of moments for forces tending to produce overturning of the pier
taken at a point one-half the depth between the Point of Fixity and the
bottom of the tremie.

Forces Acting to Produce Maximum Pile Stress

Refer to Figure 11.

(A) Transverse Wind of 200 pounds per lineal foot acting on the Live
Load six feet above roadway elevation.

(B) Wind on Truss, Floor and Rail—Wind of 30 pounds per square foot
on twice the area in elevation of Truss and Rail and once the area in eleva-
tion of the Floor System.

(C) Wind on Tower—30 pounds per square foot on once and half the
area in elevation of the vertical leg of the tower.

(D) Wind on Pier—20 pounds per square foot on once the area in eleva-
tion of the pier above mean high water.

(E) Iee—25,000 pounds per lineal foot of width of projected area of pier
at elevation of mean high water.

(F) Current—25 pounds per square foot on the projected area of the pier
between mean high water and top of mud.

Dead Loads

The pier dimensions were assumed as shown on Figure 11. All weights
of concrete above mean low water, El. 0.0, are computed at 150 pounds
per cubic foot. All concrete below El. 0.0 is reduced for buoyancy to 87.5
pounds per cubic foot. The weight of piling above center of moments is
included.

Conditions Investigated

Case 1. D + 30* Lateral W + C + L
Case2. D+ L+ C + I+ 15* Lateral W.
Case3. D+ L + C 4+ I + 15* Lateral W 4 L. L. Traction.
Case 4. Case 1-2 or 3 substituting Longitudinal W in place of Lateral W.
in which:
D = Dead Load of Superstructure, Pier and Portion of Pile above plane of in-
vestigation. ‘
L = Live Load.

The superstructure is supported on a rocker or roller nest at Pier Number 9, therefore

SUPERSTRUCTURE

The superstructure for this bridge, sections of which are shown on Plate 62
“Sections,” is divided into two main parts, the beam span approaches and
the main bridge across the deep water section of the river. As hereinbefore
stated, the pile bent and steel beam trestle construction is 3873 feet long
and is composed of rolled beam spans supported on reinforced concrete pile
bents.

The section of the superstructure over the deep portions of the river
include the Type “C”’ cantilevers, main cantilever span over the navigation
channel, and the simple spans at the low ends of the Type “C’’ cantilevers
approaching the main span, all as hereinbefore described under ‘‘Deseription
of Proposed Bridge.” A typical analysis of the main spans is briefly de-
scribed herein under ‘“Typical Analysis.”

Roadway width, 24 feet

field_edited_text_processed:
(GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE FLXPENSE 113

ROADWAY

The roadway for this bridge consists of an open mesh type flooring filled
with conerete, which when completed will present the appearance of a con-
crete roadway surface. The weight of the floor in the design of the bridge
includes an allowance for the future addition of two inches of asphalt or
other wearing surface.

The plans provide for dividing the roadway into two lanes by the con-
struction of permanent roadway markers in the surface of the roadway
slab. The central marker will be a colored stripe obtained by the use of
colored aggregates laid monolithically with the other concrete to divide the
bridge into two lanes operating in the opposite directions. Colored stripes
will also be constructed immediately adjacent and parallel to the curbs.

The footways for this bridge have been designed 1 foot 6 inches wide and
are intended as emergency footways only since little, if any, pedestrian use
is to be expected.

TOLL PLAZA

The toll plaza will provide two traffic lanes passing under the toll booth
canopy and two traffic lanes passing in the clear outside the canopy with
one toll island equipped with two toll booths. The lanes outside the canopy
are intended to pass vehicles or equipment too high to clear the canopy.

The plaza also includes a building for the administration of the mainte-
nance and operation of the bridge. This building is located off the toll
plaza in such location that the superintendent can continually oversee the
toll taking operations. The toll booths are designed to have complete glass
sections between the limits required for visibility from one side to the other
side of the plaza. The estimates of cost for the administration building,
toll booths, toll taking equipment and furnishings are based on the use of
the most recently developed and up-to-date toll taking recording devices
designed for the speedy and efficient handling of traffic and the safe collec-
tion and recording of all tolls paid by the traveling public. The toll plaza
layout is shown in plan and elevation on Plate 61, “General Plan and
Elevation.”

GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSE FOR MAINTAINING
AND OPERATING THE BRIDGES

Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, have
estimated the general and administrative expense for maintaining and

CoNSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TiME oF COMPLETION 117

combined with the Susquehanna and Patapsco River Crossings and with
the Sandy Point Bay Crossing. The gross revenues have been estimated
on the basis of a toll rate of seventy-five cents per passenger car, with bus
and truck rates as set forth in detail in the report and as herein listed in
Table 44 for convenient reference.

The estimates of vehicles and gross revenues for the first five years of
operation and the average of the first five years are tabulated in Table 45.

The report from which the above tabulation of vehicles and revenue have
been quoted has been reviewed by J. E. Greiner Company, and is considered
by them to be a thorough, comprehensive and conservative estimate of the
traffic which it is reasonable to expect will use this crossing.

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME OF COMPLETION

““The Progress Chart,” Plate 64, shows graphically the time required for
the various phases of engineering and construction, from the beginning of
the preliminary engineering work through to the completion of the bridge
and its approaches in June, 1940. As described under ‘‘Engineering Pro-
cedure,” the engineering work has been scheduled in order to begin actual
construction on this bridge and its approaches during the months of Novem-
ber and December, 1938, and in order to meet the scheduled completion
date named above. The construction is divided into main items as follows:

Substructure

(a) Reinforced concrete pile bents, which includes the casting of the

' piles, driving the piles, and capping the same ready for the
erection of the beam spans: and

(b) The main channel piers and the remaining piers for the support
of the Type “C” cantilever and the simple approach spans in the
order designated in the chart. '

Superstructure

(a) Following the design, the checking of shop drawings, and the
fabrication and delivery of the structural steel work, times for
which have been charted in the Progress Chart referred to above,
the construction procedure of the superstructure includes the
erection and riveting of the various steel spans.

(b) The construction of the roadway slab in sections as the steel super-
structure is made available for this construction work: and
field_edited_text_value:
CoNSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TiME oF COMPLETION 117

combined with the Susquehanna and Patapsco River Crossings and with
the Sandy Point Bay Crossing. The gross revenues have been estimated
on the basis of a toll rate of seventy-five cents per passenger car, with bus
and truck rates as set forth in detail in the report and as herein listed in
Table 44 for convenient reference.

The estimates of vehicles and gross revenues for the first five years of
operation and the average of the first five years are tabulated in Table 45.

The report from which the above tabulation of vehicles and revenue have
been quoted has been reviewed by J. E. Greiner Company, and is considered
by them to be a thorough, comprehensive and conservative estimate of the
traffic which it is reasonable to expect will use this crossing.

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME OF COMPLETION

““The Progress Chart,” Plate 64, shows graphically the time required for
the various phases of engineering and construction, from the beginning of
the preliminary engineering work through to the completion of the bridge
and its approaches in June, 1940. As described under ‘‘Engineering Pro-
cedure,” the engineering work has been scheduled in order to begin actual
construction on this bridge and its approaches during the months of Novem-
ber and December, 1938, and in order to meet the scheduled completion
date named above. The construction is divided into main items as follows:

Substructure

(a) Reinforced concrete pile bents, which includes the casting of the

' piles, driving the piles, and capping the same ready for the
erection of the beam spans: and

(b) The main channel piers and the remaining piers for the support
of the Type “C” cantilever and the simple approach spans in the
order designated in the chart. '

Superstructure

(a) Following the design, the checking of shop drawings, and the
fabrication and delivery of the structural steel work, times for
which have been charted in the Progress Chart referred to above,
the construction procedure of the superstructure includes the
erection and riveting of the various steel spans.

(b) The construction of the roadway slab in sections as the steel super-
structure is made available for this construction work: and

field_edited_text_processed:
118 Poromac RivEr BRIDGE

(c) Painting of the entire steel superstructure, scheduled for comple-
tion during months when favorable painting weather conditions
are to be expected, on or before June 30, 1940.

Roadway Construction

(a) The Virginia approaches are not included as a part of the work
under this schedule of operations but this work is to be executed
independently by the Virginia Highway Department, as herein-
before stated in this report.

(b) The section of approach including the toll plaza is 1527.56 feet
long, and the work of construction is scheduled to begin in the
spring of 1939, as shown on the Progress Chart.

(¢) The highway paving, guard rails and markers will follow in their
proper sequence.

Toll Booths, Administration Building and Pier Fenders

These structures are scheduled for completion by the time the bridge and
approaches are ready for traffic.

The estimates of cost of construction herein presented are based upon
the necessary equipment and labor requirements to insure the completion
of the work in accordance with the schedule outlined above and shown on
the Progress Chart.

ESTIMATED COST OF BRIDGE AND APPROACHES

The estimated cost of the bridge and approaches is summarized in
Table 46.

A. Preliminary Expenses

The preliminary expenses, herein listed, include all the preliminary engi-
neering work executed by the State Roads Commission since 1931, when the
Maryland Legislature passed—“A Joint Resolution requesting the State
Roads Commission and such other person or persons as the Governor may
appoint, to investigate the practicability of bridges across the lower Potomac
and Choptank Rivers,” and the preliminary expenses incurred by the State
Roads Commission for surveys, traffic report, and engineering work under
the supervision of J. E. Greiner Company in connection with the preparation
of this report, all as listed herein. See Table 47.

E. Legal, Administrative, and Overhead Expenses

The legal, administrative, and overhead expenses, herein listed, are in-
tended to cover the expenses of the State Roads Commission during the en-
tire period, with the exception of those listed under ¢Preliminary Expenses.”’
These expenses begin with the preliminary engineering work and extend
through the entire period until the final completion of the construction work
and the closing out of the construction fund. The legal expenses will con-
sist principally of legal work in connection with the acquisition of the neces-
sary rights-of-way, which can be handled largely as a matter of routine
work, but which may require the services of special counsel and legal assist-
ance to the extent herein estimated.

The administrative and overhead expenses are not intended to include
the routine administration or work which can be done by the personnel
regularly engaged in the routine work of the State Roads Commission.
It is, however, intended to represent an estimate of special administrative
services which may be required in addition to the regular personnel of the
Commission. See Table 52.

CONCLUSIONS 125

Present indications are that the use of statically determinate continuous
truss units of this patented design may further reduce the above named cost.

The question of royalties which the Commission might have to pay for a
license to use this patented type of truss will be an element in the deter-
mination of the final estimated cost.

CONCLUSIONS

The foregoing report on the Potomac River Bridge may be summarized
in the following conclusions:

1. The site selected for this bridge about midway between Washington
and the Chesapeake Bay is the proper site at which to build a highway
crossing the Potomac River to accommodate the traffic, which may rea-
sonably be expected to use it.

2. The bridge providing for 700 feet horizontal clearance and 135 feet
vertical clearance over the navigable channel is adequate for all navigation
requirements, has been indicated as adequate by the War Department and
will receive the War Department approval.

3. A bridge designed along the general principals described hereinbefore,
involving pier construction of the type described, and Type ‘C”’ Cantilever
construction for the main approaches, and Type ‘“A” Cantilever for the
main channel crossing, which involve no unusual types of construction,
appear to represent the most economical construction for this ecrossing.

4. Topographical surveys are complete, and permanent triangulation
stations, hubs, and bench marks have been established in order that these
surveys can be used at any time in the future.

5. Borings have been completed, insofar as borings are needed for defi-
nitely establishing construction costs, but additional borings will be needed
before contract plans and specifications have been finally prepared.

6. The annual maintenance, operation, and insurance expenses for oper-
ating this bridge as a toll facility, after its completion, amount to $41,000.
To this amount there should be added the proportionate part of the general
and administrative expense, which will depend upon the number of bridges
which comprise the entire program, and whether or not any part of these
general and administrative expenses may be supplied by the State Roads
Commission without charges against toll revenues. In the case of two
bridges, this general and administrative expense will amount to $28,500
a year if no deductions are allowed, and $13,500 a year if the salary of treas-

mination of the final estimated cost.

CONCLUSIONS

The foregoing report on the Potomac River Bridge may be summarized
in the following conclusions:

1. The site selected for this bridge about midway between Washington
and the Chesapeake Bay is the proper site at which to build a highway
crossing the Potomac River to accommodate the traffic, which may rea-
sonably be expected to use it.

2. The bridge providing for 700 feet horizontal clearance and 135 feet
vertical clearance over the navigable channel is adequate for all navigation
requirements, has been indicated as adequate by the War Department and
will receive the War Department approval.

3. A bridge designed along the general principals described hereinbefore,
involving pier construction of the type described, and Type ‘C”’ Cantilever
construction for the main approaches, and Type ‘“A” Cantilever for the
main channel crossing, which involve no unusual types of construction,
appear to represent the most economical construction for this ecrossing.

4. Topographical surveys are complete, and permanent triangulation
stations, hubs, and bench marks have been established in order that these
surveys can be used at any time in the future.

5. Borings have been completed, insofar as borings are needed for defi-
nitely establishing construction costs, but additional borings will be needed
before contract plans and specifications have been finally prepared.

6. The annual maintenance, operation, and insurance expenses for oper-
ating this bridge as a toll facility, after its completion, amount to $41,000.
To this amount there should be added the proportionate part of the general
and administrative expense, which will depend upon the number of bridges
which comprise the entire program, and whether or not any part of these
general and administrative expenses may be supplied by the State Roads
Commission without charges against toll revenues. In the case of two
bridges, this general and administrative expense will amount to $28,500
a year if no deductions are allowed, and $13,500 a year if the salary of treas-

field_edited_text_processed:
126 Poromac RivEr BRIDGE

urer, accountant, clerk stenographer, legal and other special services, and
office rental, supplies, and equipment, together with sundry administration
expenses are allowed to be deducted from the total.

7. The traffic report submitted by Coverdale and Colpitts, on September 3,
1938, with a cash one way toll rate of $0.75 per passenger and vehicle, as a
base rate for the tolls, will produce an annual gross revenue of $141,000 per
year, for the average of the first five years of operation, assuming that 1941
will be the first complete year of operation.

8. If all arrangements for financing have been completed on or before
October 15, 1938, the construction of this bridge can be started before
January 1, 1939, and the entire construction can be completed on or before
June 30, 1940, thus meeting the requirements for beginning and ending the
work as established by the Federal Emergency Administration of Public
Works.

9. Finally, this report has established the fact that the entire cost of
the bridge and approaches exclusive of interest during construction and
bond discount is $4,658,000. The estimates of cost, herein presented, are
based on labor rates as they now exist in the Construction Industry, and
which may reasonably be expected to exist during the period of this con-
struction work.

field_edited_text_processed:
Chesapeake Bay Bridge





BAY FERRIES

AT PRESENT the Chesapeake Bay is crossed by three ferry services.
One ferry operates between Baltimore and Tolchester and provides pri-
marily an excursion trip to transport patrons from Baltimore to a pleasure
beach at Tolchester. The service includes scheduled trips from Baltimore
to Tolchester, but has been intermittent for the last few years, with long
periods during which the sailings were discontinued.

A ferry is operated from Baltimore to Love Point which transports
automobiles, freight and passengers. It connects, at Love Point, with a
branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The railroad service has been re-
duced to very limited service, but the ferry service is still maintained.

The principal ferry service is operated from Annapolis to Matapeake and
transports automobiles, passengers and motor trucks between Annapolis
and the Eastern Shore. Formerly a direct connection was maintained be-
tween Annapolis and Claiborne, but this service has recently been changed.
A shuttle ferry operating from the southern end of Kent Island to Claiborne
now replaces the former direct service from Annapolis to Claiborne.

The State Roads Commission has had negotiations with the company
operating this ferry looking toward an arbitration agreement, to determine
the price to be paid by the Commission for the ferry, if the Commission
determines to construct a Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

BRIDGE SITES

As stated in the preamble of Chapter 356 of the Laws of Maryland
of 1937, the Chesapeake Bay stretches 130 miles from the southern boundary
line of Maryland to the upper regions of the Bay without any bridge or
tunnel crossing. This handicap to quick transportation by automobile
would be removed by the construction of a bridge, and such lack of a bridge
not only interferes with the quick transportation of passengers and goods,
but results in a handicap to the agricultural and industrial development of

127
field_edited_text_value:
Chesapeake Bay Bridge





BAY FERRIES

AT PRESENT the Chesapeake Bay is crossed by three ferry services.
One ferry operates between Baltimore and Tolchester and provides pri-
marily an excursion trip to transport patrons from Baltimore to a pleasure
beach at Tolchester. The service includes scheduled trips from Baltimore
to Tolchester, but has been intermittent for the last few years, with long
periods during which the sailings were discontinued.

A ferry is operated from Baltimore to Love Point which transports
automobiles, freight and passengers. It connects, at Love Point, with a
branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The railroad service has been re-
duced to very limited service, but the ferry service is still maintained.

The principal ferry service is operated from Annapolis to Matapeake and
transports automobiles, passengers and motor trucks between Annapolis
and the Eastern Shore. Formerly a direct connection was maintained be-
tween Annapolis and Claiborne, but this service has recently been changed.
A shuttle ferry operating from the southern end of Kent Island to Claiborne
now replaces the former direct service from Annapolis to Claiborne.

The State Roads Commission has had negotiations with the company
operating this ferry looking toward an arbitration agreement, to determine
the price to be paid by the Commission for the ferry, if the Commission
determines to construct a Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

BRIDGE SITES

As stated in the preamble of Chapter 356 of the Laws of Maryland
of 1937, the Chesapeake Bay stretches 130 miles from the southern boundary
line of Maryland to the upper regions of the Bay without any bridge or
tunnel crossing. This handicap to quick transportation by automobile
would be removed by the construction of a bridge, and such lack of a bridge
not only interferes with the quick transportation of passengers and goods,
but results in a handicap to the agricultural and industrial development of

127

field_edited_text_processed:
128 CHESAPEAKE BAay BRIDGE

the land area adjoining the bay, and in declining real estate values and
gradual loss of population in certain sections. It is highly desirable, there-
fore, that a bridge across the Bay be constructed and that the bridge be
connected by modern arterial highways, as shown by ‘‘Vicinity Map,”
Plate 65.

There is an urgent necessity for a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay,
either at the Sandy Point or at the Millers Island site, in order to provide
for quick transportation by motor vehicle between the Eastern Shore of
Maryland and Baltimore, Washington, Annapolis, and the Western Shore
of Maryland generally.

For many years the possibility of constructing such a bridge has been
under consideration. As early as 1919 preliminary surveys were made to
determine the feasibility of the project. With each passing year the neces-
sity for such a crossing has become more urgent. In years gone by, when
a very large portion of freight was moved by boat, the Chesapeake Bay was
a great asset to the State in furnishing cheap transportation by boat. In
those days the City of Baltimore and other points on the Western Shore of
Maryland were connected by boat lines with many important points on
the Eastern Shore, and fixed schedules were maintained. With the passing
years, the motor vehicle has virtually supplanted water borne traffic for
short hauls, so that the Chesapeake Bay has become in a sense a liability to
the State, insofar as it acts as an impediment to transportation by motor
vehicle.

Except for the ferry services which are maintained as above described,
motor vehicle traffic between Baltimore, Annapolis and Washington, and
the Eastern Shore of Maryland must travel northward to Elkton to go
around the head of the Chesapeake Bay. The result is that a great deal of
the products of the Eastern Shore, which in the days when most of such
products were transported by water, moved to markets in Baltimore City,
has been diverted to markets in Philadelphia and Wilmington. Likewise,
the development of resorts on the Eastern Shore Peninsula, such as Ocean
City, Maryland, and Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, has been retarded because
of the difficulty of moving by automobile from Baltimore, Washington, and
Annapolis to these resorts. The construction of this bridge will make the
markets of Baltimore, Washington, and Annapolis just as available to the
Eastern Shore as the markets of Wilmington and Philadelphia.

In 1931, following its appointment by Governor Ritchie, the Chesapeake
Bay Bridge Commission authorized traffic surveys at the site of the proposed

field_edited_text_processed:
BRrIDGE SITES 129

Millers Island Bridge and at the site of the proposed Sandy Point Bridge, by
independent traffic engineering firms. The results of these surveys were in
very close agreement and indicated that the prospective traffic across the
Bay at Sandy Point might be expected to exceed that at Millers Island.

The State Roads Commission arranged for traffic surveys, in connection
with Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program, shortly after the passage of the
Congressional authority for the construction of these bridges, in April,
1938. The field work for the surveys was conducted jointly by the Mary-
land Highway Planning Survey of the Maryland State Roads Commission,
and the Engineering Firm of Coverdale and Colpitts, engaged by the Com-
mission to undertake the traffic studies.

It is reasonable to expect that traffic at the Sandy Point site will be more
than the traffic at the Millers Island site. The former is more readily ac-
cessible to a much larger number of people, on account of its geographical
location with respect to the Cities of Baltimore and Washington, and the
entire Eastern Shore Peninsula of Maryland, Delaware, and Virginia.

If Wye Mills is used as a common point on each of two routes between the
lower Eastern Shore and Baltimore City, one by way of Millers Island and
the other by way of Sandy Point, a comparison of the distances from Wye
Mills to the City Hall in Baltimore City shows that the distance by way of
Sandy Point is shorter than by way of Millers Island.

The following tabulations, Tables 56 and 57, show the distances from the
City Hall in Baltimore to Wye Mills by way of the Millers Island-Tolchester
Bridge, and from the City Hall in Baltimore to Wye Mills by way of the
Sandy Point-Kent Island Bridge.

The difference by these routes is less than 5 miles, the Sandy Point route
being the shorter. This would indicate that either route would have nearly
the same advantages for all traffic to Baltimore originating on the lower
Eastern Shore Peninsula. Each of the routes has advantages and disad-
vantages. Each of the routes would adequately connect Baltimore with
the lower Eastern Shore Peninsula. The Millers Island route would ade-
quately connect the entire Eastern Shore of Maryland with the City of
Baltimore, but would have the disadvantage of not serving Anne Arundel
County, the City of Annapolis, and Southern Maryland generally, as well
as the City of Washington, as directly as the Sandy Point site would serve
this section of Maryland and the City of Washington.

On the other hand, the Sandy Point site, in addition to adequately con-
necting the lower Eastern Shore with the City of Baltimore, would also
