field_edited_text_processed:
BRIDGE SITES 131

to Sandy Point, and, on the Eastern Shore, an approach to the bridge more
than 1 mile long, between the bridge head and Stevensville.

It is proposed to leave the Ritchie Highway in the vicinity of Jones Sta-
tion and from this point to construct a new dual highway across the neck
between the Severn and Magothy Rivers to the bridge. This distance is
7.62 miles. The project itself is 5.00 miles long, consisting of 4.08 miles of
bridge structure and 0.92 miles of embankments and approach roads, and the
new construction required on Kent Island to connect the project with
existing Route 404 is 1.38 miles long, making a total of 14.00 miles of new
construction, including the bridge structure.

If the Millers Island location for the Bay crossing should be selected,
the existing ferries operating between Annapolis and the Eastern Shore
should be maintained in service to accommodate Eastern Shore-Annapolis
traffic. This ferry, under these conditions, should probably be operated as a
public facility rather than under private ownership because of the un-
certainties in prospective revenues, due to the bridge competition, even
if the bridge is as far away as the Millers Island site.

In case the Sandy Point-Kent Island site should be adopted for the Chesa-
peake Bay Crossing, the Annapolis Ferry would not be needed as a supple-
mentary means of handling traffic, and in such event should not be allowed to
operate in competition with the bridge, because of their close proximity.
In this case the ferry would have to be purchased by the State and the service
abandoned entirely. It is therefore apparent that the cost of the purchase
of the ferry must be included as a part of the cost of the structure at either
site, but in the case of the adoption of the Sandy Point site, the ferry would
be abandoned and would therefore form no additional source of revenue;
whereas in the case of the adoption of the Millers Island site, the ferry
would have to be purchased and would also have to be maintained and oper-
ated as a public ferry.

In order to compare the distances between the City Hall in Baltimore
and prominent points on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, the following tabu-
lation, Table 58, is presented.

The above comparison shows that the distance from Baltimore to Easton,
to Denton, to Cambridge, to Salisbury, or to Ocean City, Maryland, is
shorter via the Sandy Point Bridge site than it is via the Millers Island
Bridge site, and that the distance from Baltimore to Chestertown, or to
Centerville is greater via the Sandy Point Bridge site than it is via the
Millers Island Bridge site.

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED BRIDGE AT MILLERS ISLAND

The plans for the Chesapeake Bay Bridge between Millers Island and
Tolchester provide for the construction of a two lane highway and bridge
beginning at Patapsco River Neck, thence across the inlet to Hart Island,
across Hart Island, across the inlet to Millers Island, across Millers Island to
its northeast point, and from this point straight across the Chesapeake
Bay to the Eastern Shore of Maryland, in the vicinity of Tolchester. For
detailed information refer to ‘“Plan and Profile,” Plates 84 and 85. The
inlets above described are crossed by means of concrete pile trestle con-
struction. The Islands are crossed by means of filled causeways. The
filled causeway, also, is proposed to extend out into the Bay for a distance
of about 2100 feet from the northeast tip of Millers Island. The crossing
from the end of this causeway to the Eastern Shore is effected by means of
a steel bridge supported on concrete piers. The bridge and its approaches
are more than ten miles long.

The plans submitted to the War Department provided for two main chan-
nel crossings. Each of these main channel crossings consisted of cantilever
spans 716 feet long, flanked on each side by anchor spans 358 feetlong. The
span over the west channel, due to the skew at which the channel crosses
under the bridge, provided for a lateral clearance of 490 feet, measured nor-

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED BRIDGE AT MILLERS ISLAND

The plans for the Chesapeake Bay Bridge between Millers Island and
Tolchester provide for the construction of a two lane highway and bridge
beginning at Patapsco River Neck, thence across the inlet to Hart Island,
across Hart Island, across the inlet to Millers Island, across Millers Island to
its northeast point, and from this point straight across the Chesapeake
Bay to the Eastern Shore of Maryland, in the vicinity of Tolchester. For
detailed information refer to ‘“Plan and Profile,” Plates 84 and 85. The
inlets above described are crossed by means of concrete pile trestle con-
struction. The Islands are crossed by means of filled causeways. The
filled causeway, also, is proposed to extend out into the Bay for a distance
of about 2100 feet from the northeast tip of Millers Island. The crossing
from the end of this causeway to the Eastern Shore is effected by means of
a steel bridge supported on concrete piers. The bridge and its approaches
are more than ten miles long.

The plans submitted to the War Department provided for two main chan-
nel crossings. Each of these main channel crossings consisted of cantilever
spans 716 feet long, flanked on each side by anchor spans 358 feetlong. The
span over the west channel, due to the skew at which the channel crosses
under the bridge, provided for a lateral clearance of 490 feet, measured nor-

field_edited_text_processed:
PRoOPOSED BRIDGE AT MILLERS ISLAND 133

mal to the axis of the channel, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. The
span over the east channel provided for a lateral clearance of 636 feet, with
a vertical clearance of 140 feet. _

Following the submission of plans for this bridge, together with plans for
the other bridges, to the United States District Engineers’ Office in Balti-
more, for the approval of the War Department, J. E. Greiner Company
maintained contact with the office of the Chief of Engineers of the War
Department, in Washington, to determine what changes would be required
in the plans submitted, in order to meet all navigation requirements. The
Chief of Engineers had studied the navigation requirements for a bridge
across the Bay between Millers Island and Tolchester, and had determined
that the east end of the bridge would have to be shifted northerly, in
order to place the axis of the bridge on a line normal to the main
sailing course used by pilots in navigating the east channel of the Bay at
this point. Due to the broad expanse of open water, the Engineers of the
War Department determined that navigation of this channel would require
1,000 feet lateral clearance, with 140 feet vertical clearance, which is the
same vertical clearance as originally proposed and is the same as the maxi-
mum vertical clearance afforded by the existing lift bridges over the C.
& D. Canal.

Studies by the Engineers of the War Department, of the West channel
crossing diagonally under the bridge, from the mouth of the Patapsco River
to the vicinity of the western entrance to the C. & D. Canal, led to a de-
cision on the part of these Engineers that a span over this channel, if made
500 feet clear laterally and 50 feet high vertically, would be adequate for
the present and future navigation needs of this channel.

Upon consideration of the East Channel navigation requirements, it was
decided by the Engineers of the War Department to locate the channel
nearer to the Eastern shore, and to require a horizontal clearance of 1000
feet, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. These changes greatly increase
the cost of the channel span, and also make necessary a long approach
trestle on shore.

In addition, it was thought advisable by the Engineers of the War De-
partment to require a drawspan in the trestle connecting the Western shore
and Hart Island, which would have 80 feet horizontal clearance and 15
feet vertical clearance, with span in closed position. This drawspan has
not been shown on Plate 84, but its cost has been included in Cost Estimate,
Table 76.

The above requirements were discussed informally, however, and were
field_edited_text_value:
PRoOPOSED BRIDGE AT MILLERS ISLAND 133

mal to the axis of the channel, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. The
span over the east channel provided for a lateral clearance of 636 feet, with
a vertical clearance of 140 feet. _

Following the submission of plans for this bridge, together with plans for
the other bridges, to the United States District Engineers’ Office in Balti-
more, for the approval of the War Department, J. E. Greiner Company
maintained contact with the office of the Chief of Engineers of the War
Department, in Washington, to determine what changes would be required
in the plans submitted, in order to meet all navigation requirements. The
Chief of Engineers had studied the navigation requirements for a bridge
across the Bay between Millers Island and Tolchester, and had determined
that the east end of the bridge would have to be shifted northerly, in
order to place the axis of the bridge on a line normal to the main
sailing course used by pilots in navigating the east channel of the Bay at
this point. Due to the broad expanse of open water, the Engineers of the
War Department determined that navigation of this channel would require
1,000 feet lateral clearance, with 140 feet vertical clearance, which is the
same vertical clearance as originally proposed and is the same as the maxi-
mum vertical clearance afforded by the existing lift bridges over the C.
& D. Canal.

Studies by the Engineers of the War Department, of the West channel
crossing diagonally under the bridge, from the mouth of the Patapsco River
to the vicinity of the western entrance to the C. & D. Canal, led to a de-
cision on the part of these Engineers that a span over this channel, if made
500 feet clear laterally and 50 feet high vertically, would be adequate for
the present and future navigation needs of this channel.

Upon consideration of the East Channel navigation requirements, it was
decided by the Engineers of the War Department to locate the channel
nearer to the Eastern shore, and to require a horizontal clearance of 1000
feet, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. These changes greatly increase
the cost of the channel span, and also make necessary a long approach
trestle on shore.

In addition, it was thought advisable by the Engineers of the War De-
partment to require a drawspan in the trestle connecting the Western shore
and Hart Island, which would have 80 feet horizontal clearance and 15
feet vertical clearance, with span in closed position. This drawspan has
not been shown on Plate 84, but its cost has been included in Cost Estimate,
Table 76.

The above requirements were discussed informally, however, and were

field_edited_text_processed:
134 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

not intended to indicate that the War Department would approve the bridge
on the basis of these requirements. At the bridge hearing before the United
States District Engineer, in Baltimore, the Commanding Officer of the
Aberdeen Proving Grounds, where the Government has made an expendi-
ture of millions of dollars, filed a vigorous objection to the construction of
a bridge at this site stating that it would destroy the range used in testing
long range guns and ammunition; and it is the opinion of the Engineers
connected with this project that the War Department will not further con-
sider the approval of plans for a bridge at this location.

The State Roads Commission has been advised from time to time of the
status of the War Department’s consideration of the plans for this and the
other bridges. The revisions which were discussed with the War Depart-
ment Engineers, and which have been described above, have been made in
the plans for this bridge. Estimates of cost, however, as shown in Table
76, are based upon navigation requirements indicated as necessary to meet
the War Department approval, in case future consideration by the War
Department should be given to the approval of a bridge at this site.

The estimates of cost submitted to the Public Works Administration, in
connection with the Application for Grant, now pending, were based on the
plans as submitted originally to the War Department, and no longer will
hold because of the informally suggested increased requirements. For that
reason the accompanying estimates of cost are considerably higher than
those originally submitted. The increased estimates of cost, as now sub-
mitted, are based upon main channel spans and Hart Island Drawspan
made to conform to the informal suggestions of the War Department
Engineers together with approach and low level construction similar to that
originally proposed.

inches wide.

The United States War Department has determined that a bridge at this
site would have to be moved south, in order to provide a longer straight-
away approach to the channel span in the navigation ship channel. The
War Department has further determined that a channel span over the east
channel will be unnecessary, but that the channel span over the west chan-
nel shall provide 1,200 feet lateral clearance, instead of 1,000 feet, with the:
same vertical clearance of 175 feet. The plans for this bridge, as shown on
Plates 66 to 82 inclusive conform to these requirements of the War De-
partment.

136 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

the west approach; and about 100 feet of approach on the shore to the east
end of the project, making a total length of 26,372 feet between the crossing
limits.

The west approach is on a curve of approximately 2 degrees curvature.
Although the “Plan and Profile”” shown on Plate 67 has been drawn in the
projected position, making the entire bridge to appear straight, the curved
alignment is shown on the small “Location Plan,” at the lower left corner
of the plate. The estimates of cost submitted to the Public Works Ad-
ministration in connection with the application for grant now pending,
were based on the plans as submitted originally to the War Department.
The accompanying estimates of cost are different from those originally
submitted, because of the changes in location and navigation openings
described above.

NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS

The site for the proposed Chesapeake Bay Bridge between Sandy Point
and Kent Island, as submitted to the War Department, was one-half mile
south of the Sandy Point Lighthouse, and three miles south of the existing
buoyed entrance to the Craig Hill Channel. The main channel span across
the west channel of the Bay, at this point, was located immediately west of
the line fixed by the red sector of the Thomas Point Shoal Lighthouse, in
water between 55 and 60 feet deep, and at a distance of approximately one
mile east of Sandy Point.

The span proposed across this channel consisted of one main 1,200 feet
channel span, and two 600 feet side spans. The main span provided a
vertical clearance of 175 feet for the full clear width of 1,000 feet; and the
side spans provided a minimum vertical clearance of 155 feet for the full
lateral clearance of about 525 feet.

The construction of this bridge with such a main channel span at the site
proposed would have had the effect of forming a new entrance to the Craig
Hill Channel into the Port of Baltimore. The War Department has de-
termined that this clearance and site fail to meet navigation requirements,
and has indicated to J. E. Greiner Co. the basis on which plans for a bridge
at the site farther down the Bay will be approved. The angle of crossing
the Bay has been changed, in order to place the bridge at right angles to the
line of navigation at this part of the Bay, and the span has been increased
to provide for 1,200 feet lateral clearance, instead of 1,000 feet. Only the
main channel span is required, so that the additional smaller high level span
near the Eastern shore, which was proposed originally, has been omitted.

TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS

The surveys conducted under the supervision of J. E. Greiner Company,
in connection with the preparation of this Engineering Report, at this site,
consisted of surveys from the North Point Road across the intervening in-
lets from the Patapsco River Neck to Hart Island and to Millers Island,
and also complete surveys of the east approach to the bridge, in order to
connect the bridge with the existing highway system in the vicinity of Tol-
chester and Fairlee.

The distances from Millers Island to Tolchester for both the location of
the bridge, as submitted to the War Department for approval, and that
indicated by the War Department as the location which may be required
in the future, if the War Department decides to further consider the ap-
proval of plans for a bridge in this location, have been scaled from the U. S.
Coast and Geodetic Survey Maps, and are subject to future check either
with survey geodetic points previously established, the locations of which
are known definitely, or with a future survey at the site suggested by the
War Department Engineers.

The surveys at the Sandy Point-Kent Island site, as proposed on the plans
which were submitted to the War Department for approval, included com-
plete surveys supervised by J. E. Greiner Company in connection with the
preparation of this Engineering Report, and included a reconnaissance
survey extending from the present Gov. Ritchie Highway across the neck
between the Magothy and Severn Rivers to Skidmore and surveys from
Skidmore to the shore line at Sandy Point; a similar line extending from
Stevensville to the shore line on Kent Island at the point selected for the
bridge location; and complete soundings across the Bay at the site of the
bridge. These surveys, including the triangulation across the Bay, were
tied into the U. S. Coast and Geodetic Triangulation Stations in this vicinity,
and included the establishment of new geodetic points for the complete
triangulation and establishment of accurate distances between permanent
hubs, which have been set at this site. These geodetic points were used to
locate the position of test holes at this site, as herein described under ‘“Bor-
ings.” The profile across the Bay at this site was established from sound-
ings taken by the Survey Corps, under J. E. Greiner Company’s supervision,
and checked against the boat charts made by the U. S. Coast and Geodetic
Survey:

The site which has been indicated by the War Department Engineers, as
that for which plans will be approved by the War Department, has been

field_edited_text_processed:
138 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

established from the geodetic points fixed in conducting the surveys, above
described, and can be relied upon as accurate within reasonable limits; al-
though extensions of the existing surveys will have to be made when actual
construction work is started at this new location. As hereinbefore stated
under ‘“Engineering Procedure,” these surveys together with the surveys
for other crossings in this program have been tied into the U. S. Coast and
Geodetic System, and at one time there were six men assigned by the U. S.
Coast and Geodetic Survey in the coordination of the State Surveys with
the U. S. Survey System.

BORINGS

No borings were made at the Millers Island-Tolchester Site. The line
which was submitted for the approval of the War Department at the hearing
on July 12, 1938, was determined on the basis of data made available by the
United States Coast and Geodetic Survey. Of course, before a bridge could
have been built at this site, it would have been necessary to make borings
to determine the character of the underlying strata. Likewise, no borings
had been made on the site which has been indicated by the War Depart-
ment to be the site required if this bridge is to be further considered.

Complete subsurface explorations at the site from Sandy Point to Kent
Island were made under the supervision of J. E. Greiner Company, in con-
nection with the preparation of this Engineering Report. Plans were
prepared showing the location of the proposed borings at this site, and were
submitted to contractors for bids in the latter part of July, 1938. The
work consisted of a sub-surface exploration by means of wash borings, dry
samples, and core borings, as required, at intervals of approximately 1,000
feet for the width of the Bay at this point. Borings were extended to a
maximum depth of about 250 feet, and the various strata through which
these borings passed at each of the boring locations are shown on ‘‘Borings,”’
Plate 73.

The borings at this location had about been completed when J. E. Greiner
Company was advised by the War Department Engineers that the loca-
tion for this bridge would have to be shifted down the Bay to a new location.
The boring equipment was immediately moved to the new location, at
which five new borings were made: one at each of the main pier locations
at the navigation channel, and others at intermediate points, as a check to
determine whether or not the substrata conditions at the new site were
the same as at the originally selected site. The five borings at the new site
confirmed the fact that the conditions are about the same at either site,

field_edited_text_processed:
FounbpATIONS 139

and also confirmed statements of Geologists which have been made to the
effect that this entire section of the Chesapeake Bay is underlain by heavy
sand deposits, as has been shown by every boring made at either of the
two sites.

The results of the borings have led to the adoption of the foundation
types which have been used as a basis for estimating the cost of the con-
struction of this bridge. The foundations adopted are the result of studies
of these sub-surface conditions, and are well adapted for use where these
particular foundation conditions exist.

FOUNDATIONS

The foundations for the bridge at Sandy Point include, principally, three
types of pier construction. The main channel piers have been estimated
on the basis of the pier type shown on “Piers,” Plate 77.

The method of construction proposed has been tried out and involves no
unusual construction procedure. The general principles of construction
involve the displacement of the relatively shallow stratum of mud at the
location of these main channel piers by the dumping of a large surcharge of
sand fill at the sites of the piers; the driving of sheet pile cofferdams around
the outside of the pier foundations; the digging out of the material to a
point below the mud and well into the sand over the area inside of the cof-
ferdam, thus constructed; the driving of wide flange steel beams, called
““H Sections,” as piles; the pouring of a tremie seal of the width, length and
depth, shown on the plate referred to above, over the area of the foundation
and encasing the piles previously driven; the unwatering of the dam by
pumping it out; the capping of the piles for proper bearing between the con-
crete and the steel piles; and, finally, the construction of the pier base and
pier stems in the dry after the cofferdam has been completely unwatered
down to the top of the tremie seal.

The remaining principal piers are of two types: one type is much larger
than the other on account of the necessity for longitudinally anchoring the
bridge at intervals. The piers used for this longitudinal anchorage are
much larger than the intermediate piers used for supporting vertical loads
only. The anchor piers are approximately twice the size of the intermediate
piers. The construction procedure is similar in either case.

The estimates of cost, herein presented, include the use of seamless steel
tubes 24 inches or 26 inches in diameter, with one-half inch thickness of
metal, as piles, and the capping of these piles with a tremie cap which, in

pumping it out; the capping of the piles for proper bearing between the con-
crete and the steel piles; and, finally, the construction of the pier base and
pier stems in the dry after the cofferdam has been completely unwatered
down to the top of the tremie seal.

The remaining principal piers are of two types: one type is much larger
than the other on account of the necessity for longitudinally anchoring the
bridge at intervals. The piers used for this longitudinal anchorage are
much larger than the intermediate piers used for supporting vertical loads
only. The anchor piers are approximately twice the size of the intermediate
piers. The construction procedure is similar in either case.

The estimates of cost, herein presented, include the use of seamless steel
tubes 24 inches or 26 inches in diameter, with one-half inch thickness of
metal, as piles, and the capping of these piles with a tremie cap which, in

field_edited_text_processed:
140 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

turn, supports concrete filled steel cylinders extending above the water line
and connected by means of concrete diaphragm walls from points below the
water line to the tops of the cylinders, all as shown on ‘‘Piers,” Plate 76.
This type of pier, although quite simple, involves construction procedure,
each step of which is simple in itself, but which is different from that which
has been previously, generally, used in similar foundation conditions. The
methods and resulting foundation conditions have been checked carefully
by J. E. Greiner Company and by specialists called in by that Company
for that purpose, and every assurance is given that the estimates of cost are
adequate and that the methods are so simplified that there can be no ques-
tion as to meeting a construction schedule, because exigencies which would
tend to interrupt a completion schedule have been eliminated.

TYPICAL PIER DESIGN

The typical pier design presented herein is typical for the design of a pier
under foundation conditions similar to those existing at either the Millers
Island-Tolchester Site or at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site. Pier
No. 33, shown on Plate 76 of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, Sandy Point-
Kent Island Site, which supports one end of a 600 feet cantilever span and
one end of a 480 feet anchor span and forms the longitudinal anchorage for
a unit consisting of two spans, has been selected as a typical pier and its
analysis is herein presented as an illustration of the method used to design
the foundations for this bridge. An outline of the pier and the forces to
which it is subjected are shown on Figure 15.

Conditions Investigated:
Case 1. D + 309, Lateral W + C + 151
Case 2. D + 309, Lateral W + C + 1
Case3. D+ L+ C+ I+ 159 Lateral W
Case4. D+ L + C + I+ 159, Lateral W + L.L. Traction
Case 5. Case 1-2-3 or 4, substituting Longitudinal W in place of Lateral W
Note: Although permissible, increased allowable unit stresses have not been specified
for Cases 2, 3 and 4.

SUPERSTRUCTURE

The design of the bridge superstructure at both sites is based upon the
use of structural steel spans throughout. Silicon steel has been used in the
design of the main truss members. Structural grade carbon steel has been
used for minor truss members, floor systems, and beam spans.

Types of Spans
Flve types of spans have been adopted for the Sandy Point-Kent Island

1. Beam Spans

2. Plate Girder Spans

3. Truss Spans

4. Type “C” Cantilever Spans
5. Type “A” Cantilever Span

SUPERSTRUCTURE

The design of the bridge superstructure at both sites is based upon the
use of structural steel spans throughout. Silicon steel has been used in the
design of the main truss members. Structural grade carbon steel has been
used for minor truss members, floor systems, and beam spans.

Types of Spans
Flve types of spans have been adopted for the Sandy Point-Kent Island

1. Beam Spans

2. Plate Girder Spans

3. Truss Spans

4. Type “C” Cantilever Spans
5. Type “A” Cantilever Span

field_edited_text_processed:
RoADWAY 147

With the exception of the Type “A” Cantilever Span, all structures are of
the deck type. The Type “A” Span is of the through type because of navi-
gation requirements.

The lengths and types of spans were largely determined by the criterion,
that the economical span length is a function of the cost of piers and cost
of steel in the superstructure. Full advantage was taken of any possible
duplication of spans and the resulting decreased cost of fabrication. The
economic possibilities of various schemes of erection were also studied.

Specifications

The designs on which this report is based were made in accordance with
the provisions of the Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges of the
American Association of State Highway Officials, dated 1935. This speci-
fication is widely used throughout the United States and is considered au-
thoritative, its requirements being in line with the most modern structural
practice. It is expected that the final designs will be in accordance with
this specification, modified slightly as may be found necessary because of
the unusual size and importance of the structure.

Lave Load

The bridge is designed to carry two lanes, (H-20 loading), each lane 12
feet wide. This loading is as specified by the American Association of State
Highway Officials and is believed ample for present and future conditions.

ROADWAY

The roadway for the Chesapeake Bay Bridge will be the same for either
the Millers Island-Tolchester Site or the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site
and will consist of an open mesh type flooring filled with concrete, which
when completed will present the appearance of a concrete roadway surface.
The weight of the floor in the design of the bridge includes an allowance
for the future addition of two inches of asphalt or other wearing surface.

The plans provide for dividing the roadway into two lanes by the construc-
tion of permanent roadway markers in the surface of the roadway slab.
The central marker will be a colored stripe obtained by the use of colored
aggregates laid monolithically with the other concrete to divide the bridge
into two lanes operating in opposite.directions. Colored stripes will also
be constructed immediately adjacent and parallel to the curbs.

The footways for this bridge have been designed 1 foot 6 inches wide
and are intended as emergency footways only, since little, if any, pedestrian

use is to be expected. Their chief value consists in making it possible for

TOLL PLAZA

The toll plaza at either site will be designed to provide two traffic lanes
passing under the toll booth canopy, and two traffic lanes passing in the
clear outside of the canopy with one toll island equipped with two toll booths.
The lanes outside the canopy are intended to pass vehicles or equipment too

GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSE FOR MAINTAINING AND OPERATING
THE BRIDGES

Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, have
estimated the general and administrative expense for maintaining and
operating bridge combinations as tabulated above. This tabulation,
Table 61, is herein reproduced for the purpose of ready reference.

MAINTENANCE, OPERATION, AND INSURANCE

Coverdale and Colpitts have also estimated the operating expenses for
each of the crossings in the program, and the tabulation of such expenses
for the operation, maintenance and insurance requirements for the proposed
Chesapeake Bay Crossings are herein tabulated for ready reference in
Table 62.

TRAFFIC REPORT

Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, under
date of September 3, 1938 have reported to the State Roads Commission on
estimated traffic, gross revenues, and toll schedules for the crossings included
in the State of Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program. The estimates in
this report show that a bridge at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site may
be expected to produce $113,000 more gross revenue than a bridge at the
Millers Island-Tolchester Site, if each crossing be considered as an inde-
pendent unit on the assumption that none of the other crossings is con-
structed. The gross revenues have been estimated on the basis of a toll
rate of $1.00 per passenger car and twenty cents for each extra passenger,
with bus and truck rates as set forth in detail in the report and as herein
listed for convenient reference in Table 63.

The estimates of number of vehicles and gross revenues for the first five
years of operation and the average of the first five years are tabulated in
Table 64 for both the Millers Island-Tolchester and Sandy Point-Kent
Island Sites.

The traffic engineers have estimated that a bridge at the Sandy Point-

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME OF COMPLETION

The Progress Chart, Plate 83, shows graphically the periods of time re-
quired for the different phases of engineering and construction, for the
Chesapeake Bay Bridge, Sandy Point-Kent Island Site. Similar data
has not been prepared for the Millers Island-Tolchester Site. The chart
shows the period of time from May, 1938 to June, 1941, the date on which
the bridge is herein scheduled for completion. The first phase of the engi-
neering work including the topographical surveys, sub-surface investigations,
navigation studies, preliminary comparative studies and estimates, War
Department Permit Drawings and preliminary plans and specifications
developed as a basis for estimates of construction cost, and all else required
for the completion of the engineering report herein presented, is shown on
field_edited_text_value:
152 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE

Kent Island site will produce $104,000 more gross revenue than a bridge at
the Millers Island-Tolchester Site for an average of five years, if either of
these Bay Crossings were combined with all of the three crossings in the
North-South Highway including Susquehanna, Patapsco and Potomac
River. The estimates of vehicles and gross revenue for the first five years
of operation, and the average of the first five years are tabulated in Table 65.

CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TIME OF COMPLETION

The Progress Chart, Plate 83, shows graphically the periods of time re-
quired for the different phases of engineering and construction, for the
Chesapeake Bay Bridge, Sandy Point-Kent Island Site. Similar data
has not been prepared for the Millers Island-Tolchester Site. The chart
shows the period of time from May, 1938 to June, 1941, the date on which
the bridge is herein scheduled for completion. The first phase of the engi-
neering work including the topographical surveys, sub-surface investigations,
navigation studies, preliminary comparative studies and estimates, War
Department Permit Drawings and preliminary plans and specifications
developed as a basis for estimates of construction cost, and all else required
for the completion of the engineering report herein presented, is shown on

field_edited_text_processed:
CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURE AND TiME oF COMPLETION 153

the Progress Chart as extending over the period from May to Septem-
ber 30, 1938.

The second phase of the engineering work including the preparation of
contract plans and specifications, other contract documents, advertising,
receiving bids, investigation of bidders, award of the contracts, and all
work required preliminary to the beginning of the actual work of construc-
tion is shown as extending from the first week in October, 1938, until the
third week in December, 1938, except that this phase of the engineering work
for certain portions of the superstructure design, the administration building
and toll facilities, and such other engineering work in this second phase of
engineering as may be extended into the period during the early months of
1939, have been so shown.

The actual work of construction, beginning with the grading and embank-
ments required for the construction of the approaches and the pile bents,
is shown as being started on the first of January, 1939 and is followed
on February 15, 1939 by that part of the work of construction for the piers,
which can be done on shore. The approval of shop drawings and the fab-
rication of steel work is scheduled to be carried on simultaneously with the
construction of the substructure, in order that steel erection can be started
as soon as various parts of the substructure are ready to receive steel, and
in order that the progress of steel erection be coordinated with the comple-
tion of the remaining parts of the substructure.

Most of the work of construction will have been started during the
calendar year of 1939 and the schedule of completion provides for the com-
pletion of the entire substructure by February 15, 1940, except for the fenders
to protect the main channel piers, which are scheduled for completion during
the calendar year of 1940. The paving and administration building and
toll facilities of the approaches are scheduled for the construction season
beginning in April, 1940, and extending through the month of September
of that year. During the early months of 1941, construction work will be
confined to erection of the superstructure only. As soon as the weather in
the spring of 1941 will permit, the painting of the superstructure and the
remaining portions of the roadway floor are scheduled for completion, with
the opening of the bridge for traffic, in the middle of June, 1941, as repre-
sented on the chart by the completion of the roadway flooring. After that
date there may still remain small portions of painting work to be completed
which, based on the schedule herein presented, will all have been finished
by the completion date of June 30, 1941, named above.

Alternate Design

Since the completion of the engineering work, upon which the estimated
cost herein presented is based, J. E. Greiner Company has investigated the
possible use of determinate continuous truss spans of a patented type,
instead of the Type “C’ cantilever truss spans estimated herein. The
arrangement of the spans, in case such continuous truss type is used, will be
somewhat different from the arrangement shown for this bridge in Volume
II, “Plates.” The question of the use of this alternate truss type will be
taken up with the Commission, and, if so authorized, J. E. Greiner Company
will submit a supplemental report to cover the results of the further in-
vestigations. Present indications are that the use of statically determinate
continuous truss units of this patented design will effect a considerable
saving. The question of royalties, which the Commission might have to
pay for a license to use the patented type of trusses, will be an element in
determining possible savings.

CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

The conclusions to be drawn from the foregoing report on the Chesapeake
Bay Bridge may be summarized as follows:
(1) The three Bay ferries now operating between the Eastern and Western

field_edited_text_processed:
CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 163

Shores are inadequate as connections of the highways of the State, separated
by the Chesapeake Bay, when measured in the terms of modern rapid trans-
portation afforded by the automobile and modern highways.

(2) The geographical location of the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site
makes the distance from Baltimore to the majority of the county seats on
the Eastern Shore of Maryland shorter than when a connection by way of
Millers Island and Tolchester is considered.

(3) A bridge at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site will serve more people
than a bridge at the Millers Island-Tolchester Site, because, in addition to
being quite as accessible for the metropolitan area of Baltimore, as is the
Millers Island Site, it is in closer proximity to Annapolis and Wash-
ington.

(4) The bridge at Millers Island is longer than the bridge at Sandy
Point, although its construction cost is less. The alignment of the highway,
of which the Millers Island Bridge would become a part, is indirect, since
it is necessary to travel north from the Patapsco River Neck across Hart and
Millers Islands before crossing the Bay, and for traffic between Baltimore
and the Lower Eastern Shore, a similar distance south on the Eastern Shore
1s necessary, thus increasing the distance between Baltimore and Centerville
or Wye Mills over the distance which it would be necessary to travel if the
location of this bridge were shifted south to connect Patapsco River Neck
with the Eastern Shore direct at a point between Tolchester and Rock
Hall.

(6) The War Department has required a lateral clearance of 1000 feet
and a vertical clearance of 140 feet over the east channel near Tolchester,
as compared to 1200 feet lateral clearance and 175 feet vertical clearance
required near Sandy Point. These requirements recognize the greater
importance of the channel between Baltimore and the Virginia capes, as
compared with the channel between Baltimore and the C & D Canal. The
War Department has, however, required that a secondary long span be
placed over the west channel of the Bay, between Millers Island and
Tolchester and has indicated the probable necessity for a movable span in
the crossing between Patapsco River Neck and Hart Island.

(6) Although the water depths between Sandy Point and Kent Island
are considerably greater than the depths between Millers Island and Tol-
chester, the heavy sand stratum underlying the Sandy Point Site, for the
entire width of the Bay, makes the foundation conditions at this site better
than the water depths would indicate, and the foundation conditions at the
site of the main channel span at Sandy Point are considerably better than
